DEBT.CAMPAIGN_HEADER: Welcome! There's more to debt than a number on a statement. Your family history, money, values, and spending habits all contribute to your debt narrative.
DEBT.CAMPAIGN_SUBHEADER: Answer these quick questions before diving in on this journey.

PAYOFF_PROJECTOR_WHAT_IF.MAIN: In Step 2, you entered your debt details and chose a payoff strategy. Now, use this tool to change it up. Enter a lump sum amount or increase your monthly payment and new projections will appear.
PAYOFF_PROJECTOR_WHAT_IF.SECONDARY: Save that time and money by hitting "commit". This will update your payment schedule.

PAYOFF_STRATEGIES.DEFAULT: Pay off the debt using your current monthly payments.
PAYOFF_STRATEGIES.AVALANCHE: Pay off the debt with the highest interest rate first.
PAYOFF_STRATEGIES.SNOWBALL: Pay off the debt with the smallest balance first.
PAYOFF_STRATEGIES.USER_ORDER: Pay off the debt that causes the most personal angst.

PAYOFF_STRATEGY_STEP.STRATEGY_STEP_MESSAGE1: All of them - except your current payments -
PAYOFF_STRATEGY_STEP.STRATEGY_STEP_MESSAGE2: focus on paying off one debt at a time
PAYOFF_STRATEGY_STEP.STRATEGY_STEP_MESSAGE3: while paying only the minimum due on all the rest.
PAYOFF_STRATEGY_STEP.STRATEGY_STEP_MESSAGE4: Once the first debt is paid off,
PAYOFF_STRATEGY_STEP.STRATEGY_STEP_MESSAGE5: you'll reallocate those funds to the next debt, and then the next debt, etc. Ready?

PAYOFF_PROGRESS_SCREEN.PRO_TIP_MESSAGE: Make life easier by setting up automatic payments. Once you pay off a debt, roll that payment over to your next priority debt. This table shows when you'll need to change up your payments.

DEBT_FREE_MESSAGE.DEBT_FREE_MESSAGE3: you will be debt free by

FIND_MONEY_HONEY.DESCRIPTION: Let's help you find some extra cash, sound good?

LOW.CONCLUSION: When the opportunity to spend money presents itself, you usually take it. Take a look at your spending and whether the things you buy are consistent with your values.
LOW.ACTION: Try this: When you're spending, ask yourself, ‚ÄúAm I just spending to spend? Will I really get satisfaction from what I'm about to buy?‚Äù This is your life-you get to decide!

MEDIUM.CONCLUSION: Your spending seems to depend on the situation üòê. On some things you pull back, while others you go a little too far.
MEDIUM.ACTION: Try this: Think about what triggers your spending and what questions you can ask yourself before agreeing to the purchase. It's a quick little strategy that works for a lot of people!

HIGH.CONCLUSION: You know how to spend your money üòä. If you still don't feel like you have enough, it might be more about income than spending.
HIGH.ACTION: Try this: Later in this pathway, you can learn ways to increase your income without taking on a second job.

QUIZ.STAY_IN_BUDGET: Remember, your wants are for you. so treat yourself! Just stay in budget :).
QUIZ.HUNDRED_PERCENT_ERROR: These numbers don't add up :(. You need to adjust your allocations to make sure you don't budget more money than you have!

MY_SPENDING_PLAN_QUIZ.DESCRIPTION_1: It starts with understanding your spending. Are you spending more than you earn? Are there things you can live without?
MY_SPENDING_PLAN_QUIZ.DESCRIPTION_2: We recommend a 50/30/20 approach to building your budget. That way you‚Äôve got all your bases covered, but still can have some fun.

BUDGET_BREAKDOWN.TITLE: FOR MY WANTS
BUDGET_BREAKDOWN.BUDGET_AMOUNT_TEXT: Here's the amount you're able to spend on anything you'd like. Try not to go over.

CONGRATS.TITLE: Congrats!
CONGRATS.DESCRIPTION_1: You‚Äôve got your basic budget ‚Äì a set of guidelines for daily, weekly, and monthly spending.
CONGRATS.DESCRIPTION_2: Now take it to the next level and get a more advanced budget. We‚Äôll ask you more questions about your spending. Rough estimates are okay.

OVER_BUDGET.DESCRIPTION_1: You‚Äôre spending more than you‚Äôre taking in.
OVER_BUDGET.DESCRIPTION_2: Was this on purpose or an accident? Do you want to continue this way or go back and fix it?

JOHN_ACUFF_ACCOUNT_VALUE_PROPOSITION.1B: Why? Most people forget to create a roadmap before they begin. We'll help you make one in under 60 minutes.

JOHN_ACUFF_ACCOUNT_VALUE_PROPOSITION.3B: After the champagne bottle empties, motivation wanes. Which is why we'll send you reminders to help you stay focused.

FINANCIAL_WELLNESS_ASSESSMENT.OVERVIEW_INTRO: , let's take your financial wellness to the next level. Get started below.

FWADIMPRACTICAL.NAME: Practical
FWADIMPRACTICAL.DESCRIPTION: The practical dimension of money is just that: practical. It's a clear and objective look at your current financial situation, from savings to spending and everything in between. Taking a moment to look at the practical side of things will give you glimpse into your current financial strength, and where you could go in the future. With that foundation, you can identify which steps to take next.

MONTHLYINCOMEEXCEEDSHHEXPENSES.INTRODUCTION:
How are you doing with saving and spending?

Spending less than you earn-living within your means-is a good indicator of financial wellness.

ANSWERS.0:
You've got more money going out than coming in each month. That's a tough spot. Shift the balance by shrinking your spending.

What's next: Start small. Take stock of your debt and see if you can lower any interest rates. The Negotiator Challenge can help. Try it out!
ANSWERS.1:
You're not sure if you're living within your means, but it's important to find out. You'll know if you're able to pay your bills each month-and if you have any left to save for your future.

What's next: Compare what you spend to what you bring home. Think that sounds hard? Take it step by step in the Budget tool.
ANSWERS.5:
You're spending less than you earn each month. Nice work! Living within your means is the best indicator of financial wellness, and you've got it down.

What's next: Resist the urge to slip into bigger spending: Review your income and expenses regularly to make sure you continue to live within your means.

EMERGENCYSAVINGSVALUE.INTRODUCTION:
How's your emergency fund?

Having money set aside for emergencies can mean not borrowing (or borrowing as much) when an unplanned expense crops up. It's an important component of financial wellness.

ANSWERS.0:
You don't have anything set aside for emergencies. You're not alone. Roughly a third of Americans are in this vulnerable position.

What's next: Open a savings account just for emergencies. Don't know where you'll find money to put in it? Try the Set-It-and-Forget-It Challenge
ANSWERS.1:
You're not sure if you have anything set aside for emergencies. Time to make a plan!

What's next: Review your accounts: How much do you have that you could access without fees or penalties? Set up an account just for emergencies and move what you have there. Try the Set-It-and-Forget-It Challenge to find more money to put there.
ANSWERS.2:
You have some set aside for emergencies-keep building that cushion.

What's next: Want to find more you could save? Try the Set-It-and-Forget-It Challenge.
ANSWERS.3:
Good job! More than $1,000 is more than some 69% of Americans have.

What's next: If you haven't already, set up an automatic transfer into an account just for emergencies. Have you set that up already? Considering increasing it. Your goal: 3 months of income saved.
ANSWERS.4:
Great job! You've got a good base set up.

What's next: If you haven't already, set up an automatic transfer into an account just for emergencies. Have you set that up already? Considering increasing it. Your goal: 3 months of income saved.
ANSWERS.5:
Congratulations! You're better prepared for emergencies than most Americans.

What's next: Got it? Keep it. You never know when you might need money for the unexpected. If you have more to save, set up an account for your next big financial goal-a home, car or vacation.

FIXEDEXPENSESHALFINCOME.INTRODUCTION:
How much are your fixed expenses?

Think of this as money that's spent before you take out your wallet: rent or mortgage, utilities, loan payments. But fixed expenses are not set in stone. Keep them below 50% of your household income for wiggle room in your budget-and for savings.

ANSWERS.0:
You're certainly not alone, but your high fixed expenses are holding you back from achieving the kind of financial security that comes from living within your means.

What's next: Make a list to see what you could target to shrink or even eliminate. Tap into your inner diplomat and slash some expenses in the Negotiator Challenge.
ANSWERS.1:
Find out how much of your income goes to fixed expenses. Review your bank or credit card statements and add up the expenses that repeat every month. Divide that number by your monthly take-home pay and multiply by 100. That's the percent of your income that's devoted to fixed expenses.

What's next: If your fixed expenses are more than 50% of your income, make a list to see what you could shrink or even eliminate. Tap into your inner diplomat and slash some expenses in the Negotiator Challenge.
ANSWERS.3:
Good news: You're really close to the goal of spending 50% or less on fixed costs. Let's get you across the finish line!

What's next: Make a list of your fixed expenses and the amounts. Pick one or two you could reduce or eliminate. Tap into your inner diplomat and slash some expenses in the Negotiator Challenge.
ANSWERS.5:
Way to go! Keeping your expenses manageable gives you the flexibility to roll with life's punches.

What's next: Beware of spending slide. Over time, it's easy for expenses to rise without you doing anything. Watch for annual increases in your insurance premiums or internet bills. And shop around as needed.

WETRACKEXPENSES.INTRODUCTION:
Do you know what you spend?

Tracking what you spend is a good financial habit-it makes you aware of where your money is going. It allows you a bird's-eye view, helping you spend and save according to your values.

ANSWERS.0:
It may seem like just one more task to add to an already busy life, but tracking your finances is worth it. You can spend mindlessly if you're not paying attention.

What's next: Find a tracking method that works for you. Try our Budgeting Tool, which links with your accounts and gathers your spending data for you.
ANSWERS.4:
Chances are you know that tracking is a good habit. It allows you to spend and save more consciously. But you haven't quite found a routine that works.

What's next: Commit to recording every cent you spend for 21 days. Try our Budgeting Tool, which links with your accounts and gathers your spending data for you.
ANSWERS.5:
Smart! We don't need to tell you how valuable it is to stay attuned to your spending. Keep up the great work.

What's next: Schedule a monthly check-in to review your budget and expenses-and adapt as needed. Want to improve your system? Try our Budgeting Tool.

HAVEDEBTMONTHLYBALANCE.INTRODUCTION:
Has your debt got you down?

Most of us crave the freedom of being debt-free. After all, we don't want our money to cost us more money, which interest does. The goal is to pay off cards each month and pay for things in full.

ANSWERS.0:
It's easy to feel trapped when interest and fees get tacked on to a debt you already can't afford. You aren't going to wipe out what you owe overnight, but it's time to start. You can do this!

What's next:¬†Stop the fees by paying the minimum balance. Log on to your bank website and set up an automatic payment of that minimum. Don't have the funds? Call a credit counseling service or try the Negotiator Challenge.
ANSWERS.1:
Being trapped under debt can feel paralyzing. Thanks to interest, it keeps getting bigger and bigger. It's good that you're paying the minimum, but you need to chip away at more. Every little bit helps!

What's next: Make your minimum payment automatic to stop paying late fees. Then step up the payment. Need help finding extra funds? Try the Side Hustle Challenge.
ANSWERS.2:
It's good that your debt isn't rising. But paying down those balances, starting with the credit cards, will free you up to save. Then you can earn interest instead of paying it.

What's next: Make redirecting funds your new game. Instead of eating lunch out, pack a brown bag. Then use your bank's app to immediately put $10 toward your debt. Need help on lunch ideas? Try the Bag-Lunch Challenge.
ANSWERS.3:
You know that working your debt down is important, and you're on it. Are you doing everything you can?

What's next: Try the snowball method to shrink your debt. Click on this blog article to learn more: ‚ÄúHow I Paid Off $4000 in Debt Using the Snowball Method‚Äù
ANSWERS.4:
You've got the hang of this pay-down-debt thing. Awesome! You know that getting your debt to zero is important, and you're getting there as fast as you can. Check your spending to be sure.

What's next: Try the snowball method to shrink your debt. Click on this blog article to learn more: ‚ÄúHow I Paid Off $4000 in Debt Using the Snowball Method‚Äù
ANSWERS.5:
No debt? Way to go! You know how good it feels to be free from interest and loans that grow and grow. To keep it that way, prioritize your savings now to help you avoid debt in the future.

Try this: Set up an account for your next big expense. Want to take a trip? Pick a spot to fantasize about-and a budget. Then set up a savings account for that specific purpose. It feels good to save when you know what the money is for.

HHINCOMETOWARDSRENTMORTGAGE.INTRODUCTION:
Is your housing affordable?

Housing often makes up a large chunk of our fixed expenses. Sure, a larger home may be nice. But consider how the costs could affect your freedom to do other things, like traveling or giving. And a bigger home comes with bigger utility bills, insurance costs and maintenance. Aim to keep your housing costs to 30% or less of your total income before taxes.

ANSWERS.0:
While it isn't always easy, consider steps you could take to reduce your housing costs, such as refinancing or even moving. It can pay dividends in your financial security for years to come.

What's next: Call your mortgage lender or landlord and ask what you could do to reduce your monthly payment. Do you qualify for any homeowner assistance programs? Could you refinance? If you rent, could you take on maintenance duties in exchange for a discount?
ANSWERS.1:
To find out, divide the amount you pay monthly by your monthly pay before taxes. Less than 35%? You're doing great. More than that? Start thinking about how you can get the number down.

What's next: If you're paying more than 35% of your pretax income on housing and you can't move, chip away at costs you can control. Caulk your windows and turn down your thermostat. Drop your cable TV. Start a carpool.
ANSWERS.3:
You may not be able to immediately change your housing cost, but you can take other small steps.

What's next: Find one fixed expense that you can reduce and start there. For example, drop your cable TV, caulk your windows, turn down your thermostat, or start taking public transportation.
ANSWERS.5:
Great job keeping a lid on housing costs! You're in a strong position to pay off any debt more quickly-or save for your next big purchase, like a vacation, car or something else.

What's next: Monitor this if your income or housing costs change. If you decide to move to a more expensive place, remember that the costs don't stop with the monthly payment. Be sure you're ready for any trade-offs.

MONTHLYCREDITCARDBALANCE.INTRODUCTION:
How's your credit card balance?

Credit cards can be great. With a good dose of discipline, you can even get some nice rewards. But if you don't pay it off every month, credit card debt is arguably the worst type to have: high interest rates and no set end-date.

ANSWERS.0:
You know you have to do something, but where to start? Start here: Freeze your balance and find a way to pay the minimum.

What's next: Call your lender and ask if they can help. See if you qualify for a zero-interest balance transfer offer. Check out the Side Hustle Challenge for more income to pay off your debt. A credit counseling service can help you weigh your options.
ANSWERS.1:
Whatever the source of your credit card debt-day-to-day expenses or a single unexpected expense-the path forward is to spend less and pay more.

What's next: Take your credit card out of your wallet and put it in a drawer. Delete payment info on any websites where you shop. You might be surprised at how much you can avoid buying by not having credit handy. Also, check out the Side Hustle Challenge for more income to pay off your debt.
ANSWERS.2:
It's good that you aren't getting deeper in debt, but get to zero, and you're in control of your financial future. Look at the interest paid on a recent statement and think about how much you had to work just to pay for the money you've borrowed.

What's next: Call your credit card company and ask for a lower interest rate. The trick: If you succeed, don't reduce your payment. The Negotiator Challenge can also help. Try it out!
ANSWERS.3:
Your mission: Pay it down faster. After all, the sooner you get to zero, the sooner you have control of your financial future by building your savings. What will you save for?

What's next: Decide on something you could do without for just a month to save money. For example, some gyms allow you to "pause" memberships for a few months without penalty. Put that savings straight toward your credit card debt.
ANSWERS.4:
Keep up the great work! Once you clear your debt, you'll have much more financial freedom. Start dreaming (if you aren't already) of all the things you'll save for and do. How will you celebrate?

What's next: Decide on something you could do without for just a month to save money. For example, some gyms allow you to "pause" memberships for a few months without penalty. Put that savings straight toward your credit card debt.
ANSWERS.5:
Superstar! Not carrying a credit card balance month to month is saving you money you can use toward what you value most.

What's next: Keep it up! Focus on building your savings to help ensure an unexpected expense won't leave you with a credit card balance that you can't pay off.

HASHEALTHINSURANCE.INTRODUCTION:
Got health insurance?

Healthcare gets more expensive each year. If you have money saved, you might be able to cover a routine doctor visit or more. But if you land in the hospital, you could find yourself buried in debt. Health insurance covers unexpected events as well as preventive care.

ANSWERS.0:
Without health insurance, you could be financially devastated by an unexpected health problem. If cost is a concern, find out if a higher deductible or higher co-insurance plan could provide a safety net.

What's next: Usually health insurance is only available during a time of the year called "open enrollment." Find out when that is, either through your employer's plan (if you qualify) or through the open market. Mark it on your calendar.
ANSWERS.1:
Without health insurance, you could be financially devastated by an unexpected health problem, so it's important to find out. If you might be on a spouse or parent's plan, ask them. If your employer offers coverage, ask your HR representative.

What's next: Usually health insurance is only available during a time of the year called "open enrollment." Find out when that is, either through your employer's plan (if you qualify) or through the open market. Mark it on your calendar.
ANSWERS.5:
Give yourself a big pat on the back for taking this smart step to protect yourself and your finances.

What's next: Look at your coverage and make sure you're getting the most out of it. Could you get discounts for healthy habits like exercise or eating well? Do they offer programs that could help you get healthier-and save money too?

HASDISABILITYINSURANCE.INTRODUCTION:
Is your income protected?

One of the most valuable things we have is our ability to earn income. Long-term disability insurance pays a part of your income if you become sick or injured and can't work. The average claim is nearly 3 years. Could you afford to be out of work that long?

ANSWERS.0:
Likely you think it would never happen to you. Or that you have family who could help if needed. Maybe you've never thought about it at all.

What's next: Find out how much long-term disability insurance would cost you and consider applying. If your employer offers coverage, that's a good place to start. If they don't, reach out the Thrivent Financial Guidance Team to discuss options.
ANSWERS.1:
Long-term disability insurance is easy to forget, especially if your employer provides it as a part of your benefit package. But for peace of mind it's worth knowing what you have (or don't).

What's next: Contact your benefits administrator to review your coverage. Some employers enroll workers in basic plans and allow them to buy better coverage. Others require you to opt in and pay some or all of the premiums.
ANSWERS.2:
That's a solid start. If you get sick or hurt, you'll have some income to cover your expenses. Consider how much more protection you'd get by increasing your coverage amount.

What's next: Do the math to see how much your income would be with the coverage you have. How would it compare to your expenses? What changes would you have to make? Find out how much it would cost to bump it up to 50% or 75%.
ANSWERS.3:
That's a good start. If you get sick or hurt, you'll have income to cover your expenses. Consider how much more protection you'd get by increasing your coverage.

What's next: Calculate how much your income would be at your current coverage level if you were unable to work. Would you have to make changes to get by? How much more would it cost to increase your coverage to 75% of your income?
ANSWERS.4:
Way to be forward thinking! If you get sick or hurt, you'll have income to cover your expenses. Consider how much more protection you'd get by increasing your coverage.

What's next: Calculate how much your income would be at your current coverage level if you were unable to work. Would you have to make changes to get by? How much more would it cost to increase your coverage to 75% of your income?
ANSWERS.5:
You're right where we would recommend you be. If you get sick or hurt, you'll have a solid income base to cover most (if not all) of your expenses-and possibly even keep making progress on your savings goals too.

What's next: Check in periodically with your plan to make sure you're getting the best possible rates on your coverage. Otherwise keep doing what you're doing.

HASLIFEINSURANCE.INTRODUCTION:
Do you have life insurance?

Nobody likes thinking about death. But if something happened to you, you'd want your loved ones to be taken care of. That's why there's life insurance. Don't work outside the home? It could still cost a great deal to hire someone to do what you do.

ANSWERS.0:
Consider applying for coverage. It doesn't cost as much as you might think. If you passed away unexpectedly, what would you want taken care of for your family? Your mortgage and other loans is a good place to start.

What's next: Get a quote to find out how much a life insurance policy would cost you. You might be surprised at how affordable this peace of mind can be. Reach out to the Thrivent Financial Guidance Team to discuss options.
ANSWERS.1:
It's great that you have some coverage, but it's important to know how much. Do you have enough to pay off loans and replace your income for a period of time? Three times your yearly income is a good place to start.

What's next: Check with your policyholder to find how much coverage you have and how much it costs. If you have life insurance through your work, does your employer let you add more coverage? If not, reach out to the Thrivent Financial Guidance Team to discuss options.
ANSWERS.2:
It's great that you have coverage, and it may seem like a lot. But your loved ones could be affected by the loss of your income for years. How much coverage it would take to really protect your family?

What's next: Get a quote for increasing your coverage to at least 3 times your yearly income. Seem extravagant? Imagine the expenses your family could be left with if you died. If you're interested, reach out to the Thrivent Financial Guidance Team to discuss options.
ANSWERS.3:
While that's a good amount of coverage to have, you may want to consider more. What would you want paid off if something happened to you? Your mortgage? Other loans? Your children's education?

What's next: Get a quote for increasing your coverage. Think of 5 or even 10 times your income. Seem extravagant? Imagine the expenses your family could be left with if you died.
ANSWERS.4:
That's a terrific amount of coverage to have, but you may still want to consider more. Think about what you'd want to be taken care of if something happened to you. Your mortgage? Other loans? Your children's education?

What's next: Could you increase your coverage? Ten times your income is a great target. Seem extravagant? Imagine the expenses your family could be left with if you died, not to mention the loss of your income.
ANSWERS.5:
Great work! You're right at the recommended amount for most people. Bet it feels great to have the peace of mind of knowing your family would be taken care of financially if the worst happened.

What's next: Make sure to keep up with your premiums, so your coverage doesn't lapse. If your finances change substantially, give your policy a checkup to make sure you still have the right amount of coverage.

RETIREMENTSAVINGSINCOME.INTRODUCTION:
Are you saving for retirement?

Starting to save for retirement is so important when you're young. Saving a little bit earlier can be worth more than saving a lot later. Still, it's never too late to start.

Note: While saving for retirement is very important, be sure you have money saved elsewhere too-for goals, purchases or unplanned expenses that could occur before you retire.

ANSWERS.0:
Retirement seems a lifetime away, and there are so many things to do with your money today. But there are a lot of reasons it's worth it to start saving something early-even if it's not very much.

What's next: Set up an automatic deposit into a retirement account, even if it's just a few dollars a month. See if your employer offers a payroll deduction. If not, you can open an IRA on your own. Need help finding extra cash? Try the Bag-Lunch Challenge.
ANSWERS.1:
Knowing how much you're saving now can help you to set financial goals, like increasing your contributions as you're able.

What's next: If you have a retirement plan through your employer, check the website to see what you're saving. If you have an IRA, check the account to see how much you're contributing. Give yourself a pat on the back. Isn't it nice to know?
ANSWERS.2:
Kudos to you for getting into the habit of saving, even when you don't have a lot to contribute yet. Every little bit helps, so keep saving what you can.

What's next: Challenge yourself to increase the percentage from time to time. Could you go up to 4% next? If it's too much, you can always decrease it. Need help finding extra cash? Try the Bag-Lunch Challenge.
ANSWERS.3:
Kudos on building a strong habit of saving! Every little bit helps, so keep saving what you can.

What's next: Challenge yourself to increase the percentage from time to time. Could you go up to 7% next? You can always back off if it's too much. If you have an employer match, try to take full advantage of it. After all, free money!
ANSWERS.4:
That's great! Every little bit helps, so keep saving.

What's next: Challenge yourself to increase the percentage from time to time. Could you bump it up to 10%? You can always back off if it's too much. If you have an employer match, try to take full advantage of it. After all, free money!
ANSWERS.5:
That's excellent! Future You is going to thank you!

What's next: Keep up the great saving habit. If you have more to save, it may be worth looking at your full financial picture, possibly with a financial advisor, to decide on a course of action that reflects your goals and your values.

EMPLOYERMATCHRETIREMENTCONTRIBUTION.INTRODUCTION:
Are you maximizing your retirement benefit?

Some employers who offer retirement plans will match the dollars you contribute up to a certain point. So if you contribute $10, your employer adds $10 too. It's a win-win: You save, and you get free money. But the flip side is true too: If you don't save, you're saying "no thanks" to that free money.

ANSWERS.0:
Think about it this way: If you dropped a $10 bill, would you keep on walking? How about $100? More? Didn't think so.

What's next: How much you could withhold from your paycheck without noticing? Check out the Negotiator Challenge to cut fixed expenses. Bonus: Depending on the type of plan, it could save on taxes too. Contact your plan administrator to find out how to enroll.
ANSWERS.1:
About half of employees don't have an employer-sponsored retirement plan at all, and others have a plan that doesn't offer matching funds. That doesn't mean you shouldn't save for retirement, though!

What's next: If you don't have one already, consider opening an IRA. Want to jumpstart that account? Try the Side Hustle Challenge for some extra income.
ANSWERS.3:
Now's as good a time as any to find out! After all, who doesn't like free money? It would be nice to know if you're leaving cash on the table-and it might give you some extra incentive to save.

What's next: Call and ask. Your plan's administrator, that is. If you're not sure who to talk to, start with the HR department at work. They can point you in the right direction.
ANSWERS.4:
You have a retirement plan contribution match, and you're using it. But you're not taking full advantage. Consider this: There are very few ways you can invest with an immediate return on investment of as much as 100%.

What's next: Find out how much your employer will match and calculate how much of a difference it would make in your paycheck. Check out the Negotiator Challenge to cut fixed expenses so you'd have more for retirement.
ANSWERS.5:
Go you! Future Self thanks you!

What's next: Keep it up. As your income rises, your contributions (and your employer's match) will as well. Retirement's looking pretty nice about now.

SAVINGSFORFUTUREPURCHASES.INTRODUCTION:
Save for the good stuff

Saving ahead for future purchases helps you stay out of debt. When you save for a car, house, dream vacation or child's education, you earn interest instead of paying interest. But that's not all. Research has found that people who prepay for something before they get it enjoy it more.

ANSWERS.0:
You're certainly not alone. Americans aren't great savers. But that doesn't mean you should settle for average. The good news: You know exactly where to start.

What's next: If you don't have one already, open a savings account for future purchases. The Thrivent Federal Credit Union has options for you. Check them out here.
ANSWERS.2:
Good to hear you're saving! If you don't have a separate account set up for this, that's a good place to start. Then you'll know how much you have, and you won't be tempted to spend it just because it's in your checking account.

What's next: Check out your bank's website or talk to a banker about the best way to compartmentalize your savings. Earmark savings for an emergency separately from savings for future planned expenses, like a car or a trip.
ANSWERS.3:
That's a start! You're building a valuable habit of saving that will serve you well in your future. After all, every dollar you don't have to borrow is worth more than one you do.

What's next: See if you can work your savings rate up to 2% of your gross income. Do the math to see what that dollar amount would be. Then set up an automatic deduction in that amount. If it's too much, you can always lower it.
ANSWERS.4:
It may not seem like a lot, but you're building a valuable habit of saving that will serve you well in your future. After all, every dollar you don't have to borrow is worth more than one you do.

What's next: See if you can work your savings rate up to 5% of your gross income. Challenge yourself to choose one expense each month that you can decide not to spend and instead put into your savings.
ANSWERS.5:
You're saving 5% of your pretax income for future purchases. Super saver! Not only are you socking away a solid nest egg, you're building a valuable habit of saving that will serve you well in your future.

What's next: Need some extra incentive to maintain your strong saving habit? Take a picture of the goal you're saving for (a house, a car, college) and make it your screen saver or put it in your wallet to remind you every day.

HAVEAUTOMATICSAVINGSETUP.INTRODUCTION:
Is your savings automatic?

Automating your savings is one of the best tricks of the trade. Making your savings (or giving) automatic simply helps you do what you want to do. We all have good intentions-and busy lives. So set it, forget it, and you'll never regret it.

ANSWERS.0:
You do not have automatic savings set up. What are you waiting for? Setting up automatic savings is like paying yourself first. It's too easy to spend money if it's left in your checking account.

What's next: If you don't already have an account that's separate from your checking account, get one. The Thrivent Federal Credit Union has options for you. Check them out here.
ANSWERS.1:
Look at your checking account to see if there are transfers being made to a savings account. If not, make it happen! Setting up automatic savings is like paying yourself first. Can't argue with that.

What's next: If you don't already have an account that's separate from your checking account, get one. The Thrivent Federal Credit Union has options for you. Check them out here.
ANSWERS.5:
You know that making saving a habit gives you control over your money story, and you've put it on autopilot. After all, it's easy to spend money that's left sitting in your checking account, so why tempt yourself?

What's next: Keep up those contributions and periodically challenge yourself to contribute more. Consider if you could use this same strategy to automate a giving habit that's in line with your values.

FWADIMEMOTIONAL.NAME: Emotional
FWADIMEMOTIONAL.DESCRIPTION:
Let's face it. Many of us ‚Äúfeel‚Äù money more than we ‚Äúthink‚Äù money. We have emotional reactions over our financial decisions every day, whether it's worry over bills, frustration with a spouse's spending, temporary excitement from an impulse purchase, or regret after seeing a credit card statement.

There's no dollar amount that will make you immune from emotions when it comes to money. But there are strategies you can take to manage your emotions-and to help you find fulfillment and value no matter the size of your bills or your paycheck.

The best part? You're in exactly the right place to learn how.

FWASUBDIMFINANCIALANXIETY.NAME: Financial Anxiety
FWASUBDIMFINANCIALANXIETY.DESCRIPTION: How much is money stressing you out?

SCORE_1.FEEDBACK:
It sounds like you are feeling buried under financial stress, and it's seeping into all of your life from your physical health to your relationships, thoughts and emotions. This isn't something to ignore: Some researchers believe financial stress can mirror the experience of someone with post-traumatic stress disorder. Consider this your wake-up call to find the resources you need to get out from under this financial and emotional burden.

Tackle your stress first. The rest will be more manageable.

It doesn't take a dime to start chipping away at stress. Three ways to do it:
  1. Five deep breaths, right now: in through your nose, out through your mouth.
  2. Download a meditation, devotion, or prayer app and follow along.
  3. Talk to a supportive friend. And be willing to listen to them in return.

SCORE_2.FEEDBACK:
It sounds like financial stress is taking a toll on you, physically and emotionally. And the impact isn't limited to your bank account. It can affect your health and your relationships too. You may not be able to fix your financial problems overnight, but you can take steps to target your stress right now.

Tackle your stress first. The rest will be more manageable.

It doesn't take a dime to start chipping away at stress. Three ways to do it:
  1. Five deep breaths, right now: in through your nose, out through your mouth.
  2. Download a meditation, devotion, or prayer app and follow along.
  3. Talk to a supportive friend. And be willing to listen to them in return.

SCORE_3.FEEDBACK:
Some months you feel trapped by worry about making ends meet, and other times it's at least manageable. Still, finances are affecting your life. And not in a good way. No question, feeling that you're not able to live a financially secure life is one of the most stressful things you can experience. But there are steps you can take to minimize the stress, even if you can't solve all your financial problems right away.

Tackle your stress first. The rest will be more manageable.

It doesn't take a dime to start chipping away at stress. Three ways to do it:
  1. Five deep breaths, right now: in through your nose, out through your mouth.
  2. Download a meditation, devotion, or prayer app and follow along.
  3. Talk to a supportive friend. And be willing to listen to them in return.

SCORE_4.FEEDBACK:
There are plenty of things to stress about in life. While money sometimes lands on your list of worries, it's not the norm. Nice! Finding a way to spend less than you earn each month certainly helps to keep stress at bay, but there's something else that makes a difference too: your attitude. Specifically, not getting too preoccupied with having more, more, more and instead focusing on the things that give your life meaning.

Write down your long-term financial goals.

Taking into account the reality of your current financial picture, where do you hope to be in six months? Ten years? Maybe you hope to own a home in a particular place? Wipe out your credit card debt? Buy a car with cash?

Don't forget to also consider the value of your time and how you want to spend that. A job that allows you to be home for dinner every night, or even to pick your kids up from school, is worth a lot. Some experts have found that when you spend money on things that ‚Äúbuy‚Äù you more time with people you love-and on things that matter most to you-it can actually make you happier.

Refer to your goals often as you consider the steps you can take today to make them a reality.

Take a look at the Take Back Your Time Challenge for more ideas.

SCORE_5.FEEDBACK:
There are plenty of things to stress about in life. Lucky for you, money isn't high on your list. There are two factors that typically help people find this sweet spot: The first is living within your means, no matter what your income is. The second? An understanding that more is not always better-and true satisfaction comes from a life filled with meaning, purpose and gratitude.

Take inventory. Not of stuff, but of how you spend your time.

Many of us are good at keeping records of money and things. But what about time? Reviewing how you spend it can make a big difference in your sense of purpose and meaning.

Some experts have found that when you spend money on things that ‚Äúbuy‚Äù you more time with people you love-and on things that matter most to you-it can actually make you happier.

Challenge yourself to go a step beyond the awesome place of not being stressed to actually demonstrating security by being generous with others. Consider if there are ways you could reach out to support others who are experiencing anxiety, perhaps by leading a small group in your church.

Take a look at the Take Back Your Time Challenge for more ideas.

FWASUBDIMDISSATISFACTIONLIFEANDFINANCES.NAME: Dissatisfaction
FWASUBDIMDISSATISFACTIONLIFEANDFINANCES.DESCRIPTION: Are financial struggles getting you down?

SCORE_1.FEEDBACK:
Your answers suggest that you feel very dissatisfied with what you have in terms of material wealth. And looking around, it's easy to see how you could feel that way. We're all bombarded by messages that we should have more, more, more!

But the unfortunate result is a country where the average American has $15,000 in credit card debt. Instead of focusing on what you don't have, consider giving a good look at what you do have.

Don't let gratitude slip by. Write it down.

Keep a gratitude journal, a notebook, or even a page on your phone or computer where you can jot down the things in your life that you're grateful for. It can help you to find happiness and fulfillment wherever you are in your financial journey. Write down at least one thing you're thankful for every day this week.

Want more ideas? Take a look at the No Turkey Needed Challenge.

Review your spending from the last month.

With online bank statements, it's easy to let each swipe of a credit card be out of sight and out of mind. Right now, give your spending a checkup. It's not just about the amount you spend, but how you spend your money. What expenses reflect the values you seek, and which ones, well, don't?

Remind yourself that what you're experiencing is common, and it's not something to be ashamed of. You might find comfort in seeking help from a counselor or a pastor.

SCORE_2.FEEDBACK:
It's clear that you're seeking more from life both in your material possessions and even the time you have to spend as you wish. Hopes and dreams are part of being human. When you can't buy what you want and do what you want, it can feel like the game is rigged.

Try to remember that life has a way of unfolding along different paths, and if you're willing to adjust, you can find satisfaction in what really matters: friends, family and those who surround you.

Don't let gratitude slip by. Write it down.

Keep a gratitude journal, a notebook, or even a page on your phone or computer where you can jot down the things in your life that you're grateful for. It can help you to find happiness and fulfillment wherever you are in your financial journey. Write down at least one thing you're thankful for every day this week.

Want more ideas? Take a look at the No Turkey Needed Challenge.

Put your money where you can see it.

If you've ever tamed ‚Äúto-do‚Äù stress by making a list, you know how helpful it can be to put things down on paper. A money budget can work the same way: Seeing your cash flow in black and white can help you to gain an important sense of control over your financial situation.

SCORE_3.FEEDBACK:
Sure, you're grateful for what you have. But at times you still feel something is lacking, whether it's stuff or even just time. You want to do something, but what? Finding a balance between pursuing what you want and enjoying what you have is a challenge. Beware of the notion that more is better. After all, not all ‚Äústuff‚Äù adds value to our lives.

Don't let gratitude slip by. Write it down.

Keep a gratitude journal, notebook, or even a page on your phone or computer where you can jot down the things in your life that you're grateful for. It can help you find happiness and fulfillment wherever you are in your financial journey. Write down at least one thing you're thankful for every day this week.

SCORE_4.FEEDBACK:
You're feeling pretty good when it comes to your financial health and how you spend your time. You appreciate what you have, and you're building a foundation for the future. Nice work! Still, sometimes that little voice in your ear questions whether you're doing enough. Beware of the trap of always seeking more. A better investment may be in the relationships that bring you joy and emotional security.

Think about who supports you. Say thank you.

Does your partner make you lunch every day? Did a colleague help you earn a promotion? Does a friend always answer your call, no matter what else is going on? Tell them just how grateful you are that they're in your life. Better yet, brainstorm something you can do for them in return.

SCORE_5.FEEDBACK:
Thanks to your mature approach to your financial life, you're able to enjoy the fruits of your labor without worry or stress. It takes time and attention to build such a strong foundation of security and stability. Congratulations on a job well done.

While you're at it, don't forget to feel gratitude for the riches of your life. Not just the financial ones, but also the relationships and simple pleasures that enrich your life.

Think about who supports you. Say thank you.

Does your partner make you lunch every day? Did a colleague help you earn a promotion? Does a friend always answer your call, no matter what else is going on? Tell them just how grateful you are that they're in your life. Better yet, brainstorm something you can do for them in return.

FWADIMSPIRITUAL.NAME: Spiritual
FWADIMSPIRITUAL.DESCRIPTION: The Spiritual Dimension of finances taps into how our relationship with money reflects our most deeply-held beliefs and values. It is about meaning and purpose, our relationship and connection to others and to our resources. It's about the ‚Äúbigger story.‚Äù Does your faith play a role? How central is money to your existence, and how much do you need to feel content? How much gratitude do you feel for the blessings in your life?

FWASUBDIMMONEYORIENTED.NAME: Money Oriented
FWASUBDIMMONEYORIENTED.DESCRIPTION: How important of a tool is money to you?

SCORE_1.FEEDBACK:
Your answers suggest that your internal sense of self depends greatly on what you buy. You seem to fill life with stuff and judge how you feel about yourself based on how you look to others. But that's not your heart-how do you truly want to live?

The Bible tells us that earthly treasures ultimately fade. Everlasting treasures include the joy and contentment that comes from our relationship with God and others. Chances are you know this. But we live in a world and a society that doesn't always reflect this.

Marketers have been trying to convince us from birth that what we need is for sale. Everywhere we turn on social media, people are posting their best selves‚Äìbuilding the illusion of perfection. But you know that's not the whole story. None of our lives are that picture perfect!

The problem is that there's always more to want, setting you up for overspending and debt. Fortunately, it's not too late to challenge those messages and start focusing on who you are, not what you have.

Do this: Stop, think…and redirect your spending.

Next time you're about to make a purchase, freeze. Take the money you were going to spend and do one of these things instead:
  1. Use it to create an experience or to spend time with someone you love and care about.
  2. Find a worthy cause or someone in need and hand-deliver a donation.
  3. Put it in savings and do one of the above without spending any money. Spend time with a friend or volunteer for a cause.
Your goal is to find a new way to spend—or not spend—that might be more meaningful and taps into your values.

SCORE_2.FEEDBACK:
Shopping is fun for most people. But when it goes from one of life's little pleasures to an anchor in your life, it can become problematic. It sounds like you may be caught in this zone. Remember, the Bible tells us that earthly treasures ultimately fade, while true joy and contentment comes from our relationship with God and others.

You probably know it's true: Buying things can make you feel good in the moment, but it doesn't last. Accumulating things and comparing what you have to others is more likely to leave you feeling empty. Remember that your value isn't determined by what you have.

Do this: Go on an impulse-spending freeze.

Make a pact not to act on any unplanned purchases for one week. Before you go shopping (or even out the door), make a list of what you intend to buy and stick to it. If you see other things you need or could use while out, don't get them on the spot. If they make the list for next time you're out, they are fair game.

Spending is part of life. The idea is to add a check on impulse buying or spending for the ‚Äúwrong‚Äù reasons. With practice and thoughtfulness, you can learn to better direct your time and money toward what is most meaningful for you.

SCORE_3.FEEDBACK:
Like many people, you're caught in a battle between a simpler life and too much focus on building up treasures here on earth. It's a trap we all fall into-feeling like buying ‚Äústuff‚Äù will satisfy you. Yet the Bible tells us those treasures ultimately fade. True joy and contentment come from our relationship with God, producing good fruit in our relationships with others in turn!

Bring your mind back to this basic truth when you find yourself getting caught up with pressures that are not life-giving: As the Bible says in Matthew 6:21, your heart will be where your treasure is. Invest in things that last and matter.

Work to be purposeful in how you spend. After all, the more material things you seek, the harder it becomes to grow as a person and live up to your values. Remember: You have the ability to choose the way you want to live. What will that look like? A life focused on material things? Or one with true contentment?

Do this: Take a trip down your Memory Lane of spending.

Think of some things you spent money on in the last month or even year. Pull out a credit card statement if you need to. How many of them are still bringing you joy today?

Consider why some purchases were more meaningful than others. Did it buy you free time or quality time with a loved one or friend? Was it an impulse buy of something you didn't need? Did you spend it on someone else as a gift?

Having a good perspective on your spending and on the gratitude for what you already have is an awesome one-two punch toward true contentment.

SCORE_4.FEEDBACK:
You are generally grateful for what you have, and that doesn't just mean things. You get pleasure and a feeling of success from many aspects of life beyond money or possessions. While you might daydream about little luxuries or the latest tech gadget from time to time, you're well aware that the rush for "more" can be a trap. You've wisely opted for a different path.

Good for you. Keep your eye on the prize and enjoy the wealth that comes from within.

Do this: Practice heart breathing before bed.

Place one hand over your heart, and as you inhale and exhale slowly, think of the things you are grateful for in your life. Take five minutes to breathe and reflect, letting your mind focus on these things.

This simple practice can change stress patterns and benefit your life. The benefits of gratitude, a spiritual principle, are scientifically proven!

SCORE_5.FEEDBACK:
Your sense of well-being isn't tied to money or the things it buys. You understand that while money is a tool that serves a purpose, you own your role in determining that purpose.

That attitude frees you up to enjoy a simpler life—and to find meaning and purpose in entirely different ways. Plus, money goes further when you're not always chasing the latest thing to spend it on.

Do this: Enrich your life without dollars.

A feeling of abundance multiplies when you find ways to be of service to others. Mow your neighbor's grass. Take soup to a sick friend. Invite a friend who is struggling over for a meal.

Don't be afraid to be bold in your generosity. If you wait for people to tell you what they need, you might be waiting a long time. Keep your eyes open and look for the unexpected. Some of those easily-missed opportunities are the most needed!

FWASUBDIMENOUGHNESS.NAME: Enoughness
FWASUBDIMENOUGHNESS.DESCRIPTION: Do you feel like you have enough?

SCORE_1.FEEDBACK:
Money appears to be a constant and overwhelming source of anxiety for you. You associate it with freedom and power. And you may even believe it's the answer to all of your problems. Deep down, though, you probably know it's never that simple. Basing your life around chasing money can leave you feeling helpless. But there's hope!

Make a commitment to yourself to change your relationship with money. Know that while money can be a tool for your life, it isn't the path to real freedom. True freedom and security are spiritual matters-ones that can only come from God.

Many people find professional help in the form of a pastor or counselor. They're experts in helping people experience transformation. And the great news is, you CAN change your relationship with money. You just have to take a step forward to a new way of thinking.

You can do it!

Do this: Start your day with a gratitude list every day for one week.

First thing in the morning, write down five things in your life you are grateful for. Make sure at least half of them are things that can't be bought with money. It's OK to repeat each day. Or if it seems too easy-go for 10. Be specific, and try to think of some things that happened just in the last 24 hours.

Nothing is too small! Have a smooth commute? Enjoy a friendly conversation? If they're things that keep appearing on your list, take note: You may have identified something that will bring you lasting joy.

Want more ideas? Check out the No Turkey Needed Challenge.

SCORE_2.FEEDBACK:
It sounds like money is on your mind much of the time. You might often feel like you need more of it. It's true: Money gives you options. It can feel like it's the answer to the comfort, security, status and freedom that you crave. But it doesn't always bring these things.
The problem: Often the feeling that there's not enough has more to do with your mindset than an actual number of dollars and cents. Without changing your mindset, it's likely that there will never be enough, and constantly seeking it could consume you.

Try to remind yourself that money is a tool, but real lasting contentment comes only from God. We are provided for, even when it feels like we don't have enough. When we accept that, deep within, our relationship with money-and each other-can be transformed.

Do this: Brainstorm free (or cheap) ways to find joy.

Make a list of five activities that bring you joy and fulfillment and that don't require a lot of money. Then get your creative juices flowing: Draw a picture beside each one showing how it makes you feel

Now go do one of them.

Or: Ask why?

If your motto is ‚ÄúMoney can't buy happiness, but it can buy a vacation. And that's the same thing,‚Äù try this: Think back to the last few purchases you made (not including your basic required needs) and try to get to the root of why you made them. Look for patterns. Were there a lot of impulse buys? Were more of them for you, or for someone else? Were they something truly important, or were you trying to please someone?

These are tough but honest questions that will help you think critically about the role money plays in your life. It may take a little courage, but you've got this!

Want more ideas? Check out the No Turkey Needed Challenge.

SCORE_3.FEEDBACK:
You're grateful for what you have, but sometimes you still feel that your life would be better if you had more money. You know that money can't buy happiness. But it weighs on you more than you'd like it to at times.

Fortunately, you get to own your story and the choices you make. You can decide each day to be grateful for what you have, to spend quality time with those you love and to work on growing into the person God created you to be.

Choose to dwell on the blessings in your life instead of what you don't have. Train your mind in gratitude and contentment, you will find your life to be like the "well-watered garden" (Isaiah 58:11), which thrives even when conditions are seemingly bad.

Do this: Count your blessings. Out loud.

Try this new a.m. habit: When your alarm goes off, before your feet touch the floor, thank the Lord for something in your life‚Äì big or small. Even in hard times, there's always something to be thankful for.

SCORE_4.FEEDBACK:
You live with a sense of abundance, which is something to be thankful for. By focusing on what you have instead of what you don't have, you are empowered to live in a world of possibility instead of one of limitations.

Still, you live in a world where the urge to pursue "more" is all around you. Remind yourself that anyone can experience financial uncertainty, but your life isn't determined by the money in your bank account.

Do this: Look before you leap.

When the urge to pursue "more" arises (perhaps a new car or a bigger home) take the time to weigh it against other priorities. What will it cost you in terms of time and energy, as well as money? What impact will it have on your relationships? Worth it?

You don't need to feel shame for your competing desires. Bring it to God in prayer for wisdom about what to do and the confidence and courage to follow through.

SCORE_5.FEEDBACK:
The race for more, more, more may always be on, but you've opted out. Good for you! You know that money is a resource, not a cure-all. Freedom, sense of security, fulfillment: Those things can't be bought.

Knowing who you are-and whose you are-fills you with a sense of freedom, security and abundance, which sets a new bottom line. Sure, money is a needed resource. But it remains at its proper place in your life, not at the center.

Being content with what you have is a great gift. Enjoy it. Spread it.

Do this: Full heart? Make room at your table and lead the change.

We think the world needs people like you to change the culture when it comes to money, resources and relationships. Too many people are walking around feeling like they don't have enough or aren't enough.

How can you help a neighbor experience a sense of abundance, no matter their circumstances? Share the riches of your gratitude with someone who could use the gift of hospitality. That could mean having them over for dinner or inviting them on an outing to the park, for coffee or for a walk.

FWASUBDIMGRATITUDE.NAME: Gratitude
FWASUBDIMGRATITUDE.DESCRIPTION: Do you take time for gratitude?

SCORE_1.FEEDBACK:
From what you told us, gratitude isn't high on your list of priorities. Maybe you work hard in your life and feel entitled to a certain lifestyle. But is this making you happy? On the other hand, perhaps things are pretty tough for you right now. You might feel like there isn't much to be grateful for in life.

Much of the New Testament includes letters from the apostle Paul, who lived through some pretty tough circumstances. Some of those letters were written while he was imprisoned. Yet when you read them, you can see Paul's priorities. Regardless of his circumstances, he was able to tap into God's goodness and gush with gratitude.

Whether it comes naturally or not, gratitude is a habit that makes life better. Go on a hunt to find just a little bit of gratitude today. Then look for a little more tomorrow.

Do this: Change your point of view.

What if instead of focusing on all you deserve or what you don't have in life, you tried to look around and soak up the (free) pleasures all around you? The warmth of the sun. A smile from a stranger. True meaning comes from the way you spend your time, what you choose to see (and overlook), and what you value. So go on a hunt to count all of the things you're grateful for today. Then do it again tomorrow!

Want more ideas? Check out the No Turkey Needed Challenge.

SCORE_2.FEEDBACK:
From what you've told us, it sounds like you feel you've gotten a bit of a raw deal. Perhaps you work hard for everything you have and feel a sense of pride in your work. But that's not the same as gratitude. After all, gratitude doesn't pay the bills. Or maybe you're facing a pretty tough time and don't feel like there's much to be grateful for at all.

Much of the New Testament includes letters from the apostle Paul, who lived through some pretty tough circumstances. Some of those letters were written while he was imprisoned. Yet when you read them you can see Paul's priorities. Regardless of his circumstances, he was able to tap into God's goodness and be filled with gratitude.

Whether it comes naturally or not, gratitude is a habit that makes life better. Go on a hunt to find just a little bit of gratitude today. Then look for a little more tomorrow.

Do this: Text a "thank you" to someone who helped you get where you are.

No one succeeds by themselves. Think about someone who helped you or supported you in a meaningful way. It could be something big or small, specific or general. Expressing appreciation for that person's role in your life will absolutely make their day. Notice how it makes you feel too.

Want more ideas? Check out the No Turkey Needed Challenge.

SCORE_3.FEEDBACK:
You told us you feel grateful sometimes, especially when something particularly good happens. But when you're caught up in the hum of your busy life, gratitude isn't at the top of your mind.

Gratitude is a choice that we make every day. In a society where people feel like they'll never have enough, gratitude goes against the grain. Taking note of our blessings can help us to be content with ourselves and our lives.

Do this: Try sticky-note gratitude.

Get some sticky notes. Every morning, write something you're grateful for and stick it on your mirror (or around it). Each day try to write something new. Can you do it for a week? A month? This simple exercise of gratitude can transform any day (yes, even Mondays).

SCORE_4.FEEDBACK:
You feel moments of gratitude daily. Sometimes you even pause to soak it all in. You recognize that gratitude makes you feel more content, and you try to embrace it.

Still, while you're grateful for the many good things in your life, you can't help but wish you had more time and energy to enjoy them. That doesn't have to hold you back. There are small ways to weave more gratitude into what you do. You just have to look for them.

Do this: Find pleasure in a painful chore.

Find pleasure in taking a step toward growth—though it may feel painful. Just as you may celebrate the burn of your muscles getting stronger when you work out, be intentional about not only bearing with a task you would normally find painful, but even deciding to smile while doing it.

SCORE_5.FEEDBACK:
You are deeply grateful for the small and big things in life: health, family, a cozy bed to tuck into at night. It may be that hard times pushed you toward a more grateful approach to life. Or you simply recognize that gratitude brings you joy. However you got here, embrace it.

Do this: Celebrate your abundance by giving to those with less.

Love the fellowship of a family dinner? Invite someone who often dines alone to join you. Find joy in the beauty of nature? Invite someone to join you on a hike. Sharing life's simple pleasures can be contagious. And by sharing, you are literally fulfilling the great commandment to love God and love others as you love yourself.

FWASUBDIMSIMPLYCONTENT.NAME: Simply Content
FWASUBDIMSIMPLYCONTENT.DESCRIPTION: Can you be happy with a simple life?

SCORE_1.FEEDBACK:
You've got your sights set on the luxuries in life. Some may think it's extravagant, but you feel you deserve the best, and you're willing to do what it takes to get it.

Your drive is impressive. But what if it's getting in the way of enjoying the journey? You might find it helpful to ask yourself, "What's driving me?" Consider the desires of your heart. Is ‚Äúmore‚Äù really the means for getting there?

It might be time to stop and smell those roses—and reflect that the scent of just one could be equally as satisfying as a whole dozen.

Do this: Take a step to simplify.

It might be hard to remember (or imagine) being content when you are just meeting your basic needs. Try to streamline just one area of your day today. Yes, less—not more—of something. Use extra time for a relationship, reflection or even relaxation. See how it feels to simplify a little.

SCORE_2.FEEDBACK:
You like the finer things in life, and you make no excuses about it. Sure, you can make do with cutting back once in a while. But you'd rather not make a habit of it. Truth is, you don't really get why anyone would choose to live with less.

Your drive to succeed is impressive. But consider if there are things you could enjoy in life that don't require focus and drive-or even ownership. For example, the beauty of nature is all around you, and it doesn't cost a thing.

Meditate and maybe even memorize this passage from the Bible: "Consider how the wild flowers grow. They do not labor or spin. Yet I tell you, not even Solomon in all his splendor was dressed like one of these." (Luke 12:27)

Do this: Take a step to simplify.

It might be hard to remember (or imagine) being content when you're just meeting your basic needs. Try to streamline just one area of your day today. Yes, less-not more-of something. Use that extra time for a relationship, reflection or even relaxation. See how it feels to simplify a little.

Can you do this two days in a row? Three? Make it a challenge and see if simplifying is satisfying.

SCORE_3.FEEDBACK:
Sure, you enjoy the finer things in life. But you keep it in perspective. You like what you like. But you know that without family and friends, material things would lose their appeal. It seems like you've found the balance of a simple life peppered with occasional well-chosen indulgences.

Consider: Could you be even more satisfied with a greater emphasis on family and simplicity? Regularly reevaluating your habits can help you make sure you're prioritizing time to what is really life giving.

Do this: Dig deep for gratitude.

It might be hard to remember (or imagine) being content when you are just meeting your basic needs. Try to streamline just one area of your day today. Yes, less-not more-of something. Use extra time for a relationship, reflection or even relaxation. See how it feels to simplify a little.

Could you do this each day for a week? See if simpler living could help you make more time for family or friends. The book you could never get to, or that workout you always wanted to try, might seem much more doable. Who knew less could mean more?

SCORE_4.FEEDBACK:
Your life is built around the essentials-including family and friends. As long as your basic needs are taken care of, you don't feel a strong drive to have more. That doesn't mean you don't appreciate fine things. But they're not central to your satisfaction in life.

Many other people spend their lives reaching for more material things, so do what you can to help them see that less really is more. Remember that everyone's journey (even yours) is a work in progress. Keep exploring where you find the most joy and cut out the things that don't leave you fulfilled.

Do this: Liberate extra stuff in your life.

Appreciating simplicity in a world that does the opposite is a work in progress. Even with the best of intentions, it's easy to succumb to "stuff creep." Pick a drawer or a closet and go through it. Duplicate spatulas? Shirts you haven't worn in a year? Say "thanks" for having more than enough. Then donate the extras—that good flannel shirt is going to make someone else pretty happy.

Challenge yourself to see where else you could simplify. Could you make it a seasonal habit? Put it on the calendar and start seeing less become more.

SCORE_5.FEEDBACK:
Your life is built around the simple things: family, friends, simplicity and gratitude. And you wouldn't have it any other way.

It's not easy in this world. We're surrounded by steady messages telling us we need to do more and have more. But you are confident in your path. Enjoy it—and consider that your contentment serves as a beacon to others looking for meaning who can benefit from what you've learned.

Do this: Liberate extra stuff in your life.

Appreciating simplicity in a world that wants more is a work in progress. Anyone can succumb to ‚Äústuff creep.‚Äù Battle it by choosing a drawer or a closet and going through it. Duplicate spatulas? Shirts you haven't worn in a year? Say ‚Äúthanks‚Äù for having more than enough. Then donate the extras—that good flannel shirt is going to make someone else pretty happy.

Challenge yourself to see where else you could simplify. Could you make it a seasonal habit? Put it on the calendar and start seeing less become more.

SCORE_1.FEEDBACK:
You've decided that for you, faith and finances are best kept separate. It's possible that faith doesn't play much of a role in your life at all. One thing is certain: From what you told us, the influence of God's biblical teaching doesn't really have an impact on your financial decisions.

If you're a Christian but don't connect your faith and finances, keep in mind that the Bible has an awful lot to say about money. It can be helpful to bring God's plan into your whole life-including your wallet. Especially when it comes to seeking wisdom about financial decisions.

Whatever your beliefs, let your values be your guide-in all aspects of life. Including your money.

Do this: Have a conversation about finances with a faith-filled friend.

Don't be afraid to ask tough questions. How does faith play into their financial decisions? Does Biblical teaching influence their priorities? If they're part of a church, do they agree with everything the church leaders do? What do they do when they disagree?

Then, reflect on what your friend said. Could you let faith or values be more of a guide? Look for ways to let these influences into your financial life. You might be surprised at what you find.

So take note: Working diligently to keep your financial life aligned with your values could be the key to experiencing more contentment in your life!

Do this: Try to connect the dots between your values and your finances. Do they match up?

Take out a piece of paper and list at least five values you feel are important in your life and in the world. On the other side of the paper, list five financial choices you've made in the last year. How many match up? What might you change to better sync your spending with your values?

Can you find a Bible verse or inspirational quote that captures or speaks to the specific value you've identified? Jot it down and post it somewhere you'll see it, to continue to support how your faith influences your finances.

SCORE_5.FEEDBACK:
Your faith and your finances go hand in hand. That is, the values that underlie your faith are the same that guide your finances. That doesn't mean it's always easy, but anchoring your finances to your faith helps you live a life that's consistent with your deepest convictions.

Appreciate the assurance you get from having a moral and ethical roadmap to follow with your finances and continue to explore how Biblical teaching around generosity, justice and gratitude can be reflected in your daily financial decisions.

Do this: Thank your teachers… and pay it forward.

You didn't learn to combine your faith and finances all on your own. Who modeled these truths in your life? Was it a parent, friend, teacher or pastor? Write down a list of names and reflect on how each of these individuals influenced your life.

You may even want to send some of them a note or text expressing thanks for how they've influenced you.

Now here's a challenge: How can you pay it forward and help others align their faith and their finances to create healthier relationships with money and each other?

FWADIMBEHAVIORAL.NAME: Behavioral
FWADIMBEHAVIORAL.DESCRIPTION:
The Behavioral Dimension of your financial wellness has everything to do with action, from the habits you have now to the challenges you'll overcome in the future, in money management and beyond.

Do you chase down goals tirelessly, or do you flit from one idea to another, rarely sticking with any one plan for long? Do you make decisions easily, or do you get stuck in a cycle of FOMO? Do you feel like your life is happening to you, or do you have the power to make your own choices and move in the direction you want to go?

All of these questions affect your behavior when it comes to managing your finances. Read on to find out more.

FWASUBDIMGOALBEHAVIORAL.NAME: Goal Behavior
FWASUBDIMGOALBEHAVIORAL.DESCRIPTION: Are you a goal setter or a goal getter?

SCORE_1.FEEDBACK:
Being a free spirit can have its upsides. After all, couch surfing isn't a bad way to save on rent. And the ability to roll with life's punches can be helpful. But better to save your resiliency for things you truly can't control, instead of things you can, like bounced checks or missed payments. After all, banks aren't willing to "just relax" or "roll with it."

The good news: You don't have to become an accountant or even wear a button-up to manage your finances. Spend some time thinking about what your good life looks like. Break it down into simple steps you can take toward that goal, then celebrate each one!

One simple step: Just do something.

We know, we know. It's not that simple right? Well let's make it simple.
  1. Pick one thing you WISH you could do.
  2. Answer this: WHY do you wish you could do that? Be specific.
  3. How would it FEEL to accomplish that? Picture it.
  4. Now, what's the simplest thing you could do to even BEGIN to work toward that goal? Take a moment and try to come up with that first step.
  5. Can you make it easier still? If your small step was to call your credit card company, even easier might be to look up the phone number. You can do this!


Want more help setting goals? Check out our Personal Goal Setting.

SCORE_2.FEEDBACK:
Set a goal once, but forgot where you set it? You see the value of setting goals for your life, but reaching them is another story. You often have trouble making it happen.

Setting and meeting financial goals, like running up a household budget, doesn't require a degree in (or even an affinity for) accounting. Start with small steps, right where you are. Luckily, you're in the exact right place to get started.

One simple step: Just do something.

We know, we know. It's not that simple right? Well let's make it simple.
  1. Pick one thing you WISH you could do.
  2. Answer this: WHY do you wish you could do that? Be specific.
  3. How would it FEEL to accomplish that? Picture it.
  4. Now, what's the simplest thing you could do to even BEGIN to work toward that goal? Take a moment and try to come up with that first step.
  5. Can you make it easier still? If your small step was to call your credit card company, even easier might be to look up the phone number. You can do this!


Want more help setting goals? Check out our Personal Goal Setting.

SCORE_3.FEEDBACK:
You use goals when times are tough to keep yourself on track, but they're usually short-lived. Day-to-day, you live by more of an "if it ain't broke, don't fix it" mantra. After all, difficult goals can create their own stress.

If you're happy where you are, that's a fine approach to take. But if you find yourself wanting to change a circumstance in your life, don't be afraid to use goal setting to get there. Remember: The hardest part is committing and taking the first step.

Try this: Recruit social support for your next financial goal.

Need a little push to keep you honest? Tell a few friends about a financial goal, for example: paying down your credit card debt in the next six months. Ask them to check up on you to keep you accountable. Not shy? Broadcast it to your entire social network and let the cheers roll in.

SCORE_4.FEEDBACK:
You know just how useful a tool goal setting is. You live it. After all, when you set your mind to something, you make it happen. Especially when there is personal reputation at stake.

Still your drive isn't without downsides. You have to check yourself to make sure you're not brushing aside people in pursuit of your goals. Remember, meeting goals is not as satisfying without people we love to share in the victories.

Next Step: Define your "good life"

It's not a trick question. The answer is different for everybody. Maybe you dream of travel. Maybe it's a house with enough room to welcome guests. Maybe it's a job that you're passionate about. Get real about what success would mean for you-and take notes! Consider sharing your goal with a loved one. If you want to have some real fun, find pictures or something that represents your goals to inspire you.

Now one more important step. Think about WHY these goals are important to you? Do they reflect your values and the things in your life that matter most? Visualizing your goal is good. Making your goals meaningful and aligned to your values ‚Ä¶ that's magic!

SCORE_5.FEEDBACK:
There are few things that give you a greater thrill in life than working tirelessly at a difficult goal and ultimately succeeding. Your discipline can be your greatest gift. But at other times, when your laser focus leaves you unwilling to compromise, it can be your greatest struggle.

Organized, planned, logical, rational: These are the things that make our financial system run. And you've mastered them, making organizing your own finances child's play. But don't forget that finances aren't everything. Makes sure to look around and enjoy the present too.

Next step: Define your "good life."

It's not a trick question. The answer is different for everybody. Maybe you dream of travel. Maybe it's a house with enough room to welcome guests. Maybe it's a job that you're passionate about. Get real about what success would mean for you-and take notes! Consider sharing your goal with a loved one. If you want to have some real fun, find pictures or something that represents your goals to inspire you.

Now one more important step. Think about WHY these goals are important to you? Do they reflect your values and the things in your life that matter most? Visualizing your goal is good. Making your goals meaningful and aligned to your values ‚Ä¶ that's where the real power is!

FWASUBDIMSENSEOFEMPOWERMENT.NAME: Sense of Empowerment
FWASUBDIMSENSEOFEMPOWERMENT.DESCRIPTION: Do you feel powerful or powerless in your financial life?

SCORE_1.FEEDBACK:
Most people struggle with either trusting their own judgement or feeling the power to take action based on their judgement in some situations. For you, this seems to interfere with much of your life, leaving you feeling helpless, especially when it comes to finances.

When you feel like your life is controlled by forces out of your control, your financial decision-making process can suffer too. After all, risk is part of the equation. It may be helpful to seek support from a good friend, a pastor or a counselor to help you with this.

A first step: Instead of feeling stuck on an overwhelming goal, find one small step you know you can achieve. No matter how small and insignificant it feels, do it.

Not only will you prove to yourself that you can take control of the situation, successfully completing one small, doable step can help you build the confidence to keep going toward that bigger goal. You can do this!

SCORE_2.FEEDBACK:
You feel that much of your life is outside of your control, and that makes it hard for you to make decisions-especially financial ones. Your inclination is to think things through often several times, before making a decision.

That's not a bad approach, but too little self-confidence can leave you paralyzed with indecision. Remember: Making financial decisions often requires choosing a path with incomplete information.

Try this: Think of the smallest step you could take toward a big financial challenge. Want to get out of debt? A big step would be paying off your credit card bill. (Wouldn't that be nice?) The smallest step? Pay $10 to your card RIGHT NOW.

SCORE_3.FEEDBACK:
