Thoughtful by nature, you tend more toward caution than risk-taking. Still, you don't shy away from making difficult decisions when necessary. And you recognize that there are many aspects of life and finances that are out of your control.

A smart way to build confidence: Focus on boosting your knowledge and understanding of different financial decisions you're faced with. (Hint: You're in a great place to do that right now!)

Try this: Think of a circumstance you didn't feel you had a lot of control over. Brainstorm at least three things you feel you could have done that would have given you a sense of control or confidence. Have some fun with your ideas. Is there any situation you are facing where you can apply this same thinking?

SCORE_4.FEEDBACK:
You seem to have an optimal balance of self-confidence as well as cautious consideration. Kudos! After all, there are a lot of different factors that go into most financial decisions. Embrace that natural confidence when planning your financial life.

Next step: Don't forget that not everyone shares your comfort in calculating risks and making informed decisions. If you share finances with someone else, take the time to communicate and make decisions you're both comfortable with.

SCORE_5.FEEDBACK:
No wallflowers here. You aren't one to shy away from a challenge or to be daunted by a big decision. When it comes to money, that can be both a blessing and a curse. You may feel confident making decisions on your own, but sometimes it can help to take other people's wisdom into account.

Remember, diving in works for many things. But a bit of caution is necessary at times. Keep your determination but look before you leap!

Next step: Since you seem confident in tackling what life brings your way, think about the impact you could have on others. In a relationship? Make sure your partner also feels empowered. Be careful not to make decisions for them. Instead, offer listening and encouragement-and make sure you're reaching those decisions together.

FWADIMCULTURAL.NAME: Cultural
FWADIMCULTURAL.DESCRIPTION:
The Cultural Dimension of your financial life is about influences from your family of origin, your community, and the people around you. Whether you realize it or not, those influences affect how you talk about money (or don't), how likely you are to save (or not), and other factors.

Everyone is influenced by their family and experiences over the course of their lives in fact, you're still being influenced today. As you've gotten older, you've also begun to draw some of your own conclusions about where to invest your time and money. Now you're not only impacted by culture you're shaping the culture around you.

FWASUBDIMGENEROSITYTOOTHERS.NAME: Blessing Others
FWASUBDIMGENEROSITYTOOTHERS.DESCRIPTION: Do you believe blessings bring responsibility?

SCORE_1.FEEDBACK:
While it's likely that you look out for the people you love, you may not often consider taking care of others outside of your circle. Maybe you're trying to save all you can, to protect yourself from any potential crisis. Or maybe you believe that a handout won't help, because responsibility is learned best when you have to make your own way.

Whatever your reason for keeping blessings in your own bank account, remember: Jesus' greatest commandment is that we'd love the Lord our God with all our heart, soul, mind and strength-and also that we'd love our neighbors as ourselves. One way to do that is through generosity.

If you think that being generous only has benefits for someone else, think again. Studies show that generosity is good for the giver too. Think less stress, a stronger sense of purpose in life, and better relationships. Generous people are less depressed, physically healthier and even live longer. Think you might dip a toe in? Start by noticing people who are generous. What are they like?

Do this: Have one conversation with a stranger each day this week.

Chat with someone in line. Introduce yourself to another parent at the playground. Start a conversation with someone at work who you've never really talked to. Ask questions. The simple act of being curious about the lives of others can help you to become more empathetic-a quality that can increase your happiness too.

SCORE_2.FEEDBACK:
While you're willing to care for yourself and the people you love, you don't feel obligated to give beyond your circle. Far too often, it just doesn't seem fair.

Something to think about the next time you're not sure if you should give: Jesus' greatest commandment is that we'd love the Lord our God with all our heart, soul, mind and strength-and also that we'd love our neighbors as ourselves. One way to do that is through generosity.

If you think that being generous only has benefits for someone else, think again. Studies show that generosity is good for the giver too. Think less stress, a stronger sense of purpose in life, and better relationships. Generous people are less depressed, physically healthier and even live longer. Think you might dip a toe in? Could you give a small amount (of time or money) to someone you know?

Do this: Give something unexpected to someone you don't know.

Pack a couple bags of goodies to keep in your car and next time you see a person with a sign, roll down your window and place a simple gift in their hand. You are changing the world and your heart already.

Another challenge: Spend some time thinking and praying for that person. Consider what might have happened in their life that led them to the place they are now. What might you have in common with them?

SCORE_3.FEEDBACK:
You seem to be comfortable being generous at times, especially with your friends and family. But you sometimes feel frustrated when your generosity isn't reciprocated or met with gratitude.

Jesus' greatest commandment is that we'd love the Lord our God with all our heart, soul, mind and strength-and also that we'd love our neighbors as ourselves. One way to do that is by giving. Studies suggest givers benefit too: less stress, a stronger sense of purpose, and better relationships.

Consider that there's a value in your generosity even if you never see its effects. Being generous is more than donating money a few times a year, but rather about a mindset of compassion. Try giving yourself time to fully experience the psychological rewards of generosity.

Do this: Learn about someone's story of need.

This week, find someone who seems to have a need and simply learn a bit more about their story. It could be as simple as going to the web page for a children's crisis nursery or as bold as asking a homeless person how they ended up there.

Could you gather items to serve the specific need of the person or group you learn about? Is there something else you could do to help?

SCORE_4.FEEDBACK:
Giving is a natural part of your life, and you believe everyone should be generous based on what they have. Not only does it feel good, but giving helps take your mind off your own problems and gives you perspective.

As Christians, we're taught about the importance of caring for those in need. The Bible tells us that everything we have is God's, and we are asked to be good stewards of the resources that we're given and to care for others.

Keep up the great work by seeking organizations with which you share common values and goals. Together, you can engage others in acts of generosity.

Do this: Make an anonymous gift to a stranger one time.

Generosity doesn't always have to be tax deductible. And it doesn't have to cost a lot. Sometimes it's just fun to pay it forward randomly. Ideas: Pay for the car behind you in the drive-thru line. Make a private financial contribution to someone at your church who's going through a hard time. Bring your child's teacher a cup of coffee. Feel good? Thought so.

SCORE_5.FEEDBACK:
You enjoy giving of what you have with no expectation of return. Just knowing that even the smallest act of generosity could change someone's life makes it worthwhile. In your perfect world, everyone would give, and everyone's needs would be met.

You probably already know that the Bible tells us that everything we have is God's. We're asked to be good stewards of the resources that we're given and to care for others.

Your generosity is a gift to yourself too. Studies show that generous people have less stress and stronger relationships. It gives you a sense of self-esteem, a sense of connection with the world, and a life filled with purpose and meaning. Enjoy!

Do this: Make an anonymous gift to a stranger one time.

Generosity doesn't always have to be tax deductible. And it doesn't have to cost a lot. Sometimes it's fun to pay it forward randomly. Ideas: Pay for the car behind you in the drive-thru line. Make a private financial contribution to someone at your church who's going through a hard time. Bring your child's teacher a cup of coffee. Feel good? Thought so.

SCORE_1.FEEDBACK:
You probably don't give a lot of your time or treasure to any church or cause. Maybe that's because when you consider the value of giving to organizations, you're troubled by corruption, mismanagement, ineffective idealism or even abuse.

True, there's no such thing as a perfect organization. But consider if these views might be causing you stress and unhappiness. Is it possible you just haven't really been able to see the good that churches or organizations are doing with people's time and money? Have you really looked hard enough?

There's probably an organization out there that needs your support and is a perfect fit for you. Ask questions and seek like-minded people-and keep looking until you find a way to give in good conscience.

Do this: Talk to three friends about how they give-and why.

Ask questions about a charity your friend supports and find out why they do it. If you have criticisms, share them, but be willing to listen too. Did you learn anything new? Another idea: Talk to a church leader about how they use the money they receive.

SCORE_2.FEEDBACK:
Giving isn't a part of your budget, either because you don't believe in it or you don't feel you can afford to. You're open to the idea of supporting charities in small ways, like donating clothes to a thrift shop. But mainly you do your part by paying taxes, following the law, and being friendly to your neighbors.

Wish you could give more? It's likely that you can. Consider carefully how you spend your time and money, and how well it aligns with your ideals. If cynicism toward charity or church is causing you to miss opportunities to do good, think about how that could drive you to action instead.

Do this: Just do it. Sign up for one volunteer activity.

No commitment necessary. Just do it once. Walk dogs at an animal shelter. Help paint the inside of a soup kitchen. Help kids with homework at an after-school program. You pick what suits you. Afterward, take stock of the experience. How did it feel to help others? Did you make a difference for anyone? Would you do it again?

SCORE_3.FEEDBACK:
You show up to church and charity events when it fits your schedule, and you try to do your part financially. At times you may wish you could give more, but you don't feel you have a lot to give. After all, you need to save too.

With the busy lives so many of us lead these days, it can be hard to find the time or resources to do everything that you want to do or feel that you should do. A thought: Many people find that energy begets energy. Could that be true for you?

Do this: Give your lifestyle a checkup. Cut one weak link.

So-called "lifestyle bloat" isn't just about material things, but commitments of time too. Look carefully at your calendar from the last month. Are you spending your time in ways you're proud of-and that support your values? If not, find at least one time-suck you can cut off to make more room for what really matters.

SCORE_4.FEEDBACK:
You enjoy helping your neighbors in need and believe doing so builds a more vibrant community-the kind of place you want to live. And the relationships you build through your charity or church involvement help keep you involved.

Your faith or values may be at the root of your generosity, but step back once in a while to make sure that still holds true. Since your resources are limited, periodically reassess to make sure the places you're giving the most are still in line with your values.

Do this: Stretch outside of your comfort zone of giving.

Look for new ways to become generous in every situation-including how you listen to others. Listening is a powerful act of generosity, especially when you pair it with prayer. Instead of formulating your response in your head as someone is speaking, focus on hearing what they're really saying. Later on, pray that God will meet that person's needs.

Another idea: Try a step toward even more sacrificial giving. That doesn't have to mean giving a little more money than you think you can (although for many that's proven to be highly rewarding to their confidence in God). It can mean serving in a way or place that feels a little less comfortable. It might mean stretching to serve in an area that is not as obvious or easy and where you might grow even more!

SCORE_5.FEEDBACK:
Church and volunteer work form a basic part of your existence. You plan your week around these activities, and they give your life meaning and structure. Even your social life revolves around volunteering. To the people who know you best, you are loved and respected for your generosity.

While it's wonderful to lead such a deeply giving lifestyle, beware of going on autopilot and simply doing things because you always have. Periodically take a step back to make sure you're still investing your resources according to the values you want to support.

Do this: Stretch outside of your comfort zone of giving.

Look for new ways to become generous in every situation-including how you listen to others. Listening is a powerful act of generosity, especially when you pair it with prayer. Instead of formulating your response in your head as someone is speaking, focus on hearing what they're really saying. Later on, pray that God will meet that person's needs.

Try a step toward even more sacrificial giving. That doesn't have to mean giving a little more money than you think you can (although for many that's proven to be highly rewarding to their confidence in God). It can mean serving in a way or place that feels a little less comfortable. It might mean stretching to serve in an area that is not as obvious or easy and where you might grow even more.

SCORE_1.FEEDBACK:
Money feels very personal to you. And you don't like to talk about it. Even with your closest friends. Many people are private about their financial lives. But consider this: There are real benefits to being more open when it comes to talking about money.

For example, if you're a parent, you need to be talking about money with your kids. You play an important role in helping your child develop a healthy relationship with money in the future. If you're struggling with money, talking about it will give the people who care about you a chance to provide support. Even if you're not struggling, sharing a bit of your own story could open up opportunities for you to provide support or wisdom to someone else.

You don't have to give details about your income or debt to share what's on your mind. And you'll likely learn that others in your life have had similar experiences. Money has been called the last taboo topic. Interesting to remember that the early church pooled their money together to take care of the needs of everyone. Money wasn't seen as something to be kept from the community but as a tool to strengthen community. One question to ask yourself: Could talking about money help you engage with your whole heart into your community? There's only one way to find out.

Do this: Test the waters. Have one conversation about money.

Don't worry, you don't have to share your bank account balances. But just like any new topic, the conversation can feel funny the first time you try it. Wade in carefully and see how your friend responds. Try, "I've been really trying to get my retirement savings on track. Have you found any good ways to do it?" Or, "We're trying to spend less on groceries. Where do you shop?" Open the door and see where it goes. It might become your new favorite topic.

SCORE_2.FEEDBACK:
When it comes to money, you prefer to keep it to yourself and deal with it on your own. Sure, you could talk about it. But you don't want to burden your family or friends by bringing it up. Plus, you know you could talk to your loved ones if you really needed the support.

But consider: You may be depriving yourself of guidance that someone else is willing to give. Or worse, you could be holding back the words someone else really needs to hear. Putting aside details like the number on your paycheck, could you talk about ways to save? Or share your experiences with financial stress? Money may have been a taboo topic in the past-but there's no need for it to stay that way. We were created for community; give God a chance to work by speaking up in yours.

Do this: Test the waters. Have one conversation about money.

Don't worry, you don't have to spill it all. But just like any new topic, the conversation can feel funny the first time you try it.

Wade in carefully and see how your friend responds. Try, "I've been really trying to get my retirement savings on track. Have you found any good ways to do it?" Or, "We're trying to spend less on groceries. Where do you shop?" Open the door and see where it goes. It might become your new favorite topic.

SCORE_3.FEEDBACK:
You've struck a nice balance between oversharing and completely avoiding money talk. You occasionally share what's on your mind with those closest to you, but not often. You may not be the first to jump in with support, but you will if needed.

Consider: Would opening up a little more be healthy for you and those around you? After all, we're all in this together. We were created for community; give God a chance to work by speaking up in yours.

Think about what holds you back. Fear of judgment? Embarrassment over your situation? Just not knowing the response you'll get?

Do this: Open up a new line ‚Ä¶ of communication.

Think of someone in your life whom you trust and respect and start a money conversation. You may get great insights, and it will feel good to have a new source of support.

Wade in carefully and see how your friend responds. Try, "I've been trying to get my retirement savings on track. Have you found any good ways to do it?" Or, "We're trying to save on groceries. Where do you shop?"

Here's a twist. Can you think of someone in your life who may be struggling with money and might need a little support? Try using the same conversation starter with them. Hearing you talk openly about money may be just the type of support they need right now!

SCORE_4.FEEDBACK:
You're fortunate to have friends and family who talk openly about finances and who would have your back if needed. Many people feel isolated when they're under financial stress but withdrawing from others only makes matters worse. The good news for you is that you're backed by a strong support system.

Make sure to recognize this precious gift and keep those lines of communication open. It's great to feel comfortable and supported. Check in with others in your life to make sure they feel the same way.

Do this: Start a discussion about faith and finances.

Got an open dialogue? Take advantage of it! Consider gathering some friends to talk about ways that you could be more generous together. Then share how your own faith influences your finances. You may come away with some new perspectives as your friends share too. Like it? Make it monthly.

Don't forget to welcome people who may be struggling a bit with money. Generosity doesn't always have to come in the form of a financial contribution. Having an open and honest dialogue may help them feel less shame and be inspired to move forward!

SCORE_5.FEEDBACK:
You've got the kind of financial support system anyone would envy. Money issues are an open book, and you like it that way. Shame and secrecy (about finances, at least) just don't exist in your circle.

Whether you created this support system or were simply born into it, make sure to nurture these relationships. And be sensitive to the fact that everyone may not feel as comfortable as you do.

¬†Do this: Start a discussion about faith and finances.

Got an open dialogue? Take advantage of it! Consider gathering some friends to talk about ways that you could be more generous together. Then share how your own faith influences your finances. You may come away with some new perspectives as your friends share too. Like it? Make it monthly.

Don't forget to think of people who may be struggling a bit with money. Having an open and honest dialogue may help them feel less shame and be inspired to move forward!

FWADIMRELATIONSHIP.NAME: Relationship
FWADIMRELATIONSHIP.DESCRIPTION:
Taking care of finances can be tough for everyone. And when there are two people involved, it can be doubly hard. No question about it, savers can fall for spenders and do battle over every bill. And spenders can fall for spenders and spend with abandon.

The truth is there's no magic combo of money styles that best equips you for relationship happiness. The real recipe? A strong bond that supports both your differences and similarities-and lets you tackle challenges as a team.

Want more insight like this? The Love & Money Relationship Satisfaction Assessment takes less than five minutes to complete and will give you even deeper insights and recommendations to guide you as you continue strengthening your relationship.

FWASUBDIMRELATIONSHIP.NAME: Relationship
FWASUBDIMRELATIONSHIP.DESCRIPTION: Are you satisfied with your Love & Money Relationship?

SCORE_1.FEEDBACK:
From what you've told us, you and your significant other have some basic differences in your financial goals and values. Trust us: This is far from uncommon. But when it comes to money and relationships, often it isn't the money problem that's the problem: It's how you each respond. Blame, shame and distrust can make things worse.

Try this: Find common ground to build on.

Don't ignore your differences, but work to respect them. Learn how to work together to make a decision you feel good about with the Decision Challenge.

Try this: Find common ground to build on.

Another exercise that can help you move beyond the differences is to remember what you have in common. Plan something fun (like a date night!) and come up with as many things that you are aligned on as possible. Nothing is too small. Have some fun with it!

Do you both like a certain food, traveling or seeing the look on the kids' faces when they get a gift? The only rule for this night is NO digging into differences. Try it and see how it feels. We think you'll like it and want to do more of it.Still stuck? It's possible that frustration and a lack of feeling valued in money matters has you at an impasse. And for many, the best way to get unstuck will be to bring in a neutral third party like a pastor or counselor.

SCORE_2.FEEDBACK:
We're hearing that you and your significant other think differently about money. There are still many times in your relationship when you do connect, but the money differences can feel divisive.

And while money differences can cut straight to the heart, the remedies are the exact same skills that will serve you well in all aspects of your relationship: valuing one another, communication, honesty and respect. Work tirelessly at those, and your relationship and your financial skills will benefit.

Do this: Have a room-temperature money talk.

In other words: Nobody gets heated (or cold). One thing that will truly help your Love & Money relationship is to build understanding and value for one another. Pick a time together when you're both well-fed, well-rested and generally feeling relaxed. We know this is hard for many people, so here are some steps that will help.

  1. Start on a positive note. Express gratitude. Want to transform a conversation? Take one minute each to come up with as many positive things as you can about each other. Think of things your significant other did today-or recently. Or come up with qualities that you appreciate about them. Now share AT LEAST three ‚Ä¶ but don't limit yourself!

  2. Take turns with a question and (really) listen. Rather than fall into any bad patterns, try this: Each of you gets three minutes to respond, uninterrupted. The listening partner must listen the entire time and then simply say "thanks for sharing." Then they take a turn answering the question (not responding to the first person's answer).
      Question 1: If you all of a sudden got $5,000 that you HAD to spend right away, what would you spend it on?
      Question 2: What is one good money value or habit you got from your family growing up? What is one bad value or habit you think got passed down?

  3. If you feel yourself getting worked up, call a timeout, take a deep breath and think back on all the things you came up with in step 1 that you're grateful for. You can do it!


Or try this: Find common ground to build on.

Don't ignore your differences, but work to respect them. Learn how to work together to make a decision you feel good about with the Decision Challenge.

SCORE_3.FEEDBACK:
You and your significant other share many of the same beliefs and values regarding finances. But sometimes, handling finances together can land you in a big fight.While it's never fun to fight, a major asset for the two of you is the many times when you do communicate well and support each other. Work to foster those habits and apply them in times of disagreement. Remember: It takes a strong person to compromise.

Do this: Invite your significant other on a money date.
Be clear about your plan, so it doesn't feel like a bait and switch. You could go out to eat or just stroll through the park. Along the way, take turns with the exercises below.

  1. Start with gratitude. Take one minute to come up with as many positive things as you can about each other. Think of things your significant other did today-or recently. Or come up with qualities that you appreciate about them. Now share AT LEAST three ‚Ä¶ but don't limit yourself!
  2. Take turns answering the following questions. That means giving each other at least three minutes of uninterrupted answer time while the other person just listens. Then switch. Take lots of deep breaths, listen, and don't be afraid to hit pause and change the subject if things get too charged.
      Question 1: If you all of a sudden got $5,000 that you HAD to spend right away, what would you spend it on?

      Question 2: What is one good money value or habit you got from your family growing up? What is one bad value or habit you think got passed down?

      Question 3: Finish this statement: "When it comes to our family and our money goals, my wish is ____________________ "

SCORE_4.FEEDBACK:
The core of how you deal with finances in your relationship is sound. Nice! It certainly helps that you share similar values and goals, value one another, communicate well, and show each other gratitude.

Keep it up. And remember: This harmony only happens with a solid foundation of trust, openness and good communication. Don't take it for granted.

Do this: Turn off the TV and talk about your dreams.
Crack a bottle of wine, if you wish, and ask the big questions: Where do you want to be in five years? Fifty? How do you feel about giving to charity? Do you want to leave money when you pass-or spend it all while you're alive?

SCORE_5.FEEDBACK:
You and your significant other have built a union free from financial strife. Impressive! It certainly helps that you share similar values and goals, value one another, communicate well, and show each other gratitude.

Keep it up. And remember: This bliss only happens with a solid foundation of trust, openness and good communication. Don't take it for granted.

Do this: Turn off the TV and talk about your dreams.
Crack a bottle of wine, if you wish, and ask the big questions: Where do you want to be in five years? Fifty? How do you feel about giving to charity? Do you want to leave money when you pass, or spend it all while you're alive?

DIMENSION_1.NAME: Commitment and Teamwork
DIMENSION_1.DESCRIPTION: Life is better when you have someone to work with and someone to have your back (while you have theirs). A strong partnership is one where you're each committed equally to your success. That means valuing your role on this 'team' above all else and putting time and effort to the relationship. Partnership strengthens into unbeatable teamwork when you add trust to that equation. You're both fully committed and complement each other so that you're truly better, together. Are you working together for the win?

MAIN.TITLE: Teamwork seems tough for you and your partner.
MAIN.DESCRIPTION:
Right now, you and your partner don't seem to be on the same page for most things, and that's stressing you out.

It doesn't feel great when you think you're putting more effort into your relationship than your partner.

Through this resentment, you might be struggling to read one another and work as partners. You each know what you want, but you aren't working together to figure out how to get there.

Time to team up again. Think of the team's needs before going directly to your own. Work on the trust you have with each other and as you do, start spending time together again.

When you're back on the same page, arguments about little things won't blow up into battles.

Be open to change, and start listening.

DRAWER_1.TITLE: The Good News
DRAWER_1.DESCRIPTION:
You're here. (Nice work on that!) That means you're ready to get to work on building a new normal ‚Äì and your willingness makes all the difference.

Think of this as a fresh start: don't look to settle old issues right now. Start small, and build up to resolution.

DRAWER_2.TITLE: The Stuff of Great Teamwork
DRAWER_2.DESCRIPTION:
Consider this list of features great teams often share. Which are most important to you? Where are you strong, and where could you improve? What would you add?
  • Good communication
  • Working well together
  • Being aligned on shared values and goals
  • Navigating conflict effectively
  • Dividing work fairly
  • Compromising when needed
  • Trusting each other's intentions

MAIN.TITLE: Right now, teamwork seems a bit tough for you and your partner.
MAIN.DESCRIPTION:
When you and your partner get out of sync, it's harder than you'd like to get back on the same track. In trying to align, you may feel like you're putting more effort into the relationship than your partner.

Through this resentment, it's easier to just look at your own needs, rather than that of your partnership. You do your thing, they do theirs.

Time to team up again. Get back to the trust you had in each other and build from there. If you don't decide to be a team, you both lose.

When you're back on the same page, arguments about little things won't blow up into battles.

Be open to change, and start talking about a game plan.

DRAWER_1.TITLE: The Good News
DRAWER_1.DESCRIPTION:
Marriages change all the time. And just by being here, you're showing that you're ready to get to work on changing things for the better.

Take baby steps, set small goals and once you make those happen, go back and tackle old issues. Until then, keep it in the present.

DRAWER_2.TITLE: The Stuff of Great Teamwork
DRAWER_2.DESCRIPTION:
Consider this list of features great teams often share. Which are most important to you? Where are you strong, and where could you improve? What would you add?
  • Good communication
  • Working well together
  • Being aligned on shared values and goals
  • Navigating conflict effectively
  • Dividing work fairly
  • Compromising when needed
  • Trusting each other's intentions

MAIN.TITLE: Some days, you guys have this teamwork thing nailed ‚Äì and some days you don't.
MAIN.DESCRIPTION:
Most of the time, you and your partner are working together just fine.

There are times when you and your partner's strengths can clash. But you generally know how to tame the situation before it blows up into something bigger.

It's the times when you forget how well you can read each other that the arguments escalate. When that happens, you can end up feeling like you're on your own.

Remember to rely on the trust you have in each other. You both know each other better than anyone else.

Continue to work at your teamwork. When you consider your partner's feelings, you'll both stay off the injured list.

DRAWER_1.TITLE: The Good News
DRAWER_1.DESCRIPTION:
You've got the basics down. You should feel good about that.

Expressing gratitude for the team you have is crucial. Neuroscientists from Harvard are reporting that being grateful builds your sense of calmness and peacefulness. Showing the appreciation will also make your partner feel great!

DRAWER_2.TITLE: The Stuff of Great Teamwork
DRAWER_2.DESCRIPTION:
Consider this list of features great teams often share. Which are most important to you? Where are you strong, and where could you improve? What would you add?
  • Good communication
  • Working well together
  • Being aligned on shared values and goals
  • Navigating conflict effectively
  • Dividing work fairly
  • Compromising when needed
  • Trusting each other's intentions

DRAWER_3.TITLE: One Small Step
DRAWER_3.DESCRIPTION: Tonight, tell your partner you're reading about teamwork. Ask: What do you think is the most important aspect of being a team? What do you think we could do to improve in our relationship?

MAIN.TITLE: Your teamwork is pretty awesome.
MAIN.DESCRIPTION:
You've got your strengths, your partner has theirs and together, you're quite the team.

Good teamwork is based in trust, and you have that in each other. You know their moves, they know yours, and together, you can take out even the toughest opponent.

That doesn't mean there isn't sometimes tension between the two of you. But when there is, you're able to solve arguments quickly, without things getting too personal.

Continue to listen to your partner with an open mind. You don't have to give in to your partner every time. But think of the team's needs before going directly to your own.

It's not about the win, but whether or not the team continues to grow.

DRAWER_1.TITLE: The Good News
DRAWER_1.DESCRIPTION:
Your team feels solid. You should feel good about that.

Expressing gratitude for the team you have is crucial. Neuroscientists from Harvard are reporting that being grateful builds your sense of calmness and peacefulness. Showing the appreciation will also make your partner feel great!

DRAWER_2.TITLE: The Stuff of Great Teamwork
DRAWER_2.DESCRIPTION:
Consider this list of features great teams often share. Which are most important to you? Where are you strong, and where could you improve? What would you add?
  • Good communication
  • Working well together
  • Being aligned on shared values and goals
  • Navigating conflict effectively
  • Dividing work fairly
  • Compromising when needed
  • Trusting each other's intentions

DRAWER_3.TITLE: One Small Step
DRAWER_3.DESCRIPTION:
Look at how the household chores are divided and ask yourself, "is this division fair?" If not, how can you change the equation?

Talk to your partner about re-balancing the weight. Do you each claim a list, or do you trade off each week?

MAIN.TITLE: You and your partner have hit "Awesome Team" status.
MAIN.DESCRIPTION:
You've got this teamwork thing all figured out.

You support each other when you're together and root for the other's success as you both pursue your goals.

That's not to say that life together is always perfect. How could it be? But when one of you is feeling that the other isn't listening, you know how to communicate your concerns to your partner.

The key to keeping things on track? Keep the good of the team top of mind. When you think of what will benefit your relationship before you think of what will benefit you, personally, your marriage will continue to flourish.

Be thankful for what you have and express gratitude for the strength the two of you have found.

DRAWER_1.TITLE: The Good News
DRAWER_1.DESCRIPTION:
Together, you and your partner are the team to beat.

Expressing gratitude for the team you have is crucial. Neuroscientists from Harvard are reporting that being grateful builds your sense of calmness and peacefulness. Showing the appreciation will also make your partner feel great!

DRAWER_2.TITLE: The Stuff of Great Teamwork
DRAWER_2.DESCRIPTION:
Consider this list of features great teams often share. Which are most important to you? Where are you strong, and where could you improve? What would you add?
  • Good communication
  • Working well together
  • Being aligned on shared values and goals
  • Navigating conflict effectively
  • Dividing work fairly
  • Compromising when needed
  • Trusting each other's intentions

DRAWER_3.TITLE: One Small Step
DRAWER_3.DESCRIPTION:
Find one area of household chores where you aren't in agreement.

Talk to your partner. Can you find agreement about how a particular chore is approached? If that goes well, can you get through more on the list?

DIMENSION_2.NAME: Effective Communication
DIMENSION_2.DESCRIPTION: Communication is crucial for success in a relationship. After the "honeymoon phase" comes real life. The honesty and openness you have with each other provides the foundational trust for the rest of your lives together. Effective communication means you make time to catch up daily and talk with each other about anything and everything. It also means that when it comes to difficult topics, like money, you work to understand each other's strengths and weaknesses and use that understanding to work through differences and disagreements.

MAIN.TITLE: Communication in your relationship isn't a priority.
MAIN.DESCRIPTION:
Right now, it seems you and your partner are like two ships that pass in the night.

Generally, you don't share the experiences of your day. There could be many reasons for this, including just being busy. But good communication is key to a meaningful marriage, so start trying to make the time.

When you don't talk, you also can't resolve any disagreements or resentments that either of you have. Regular conversation makes misunderstandings easier to clear up.

You are human, and your ability to be available, interested and understanding will ebb and flow. Just remember that your partner's inattention on a particular day may have nothing to do with you and everything to do with the work problem they're trying to solve.

With regular conversation, you know what's up ‚Äì what's important to your spouse that week, what's upsetting and where they need your support. And that can only bring you closer.

DRAWER_1.TITLE: Practice Makes Perfect
DRAWER_1.DESCRIPTION: Your spouse is your life partner. Investing the time now to talk and share your everyday lives will pay dividends for many years to come.

DRAWER_2.TITLE: Things to Consider
DRAWER_2.DESCRIPTION:
• What's holding you back from communicating more fully?
  • Exchanging personal stories gives insight into each other.
  • Instead of trying to "win" an argument, try to see your partner's view.

MAIN.TITLE: Communication in your relationship isn't as strong as you'd like it to be.
MAIN.DESCRIPTION:
Lately, it sounds as though conversation is an effort in your relationship.

It would be nice to hear, "How was your day?" But that's not happening much right now. We don't know if conversations have diminished because you've grown farther apart, or if you've grown farther apart because you're not talking.

When you do talk, misunderstanding is more common than understanding. Change that up. By talking more, you'll understand each other again.

Remember, feeling seen, heard and understood is one of the most powerful experiences of any relationship.

When you both feel valued and supported by each other, the words start to flow freely.

DRAWER_1.TITLE: Practice Makes Perfect
DRAWER_1.DESCRIPTION: The least threatening way to start talking again is to share moments from your day. Something your coworker said. Something the kids did. When it's your turn to listen, that's important too.

DRAWER_2.TITLE: Things to Consider
DRAWER_2.DESCRIPTION:
• What's holding you back from communicating more fully?
  • Expressing yourself-and listening in return can deepen your relationship.
  • Sometimes it's better to "agree to disagree" than to win an argument.

MAIN.TITLE: Communication with your partner has its ups and downs.
MAIN.DESCRIPTION:
You enjoy catching up with your partner, but it doesn't always happen as much as you'd like.

It may feel like, through the craziness of everyday life, mentioning the little things isn't important. That's not true. Sharing your daily lives with each other is just as crucial as talking about the big events.

By letting your guard down little by little, you'll see the full potential of your relationship.

Remember that you won't always agree, no matter how open you are in your communication. But would you want to? Your spouse is your partner in life, not your double. Your unique perspectives are what makes life interesting.

DRAWER_1.TITLE: Look for Common Ground
DRAWER_1.DESCRIPTION: No two people will always agree. When you do disagree, try to find a kernel of agreement, however small. From there, try to build understanding.

DRAWER_2.TITLE: Words of Wisdom
DRAWER_2.DESCRIPTION: According to Proverbs 15:1, a harsh word stirs up anger, but a soft answer turns away wrath. Try to stay cool, calm and collected when you disagree, and things won't escalate as readily.

DRAWER_3.TITLE: One Small Step
DRAWER_3.DESCRIPTION:
Next time you have a disagreement with your partner, try "reflective listening." That is, try to repeat what they're saying back to them to make sure you understand.

For example, "You are frustrated that it seems like you're taking on more of the chores around the house. You'd like to split things more evenly."

MAIN.TITLE: You and your partner communicate well most of the time.
MAIN.DESCRIPTION:
Most days you and your partner make a point to carve out time to talk.

When you don't see eye to eye on something, you know how to listen to hear what your partner's needs, values and priorities truly are.

By making a point to have daily check-ins, you know about each other's lives. Understanding the little things means the big things don't sneak up to surprise you both.

Keep going. Continue to be intentional about talking ‚Äì and listening ‚Äì to each other.

DRAWER_1.TITLE: Look for Common Ground
DRAWER_1.DESCRIPTION: No two people will always agree. When you do disagree, try to find a kernel of agreement, however small. From there, try to build understanding.

DRAWER_2.TITLE: One Small Step
DRAWER_2.DESCRIPTION:
Next time you and your partner catch up on your days, focus on listening more than you talk. Some ways to do it:
  • Try asking three open ended questions.
  • Ask follow-up questions to whatever your spouse is saying.
Get beyond the logistics: Ask how your partner felt about something in their day.

MAIN.TITLE: Communication is a strength in your relationship.
MAIN.DESCRIPTION:
Talking-and listening-is a priority in your relationship.

And when you disagree, you usually know how to work it out by talking it out. Keep it up! Strong relationships are built on this kind of communication, and you two seem to have it down.

Sure, you're human, and your ability to be available, interested and understanding will ebb and flow. That's life.

But give yourself credit for prioritizing this essential piece of your relationship. After all, it feels great to have someone genuinely interested in what you have to say, doesn't it?

DRAWER_1.TITLE: Practice Gratitude
DRAWER_1.DESCRIPTION:
You're lucky that you and your partner have such a deep understanding of each other.

Be thankful for that and bring that gratitude into your conversations. Identify 5 positive attributes in your partner and think about those before you start a big conversation.

DRAWER_2.TITLE: One Small Step
DRAWER_2.DESCRIPTION:
The next time you and your partner have a disagreement, pause before you tell your side.

Think about the most positive possible explanation for their actions and start from that perspective.

In short, work on giving your partner the benefit of the doubt.

DIMENSION_3.NAME: Feeling Valued and Heard
DIMENSION_3.DESCRIPTION: When the two of you make decisions, do you value your loved one's perspective and contribution to important topics? Do they value yours? Feeling valued and heard is an important component of a strong relationship. Couples may avoid discussing topics like finances because one member thinks it's easier to go it alone ‚Äì especially when the conversation usually ends with a fight. But when two people bring a high level of value and respect for each other into communication and decision-making, it makes your relationship oh so sweet.

MAIN.TITLE: You feel disconnected from your partner, and can't find common ground around decisions.
MAIN.DESCRIPTION:
Simply put, you and your partner aren't resolving issues very well. When a resolution is found, you might feel like your partner is the one that always comes out ahead.

If you feel ready, willing and able to communicate, maybe your partner isn't available to talk. Or perhaps you're both too busy and have given up trying to have a conversation of substance.

If one or both of you doesn't feel heard, frustration comes first, followed by lashing out. And then, after a fight, you avoid talking to each other, which doesn't make anything better.

DRAWER_1.TITLE: A Good First Step
DRAWER_1.DESCRIPTION:
Take some time to identify what you feel, think and want from your shared life. Being conscious of your feelings and being able to say them out loud to your partner is the first step to good communication.

As you gain confidence in your ability to share openly and honestly, your entire relationship will feel more supportive.

DRAWER_2.TITLE: Create a Safe Space
DRAWER_2.DESCRIPTION:
Each day, at the same time, check in with each other. Ask your partner to listen without criticism and judgement ‚Äì then also do the same. Reflect back what was said to show you're really listening.

If you feel your partner isn't understanding you, calm yourself with a deep breath and ask them to listen again.

If a conflict comes up, stop what you're doing to give your partner your full attention.

MAIN.TITLE: You often feel at odds with your partner, which can cause you to put off important conversations.
MAIN.DESCRIPTION:
Important conversations might not feel comfortable. It seems like your partner is the one that always gets the last word, which can lead to resentment.

Whatever has contributed to the current state of things, you're having a tough time feeling like your ideas are being considered. Perhaps you believe you don't have a decision-making role in your relationship.

Keep trying. Good, honest communication promotes understanding and draws the two of you together.

Feeling valued stems from feeling heard.

DRAWER_1.TITLE: A Good First Step
DRAWER_1.DESCRIPTION:
Take some time to identify what you feel, think and want from your shared life. Being conscious of your feelings and being able to say them out loud to your partner is the first step to good communication.

As you gain confidence in your ability to share openly and honestly, your entire relationship will feel more supportive.

DRAWER_2.TITLE: Create a Safe Space
DRAWER_2.DESCRIPTION:
Each day, at the same time, check in with each other. Ask your partner to listen without criticism and judgement ‚Äì then also do the same. Reflect back what was said to show you're really listening.

If you feel your partner isn't understanding you, calm yourself with a deep breath and ask them to listen again.

If a conflict comes up, stop what you're doing to give your partner your full attention.

MAIN.TITLE: You sometimes feel like your ideas are valued, and other times it seems like they're ignored.
MAIN.DESCRIPTION:
You don't always agree with the decisions that are made in your household.

Often, it's just a matter of timing ‚Äì you might make every effort to engage in big conversations, but your partner isn't listening. Or, maybe you're the one that isn't tuning in.

Even if you can't always find a solution to a problem that you're both happy with, at least you're talking.

Good communication promotes understanding and draws the two of you together.

DRAWER_1.TITLE: The Good News
DRAWER_1.DESCRIPTION: You're doing a lot of things right, even if you think they could be better. Think about what makes the difference between the times you make a decision peacefully, and the times conflict arises.

DRAWER_2.TITLE: Some Things to Consider
DRAWER_2.DESCRIPTION:
• How do you react when it feels like your ideas get dismissed or criticized? Do you lash out? Clam up? Is this something you could work on?
  • What would happen if you made more opportunities for your partner to talk, and you to listen?

DRAWER_3.TITLE: One Small Step
DRAWER_3.DESCRIPTION: Make a date this week to talk about something that's been on your mind. Ask your partner to bring whatever's on their mind, too, and take turns sharing and listening. Consider putting your phone where you can't see or touch it so you can give your partner your full attention.

MAIN.TITLE: You and your partner are usually on the same page. And when you're not, you typically work it out.
MAIN.DESCRIPTION:
You and your partner know the key to decision making ‚Äì when no consensus is found, agree to disagree.

You talk about finances, lifestyle and family matters regularly and feel confident that you're being heard. In terms of communication, you're equals.

But confidence doesn't mean perfection ‚Äì when there is a breakdown in communication, remember to go back to the basics and make sure that your conversation remains a two-way street.

DRAWER_1.TITLE: Some Things to Consider
DRAWER_1.DESCRIPTION:
• Carve out time to talk without too many distractions.
  • Don't let unresolved issues simmer. Talk about them with each other ‚Äì respectfully.
  • Ask clarifying questions if you still aren't understanding what they're saying.
  • Be grateful for the mutual respect you have for each other.

DRAWER_2.TITLE: Build on the Good Things
DRAWER_2.DESCRIPTION:
Show your partner that you're really listening.

After they've finished their point, paraphrase back to them what they're saying and how that's making them feel to show them that you're really hearing them.

How to do that without becoming an annoying parrot?

Keep it conversational. "Yeah, Tom totally took credit for your idea. That would have made me completely insane as well."

DRAWER_3.TITLE: One Small Step
DRAWER_3.DESCRIPTION:
At dinner, ask your partner a follow-up question about something he or she mentioned on a previous day.

Issues with work or family generally require longer conversations. Listen to his or her response and offer your advice.

MAIN.TITLE: You and your partner talk openly and honestly about what's on your minds.
MAIN.DESCRIPTION:
It's easy for you to be honest about what you want because you know that you won't be judged or criticized by the person you love. That's a big thing.

Just remember that being heard doesn't mean you always get your way. It means that you both know how to compromise when making decisions about your shared life.

You're happy with the communication you have with your partner. Check in with them to make sure they feel the same way.

DRAWER_1.TITLE: Some Things to Consider
DRAWER_1.DESCRIPTION:
• Carve out time to talk without too many distractions.
  • Don't let unresolved issues simmer. Talk about them with each other ‚Äì respectfully.
  • Ask clarifying questions if you still aren't understanding what they're saying.
  • Be grateful for the mutual respect you have for each other.

DRAWER_2.TITLE: Build on the Good Things
DRAWER_2.DESCRIPTION:
You listen to each other really well, but there are still a couple of areas where you find yourself tuning out.

Take note. If your partner continually returns to a topic that makes your eyes glaze over, (work stuff, cough, cough) refocus the conversation.

Are they not feeling recognized? Remind them how much you care. Are they not feeling like they can get ahead? Remind them of their success. There are many reasons for you both to feel grateful.

DRAWER_3.TITLE: One Small Step
DRAWER_3.DESCRIPTION:
Before bed, tell your partner how grateful you are for the good communication the two of you have.

Ask him or her what issue they think you haven't fully resolved. Set a time to talk it over.

DIMENSION_4.NAME: Managing Financial Stress
DIMENSION_4.DESCRIPTION: When you and your partner joined forces, you also joined finances - money owed to family, credit card companies and student loan processors also said, "I do." According to several studies, money tops the list of stressors for couples. That stress can have disastrous effects on your overall health and relationship, which means learning to navigate financial stress is all the more critical to the success of your relationship. How well do you handle financial issues and the dialogue surrounding money?

MAIN.TITLE: Financial stress is a constant strain on your marriage.
MAIN.DESCRIPTION:
From what you've told us, financial stress in your household is so severe that it's affecting both your health and your relationship.

There are no easy answers, but it may help to remember that you're not alone: nearly 3 in 4 Americans are stressed about money, according to researchers at Kansas State University.

Yes, you need to find a way to pay your bills. But getting a handle on your stress can be a way to start. Think of it as putting your oxygen mask on first: When you can breathe easily, you'll be that much more equipped to face up to your financial challenges.

You also don't have to do it alone. You and your partner might benefit from seeking out the support of others, whether that be a counselor or your pastor.

DRAWER_1.TITLE: Tackle it Together
DRAWER_1.DESCRIPTION:
You might have already found that fights about money can be more painful than other arguments. Remember you're a team, and try keep your eyes on your common goals.

Next time you argue about money, throw out the "you always" and try using "I" statements. For example, instead of saying, "You always spend too much going out with friends!" Try saying, "I feel like when you spend money going out you're not valuing our future together."

DRAWER_2.TITLE: 5 Stress Management Strategies
DRAWER_2.DESCRIPTION:
Managing stress won't put more money in your bank account. But it can protect your health and help you to think more clearly when you're facing challenges of all kinds.
  1. Inhale deeply and count to five. Exhale for another five. Repeat.
  2. Take a time out to pray, meditate or just breathe.
  3. Go for a walk with your partner.
  4. Raise your shoulders up to your ears, then release the tension and let them fall. Ahhh.
  5. Go outside.

MAIN.TITLE: Financial stress is a common challenge in your marriage.
MAIN.DESCRIPTION:
It sounds like stress over money is taking a toll on you and your spouse-and likely your relationship, too.

Here's the problem with stress: it rarely goes away on its own. Getting a handle on your financial anxiety could mean working together (and possibly with a community resource) to figure out an organized plan.

You already know what stress can do to your health and relationship. It interferes with sleep and keeps you from finding pleasure in time with your partner.

Talk it out. Keeping this stress to yourself will literally make you sick. Make sure you and your partner know exactly how the other is feeling.

Then, talk about your hopes for the future together. There is a way through this.

DRAWER_1.TITLE: Tackle it Together
DRAWER_1.DESCRIPTION:
You might have already found that fights about money can be more painful than other arguments. Remember you're a team, and try keep your eyes on your common goals.

Try this exercise together:

Write down your dream future as a couple, then write down your biggest fear. Ask your partner to do the same. Then trade papers and talk about it. What can you learn that could help you in your financial lives?

DRAWER_2.TITLE: 5 Stress Management Strategies
DRAWER_2.DESCRIPTION:
Managing stress can protect your health and help you to think more clearly when you're facing challenges of all kinds. Try one of these strategies today.
  1. Inhale deeply and count to five. Exhale for another five. Repeat.
  2. Take a time out to pray, meditate or just breathe.
  3. Go for a walk with your partner.
  4. Raise your shoulders up to your ears, then release the tension and let them fall. Ahhh.
  5. Go outside.

MAIN.TITLE: Financial stress has some effect on your marriage, but you're mostly managing it.
MAIN.DESCRIPTION:
You may occasionally hold your breath checking the mailbox for bills, or quibble about whose turn it was to pay, but you're doing okay.

It might help to know you're far from alone in worrying about money sometimes. Some 72% of Americans struggle with financial stress, according to researchers at Kansas State University, ranging from the occasional short month to constant fear that the lights are going to get shut off.

When you or your partner do feel financial stress, make sure you talk it out. Keeping worries to yourself won't help you, or your bank account.

Trust and open communication are keys to avoiding money tension.

DRAWER_1.TITLE: Tackle it Together
DRAWER_1.DESCRIPTION:
Don't take on all the money worries yourself, or expect your spouse to. Talk, gather solutions, make a plan and do it all as a team. Some ideas:
  • Start the conversation. Say to your partner, "I feel stressed about money when‚Ä¶"
  • Set some goals. How much would you need in a safety net to feel secure? What could you do now to get there?
  • Make it regular. Could you have a monthly "business meeting" to touch base about finances?

DRAWER_2.TITLE: 5 Stress Management Strategies
DRAWER_2.DESCRIPTION:
Managing stress won't put more money in your bank account. But it can protect your health and help you to think more clearly when you're facing challenges of all kinds.
  1. Inhale deeply and count to five. Exhale for another five. Repeat.
  2. Take a time out to pray, meditate or just breathe.
  3. Go for a walk with your partner.
  4. Raise your shoulders up to your ears, then release the tension and let them fall. Ahhh.
  5. Go outside.

DRAWER_3.TITLE: One Small Step
DRAWER_3.DESCRIPTION:
One time this week, plan a date with your partner. The only rule: It can't cost a dime.

Quality time together enriches your relationship. And it doesn't have to cost anything. Some ideas:
  • Eat a bowl of ice cream by candlelight after the kids go to bed.
  • Take a walk together.
  • Watch for shooting stars.

MAIN.TITLE: Financial stress is not having much of an impact on your marriage.
MAIN.DESCRIPTION:
You aren't completely immune from financial stress, but for the most part you're sleeping soundly at night. Take a moment to give thanks and be grateful for where you're at.

While you enjoy your own harmony, it's important to be aware that not everyone is so fortunate. In fact, as many as 72% of Americans are stressed about the state of their bank accounts, according to researchers at Kansas State University.

While you're at it, make sure your spouse feels the same. And don't forget to check in with your big picture plans. Do you have savings in an emergency fund? A retirement account? Are there things you could do now to make later easier?

DRAWER_1.TITLE: A Verse to Consider
DRAWER_1.DESCRIPTION: Whoever brings blessing will be enriched, and one who waters will himself be watered. - Proverbs 11:25

DRAWER_2.TITLE: One Small Step
DRAWER_2.DESCRIPTION:
Along with your spouse, come up with one free or very inexpensive social activity you could do this week, and invite another couple you suspect may be stressed about spending.

Concert in the park? Zumba class at church? Socializing doesn't have to cost a lot, but it is worth a lot: Friends make us more resilient to stress of all kinds.

MAIN.TITLE: Financial stress is not impacting your marriage.
MAIN.DESCRIPTION:
Whatever the number on your paycheck, you've found a way to make it work for your family. That's a great place to be.

Take a moment to give thanks and be grateful for where you're at. The truth is, you are among the lucky ones (even if it isn't just about luck). Financial stress is a very real burden for nearly ¬æ of Americans, according to researchers at Kansas State University.

And don't forget to look at the long game: Are you happy with your planning for future expenses like retirement or children's education? Is your spouse as at ease as you are?

DRAWER_1.TITLE: A Verse to Consider
DRAWER_1.DESCRIPTION: Whoever brings blessing will be enriched, and one who waters will himself be watered. - Proverbs 11:25

DRAWER_2.TITLE: One Small Step
DRAWER_2.DESCRIPTION:
Together with your spouse, come up with one thing you could do to give back in a personal way.

Think outside the checkbook. Sure, giving to a cause that's meaningful to you both is a great thing to do. But what about inviting over to dinner a family from your church you know is going through some tough times? Or offering to watch their kids one time while both parents work?

DIMENSION_5.NAME: Alignment on Budget and Goals
DIMENSION_5.DESCRIPTION: Spending and saving differences between partners can lead to arguments as few other things can. Add in differences in family background, experiences, income and values, and you can have very different goals and ideas of budgets, even with two people who love each other very much. Couples who are strong in this dimension align with each other on finances, lifestyle and future goals. They also continue to have fun while living within their means and their budget, while staying focused on their future financial goals - together.

MAIN.TITLE: It's a constant struggle to balance the things you want in life with the money you have.
MAIN.DESCRIPTION:
You think about saving money for bigger things, but there's always something here and now that you want to buy instead. That's understandable. There's never been more to buy, and it's never been easier to get it.

But, lately, the financial stress these purchases cause lasts longer than the thrill of the buy.

Remember that it's never too late to change your spending habits. Ask yourself this: would you be more satisfied with your life if you focused more on what really brings value?

DRAWER_1.TITLE: 5 Things That Really Give Life Meaning
DRAWER_1.DESCRIPTION:
To beat the cycle of consumerism, keep your eyes on the values that give your life meaning: faith, family, purposeful work, friendships and community.

It's not just about sacrifice. Research from the University of California, Riverside, finds that people who focus on what really matters are happier than those who are wealthy but focus on material things.

DRAWER_2.TITLE: Start the Conversation
DRAWER_2.DESCRIPTION:
Living within your means is only half the battle. The other half? Coming to an agreement with your partner on what that means.

Start here: Sit down with your spouse and come up with one financial goal you both can agree on, for example, a set budget for eating out. Talk about what it will take to meet your goal. Who will plan meals or buy groceries? When will you cook? Divide and conquer.

MAIN.TITLE: You often struggle with the urge to spend, whether or not your bank account-or your partner-agrees.
MAIN.DESCRIPTION:
When it comes to money, you have focus ‚Äì just not on the future.

Spending too much money on the here and now has caused conflict. Not just with your partner, but within yourself. You know there's bigger things for which you want to save your money. It just seems too hard to get there.

Consider how much "things" are defining your life right now. Would you be more satisfied with your life if you focused more on what really brings value?

DRAWER_1.TITLE: 5 Things That Really Give Life Meaning
DRAWER_1.DESCRIPTION:
To beat the cycle of consumerism, keep your eyes on the values that give your life meaning: faith, family, purposeful work, friendships and community.

It's not just about sacrifice. Research from the University of California, Riverside, finds that people who focus on what really matters are happier than those who are wealthy but focus on material things.

DRAWER_2.TITLE: Start the Conversation
DRAWER_2.DESCRIPTION:
Living within your means is only half the battle. The other half? Coming to an agreement with your partner on what that means.

Start here: Sit down with your spouse and come up with one financial goal you both can agree on, for example, a set budget for eating out. Talk about what it will take to meet your goal. Who will plan meals or buy groceries? When will you cook? Divide and conquer.

MAIN.TITLE: You experience some tension between wanting to plan for the future and live for the present.
MAIN.DESCRIPTION:
Sure, you like to have nice things. But you manage to keep a check on your urge to spend. Most of the time. Except when you don't.

It's a balance: buying what you want now, while also saving for bigger things in the future.

In trying to reach that balance, you and your partner might have had a few fights. Keep trying. With the constant ads and emails that tell us to buy, resistance can be hard.

Keep this question in mind: would you be more satisfied with your life if you focused more on what really brings value?

DRAWER_1.TITLE: How to Battle Materialism (And Win)
DRAWER_1.DESCRIPTION:
Next time you get the urge to spend more than your gut tells you is wise, remind yourself: None of that stuff adds up to a happier life. In fact, the opposite can be true.

A better play: Focus on what really gives your life meaning: faith, family, purposeful work, friendships and community. Notice none of those things have a price tag.

DRAWER_2.TITLE: One Small Step
DRAWER_2.DESCRIPTION:
40% off! Today only! Don't miss out! Sound like your e-mail inbox? Take two minutes to unsubscribe from three marketing e-mails you get.

Constantly being bombarded with things to buy can lure you into spending too much, and leave you miserable.

Here's a hint: There will always be another sale.

MAIN.TITLE: You enjoy an occasional splurge, but usually only with your partner's blessing.
MAIN.DESCRIPTION:
You know what matters in life, and because of that, you generally manage to keep your spending in check.

That's not easy to do. With the constant ads and emails telling us to buy every day, resistance can be hard.

Keep what really matters to you at the center of your life. Even if you are having problems with money, don't let that stress cause you to veer from your focus.

You know what your long-term goals are and what you need to do to get there.

DRAWER_1.TITLE: Can Money Ever Buy Happiness?
DRAWER_1.DESCRIPTION:
You know, and psychologists back it up, that buying stuff won't make you happy-no matter how much cash you have.

But if you do have extra money in your budget, consider this: New research from the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences suggests that you might be able to buy a little bit of happiness-if you use your money to buy free time, that is. Maybe it's not so lazy to hire the neighbor kid to mow your lawn after all.

DRAWER_2.TITLE: One Small Step
DRAWER_2.DESCRIPTION:
Set some simple goals with your partner for the next stage of your journey.

Pick the most urgent item on the list ‚Äì is there a debt to be paid? ‚Äì and choose one thing to do that week to work closer to your goal.

Even if the step you choose is a small thing, it's having the conversation about your goal with your partner that will really set things in motion.

MAIN.TITLE: You find ways to live simply and within your means, no matter how much you have.
MAIN.DESCRIPTION:
We may all live in a material world, but it looks like you and your partner have found a way to rise above it. It's not necessarily about having lots of money or never struggling financially. It's about finding a way to enjoy the simple life. Kudos to you both!

That's not to say that you don't have financial goals. But you've managed to balance the urge to spend now with the desire to save for later. And that's not easy.

DRAWER_1.TITLE: Can Money Ever Buy Happiness?
DRAWER_1.DESCRIPTION:
You know, and psychologists back it up, that buying stuff won't make you happy-no matter how much cash you have.

But if you do have extra money in your budget, consider this: New research from the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences suggests that you might be able to buy a little bit of happiness-if you use your money to buy free time, that is. Maybe it's not so lazy to hire the neighbor kid to mow your lawn after all.

DRAWER_2.TITLE: One Small Step
DRAWER_2.DESCRIPTION:
With your partner, decide on a single large purchase that the two of you would like to work toward this year.

Put a weekly money check-in on your calendars and talk about how savings is going (this can take as little as 5 minutes).

When you're halfway to your goal, reward yourselves with an inexpensive night out.

DIMENSION_6.NAME: Close Friendship
DIMENSION_6.DESCRIPTION: A meaningful relationship is built on a strong, foundational friendship. In fact, that feeling of friendship is a key indicator of the strength of the non-romantic bond with your partner. Couples with a close friendship intentionally set aside time together, support each other in social settings and trust one another as they navigate through hairy topics - like finances. And, crucially, you show each other grace and generosity. Even when it comes to money mistakes! So‚Ä¶ do you call your partner your best friend?

MAIN.TITLE: When you're having a hard time, your spouse isn't the one you lean on.
MAIN.DESCRIPTION:
Every relationship has strengths, including yours. But from what you've told us, friendship isn't one of them.

In fact, you prefer to be alone or with other friends or family members when you're having a hard time.

Good friends have similar interests and share the joys and sorrows of everyday life with each other. More than that, they're there for each other when needed.

Friends also want to help the other become the best they can be.

Many experts agree that friendship is a powerful part of a happy marriage. And it's not too late to build one, starting right now. You in?

DRAWER_1.TITLE: Fall in Like with Your Spouse
DRAWER_1.DESCRIPTION: The same rules apply for befriending your spouse as for befriending that cool new coworker. Show interest in them. Give them your time. Invite them out for coffee and laugh at what they say.

DRAWER_2.TITLE: When to Call for Backup
DRAWER_2.DESCRIPTION:
Sometimes when it feels like the connection is missing, a marriage goes through a dark period where it's hard to know where to turn. When you don't feel like your spouse is there for you, you might even fantasize about being with someone else.

Don't feel like you have to go it alone. A therapist or pastor can be a good source of support in helping you to sort things out.

MAIN.TITLE: It's often easier to confide in friends or family other than your spouse when times are tough.
MAIN.DESCRIPTION:
There are a lot of reasons friendship might not come easily in your relationship. It could be that friendship wasn't the thing that brought you together. It could be that you were once close and have drifted apart. Maybe you have a hard time opening up to anyone.

Good friends have similar interests and share the joys and sorrows of everyday life with each other. More than that, they're there for each other when needed.

Most experts agree friendship can be a valuable part of a marriage. And anyone can do it, with time and intention.

But it's up to you and your spouse to choose to work on this aspect of your relationship. After all, it takes a friend to be a friend.

DRAWER_1.TITLE: Revisit Your Past
DRAWER_1.DESCRIPTION:
Think back to what made you fall in love with your partner in the beginning.
  • What's changed in your lives since then?
  • What could you do to rekindle the early magic?


How can you appreciate the things that have changed?

DRAWER_2.TITLE: Lessons in Friendship
DRAWER_2.DESCRIPTION:
Spend a few minutes thinking about close friends in your life, past or present.
  • What made those relationships so special?
  • What takeaways could you apply to the friendship you're working towards with your partner?
  • How can you model the type of friend you want your spouse to be?

MAIN.TITLE: Sure, you partner is a friend-but not your best, or most dependable, friend.
MAIN.DESCRIPTION:
You and your partner may sit at the same lunch table every day. But you don't necessarily sit next to each other. Do you want to?

It may sound silly, but our experiences in childhood do a lot to prepare us for adult relationships.

The things that characterize the close friendships we had as kids ‚Äì telling secrets, having inside jokes, exploring together, standing up to bullies and just enjoying hanging out ‚Äì can also work in a marriage.

After all, through all of life's ups and downs, don't you want your best friend at your side?

So, forget playing hard to get: Friends can't read minds. Make sure your other half knows the kind of support you're craving. By talking about your needs, you can help each other become the best version of yourselves.

DRAWER_1.TITLE: Be the Friend You Want to Have
DRAWER_1.DESCRIPTION:
Think about the things you wish your spouse-as your best friend-would do. Send a midday text to wish you good luck before a work meeting? Binge watch the same show, and then obsessively speculate about the characters? Get seriously competitive in put-put golf?

Turn the tables and be that friend for your spouse. Then see what happens.

DRAWER_2.TITLE: One Small Step
DRAWER_2.DESCRIPTION: Invite your partner on a date, just like the good old days. Pretend you're just getting to know each other, and aim to impress. Listen to their stories and try to learn something you didn't already know. Spill your own childhood secrets. Make each other laugh.

MAIN.TITLE: Right now friendship with your spouse is feeling pretty solid.
MAIN.DESCRIPTION:
You know you're pretty lucky to have a spouse you feel completely relaxed around ‚Äì physically, emotionally and mentally.

Your relationship has a lot in common with your best friendships of childhood. You solve problems, tell secrets and cry on each other's shoulder.

You also disagree at times, feel let down, or lose trust. There are also days that you don't necessarily like them as much as you did the day before. That's all completely normal.

The difference between your friendship and the ones you had as a kid are this ‚Äì you can't tell them to go to their own house when they make you mad. Instead, you need to stop and work it out.

And effort shouldn't be limited to hard times. Relationships are dynamic and require energy and effort to keep them strong even when things are great.

DRAWER_1.TITLE: Be the Friend You Want to Have
DRAWER_1.DESCRIPTION:
Think about the things you wish your spouse-as your best friend-would do. Send a midday text to wish you good luck before a work meeting? Binge watch the same show, and then obsessively speculate about the characters? Get seriously competitive in put-put golf?

Turn the tables and do those things for your spouse. Then see what happens.

DRAWER_2.TITLE: One Small Step
DRAWER_2.DESCRIPTION: One night this week, intentionally focus on treating your spouse the way you would treat a good friend. Notice how you might give the benefit of the doubt, go out of your way to show good intentions or phrase things in a way to make them feel good.

MAIN.TITLE: You consider your partner to be your best friend.
MAIN.DESCRIPTION:
Here's something you might already know: having a strong friendship with your spouse is all it's cracked up to be. How great is it to be married to your best friend?

You trust each other and can talk about the big and small stuff of life ‚Äì family, finances and daily routine.

You enjoy each other's company, have fun together, can truly let loose and be yourself together. Lucky you!

You feel as if your partner sees you in your entirety, warts and all. And through all that, they love you.

DRAWER_1.TITLE: Take It to the Next Level
DRAWER_1.DESCRIPTION:
You're married to your best friend.

But can you build your friendship toward an even deeper vulnerability and intimacy?

Make sure you aren't just telling your partner what they want to hear about you, but what they should know as well.

DRAWER_2.TITLE: One Small Step
DRAWER_2.DESCRIPTION: Text your spouse something you love and appreciate about them. Try to make it something you haven't shared recently to catch them by surprise.

DIMENSION_7.NAME: Mutual Appreciation
DIMENSION_7.DESCRIPTION: Supporting your partner as they begin to make better financial decisions isn't always easy. But the alternative, shaming and blaming, isn't a great long-term strategy. According to several studies, maintaining a positive and generous view of your loved one's actions is a powerful predictor of relationship satisfaction. Beyond that, making time to experience and express gratitude to each other for what you have and who you have in your life is also a great way to build up your relationship.

MAIN.TITLE: You're quick to criticize your partner's financial mistakes.
MAIN.DESCRIPTION:
No one's perfect. In money or relationships.

In the past, your partner may have owned up to a money mistake and you didn't react as well as you could have. As a result, they may hide any new mistakes they make.

It's time to rebuild trust. Until the two of you can safely discuss missteps without fear of criticism and shame, your financial situation won't improve.

That said, you don't need to let your partner off the hook entirely for his or her mistakes. You just need to start discussing the situation constructively. Remember: you aren't always perfect either.

Making mistakes with money is a common cause of strain in a marriage. But even if there have been mistakes, your partner can't be cut out of your money management. Be patient and appreciative of progress. If you recognize their accomplishments, success will come more quickly.

DRAWER_1.TITLE: Turn the Tables
DRAWER_1.DESCRIPTION:
Think about a mistake you made, financial or otherwise and consider these questions.
  • How did your partner react?
  • How did it make you feel?
  • How did you react?
  • If your mistake led to an argument, can you think of a better way things could have played out?

DRAWER_2.TITLE: Try "I" Instead of "You"
DRAWER_2.DESCRIPTION:
When couples argue about money, it's easy to slip into the blame game. "You always‚Ä¶" "How could you?" "Do you realize‚Ä¶?"

Try instead explaining how your partner's action makes you feel, they may be less defensive-and more ready to work together.

MAIN.TITLE: You have a tendency to be overly-critical when your partner makes a financial mistake.
MAIN.DESCRIPTION:
