You know that saying about attracting more flies with honey than with vinegar? Well when it comes to improving finances, you'll get more cooperation from your partner with patience than with criticism.

You may need to rebuild trust. If you reacted badly to a money mistake, your partner may hide any new mistakes from you.

As a result, you might feel as if your household's money management has fallen to you, which you may resent. Time to bring your partner back into the fold.

Start discussing the situation constructively. Don't sweep mistakes under the rug - your financial reality needs to be faced. Just talk about it in a way that leaves you both feeling good.

Then, be patient and appreciative of progress. If your partner's accomplishments are recognized, success will come more quickly.

DRAWER_1.TITLE: Turn the Tables
DRAWER_1.DESCRIPTION:
Think about a mistake you made, financial or otherwise and consider these questions.
  • How did your partner react?
  • How did it make you feel?
  • How did you react?
  • If your mistake led to an argument, can you think of a better way things could have played out?

DRAWER_2.TITLE: Save it for Later
DRAWER_2.DESCRIPTION:
Ever send off a fiery text, only to later wish you'd held your tongue?

Often your first reaction isn't your best one. So next time you find out your partner did something you wish they hadn't with your finances, hit the pause button, and agree to talk about it-later.

The same strategy can be helpful when you're the one who screwed up. Say, "I know you're frustrated with me. Can we talk about it later tonight when we've both cooled down?"

MAIN.TITLE: Sometimes you can be critical of your partner's financial missteps.
MAIN.DESCRIPTION:
You try to be supportive of your partner's efforts to improve in the financial arena. And you can see that improvement happening, though it might seem like there's still a ways to go.

But sometimes, when your partner makes a miscalculation that costs your family money, your reaction isn't exactly textbook supportive.

Keep working. Don't sweep mistakes under the rug, just talk about them more openly.

Criticism causes shutdown, which you may have already seen. It can also cause a loss of trust, which isn't always easy to rebuild. If your partner can't be guaranteed they won't be shamed about their mistake, they'll stop sharing altogether.

Continue to be patient and appreciative of progress. If your partner's accomplishments are recognized, success will come more quickly.

DRAWER_1.TITLE: Turn the Tables
DRAWER_1.DESCRIPTION:
Think about a mistake you made, financial or otherwise and consider these questions.
  • How did your partner react?
  • How did it make you feel?
  • How did you react?
  • If your mistake led to an argument, can you think of a better way things could have played out?

DRAWER_2.TITLE: Pretend it Was You
DRAWER_2.DESCRIPTION:
Next time you catch yourself about to go off on your partner for a financial mistake, stop and pretend you were the one who did the thing.

Consider how you wish your partner would respond, then follow your own wishes.

DRAWER_3.TITLE: One Small Step
DRAWER_3.DESCRIPTION:
This week, make a point to notice something your partner does well in the realm of finances, and give them props for it.

Maybe it's paying the credit card bill on time. Maybe it's packing a lunch for work to save money. It might be something they always do anyway. But that doesn't mean it doesn't deserve thanks.

When your financial efforts are recognized, it's motivating. And it's likely to lead to success more quickly.

MAIN.TITLE: You're usually supportive of your partner's financial efforts-even when they slip up.
MAIN.DESCRIPTION:
Bounced check? Late payment? You know it can happen to the best of us, and you try hard to hold your tongue over a single screw up.

You and your partner have trust in each other's decisions and when there is a mistake, you can talk about it calmly. Most of the time.

But don't start ignoring the mistakes because you're afraid of losing your cool. If something frustrates you, talk about it. And let your partner know that if you screw up, they can do the same.

Removing blame from the conversation is a great place to start, but continue to be encouraging. Change and progress can be a slow-moving machine. Make sure you recognize when good things happen.

DRAWER_1.TITLE: Advise Constructively
DRAWER_1.DESCRIPTION:
When a misstep happens and you want to bring it to your partner's attention, be sure that any criticism you have is constructive.

How?
  • Start positive. Talk about what went right, first.
  • Keep blame out of the conversation. If your partner feels attacked, they'll get defensive or shut down.
  • Provide suggestions if asked, and let them respond.

DRAWER_2.TITLE: One Small Step
DRAWER_2.DESCRIPTION:
Tell your partner something you appreciate about their financial contribution to your household.

Are you grateful for the income their work affords your family? Do they manage your cupboards and meals so you aren't tempted to order takeout too much? Are they a pro at finding bargains on things that make your life nicer?

MAIN.TITLE: You and your partner trust and appreciate each other's financial role-mistakes and all.
MAIN.DESCRIPTION:
Congratulations! You seem to have dodged one of the most common sources of strain in relationships: fights over money missteps.

That doesn't mean that mistakes aren't made. It does mean that when they are, you know how to talk about it without blame and criticism.

Your partner has also helped you achieve growth. They've offered gentle help where you need it and cheered on your achievements.

There is always room for improvement, even when you're happy with how things stand.

For example, are you open to criticism when it comes? Even if it is delivered kindly, is your first instinct to be defensive or accessible?

DRAWER_1.TITLE: Shared Duties
DRAWER_1.DESCRIPTION:
Your partner has this whole money management thing down pat.

But are you leaving too much in your partner's hands?

You share other responsibilities ‚Äì share your family finances as well.

Talk to your partner about what tasks you can take on, and have confidence in your own ability to be successful.

DRAWER_2.TITLE: One Small Step
DRAWER_2.DESCRIPTION:
Your partner is an integral cog in the machinery of your household. Tell them how.

Do they cook a mean steak that puts pricey steakhouses to shame? Masterfully orchestrate your bill-paying so it all gets paid on time, every time? Always come up with fun things to do together that don't cost anything?

LOW.INTRO: Take a closer look with three steps:
LOW.DESCRIPTION:
1. Reflect on your overall results. Resist the temptation to feel ashamed if it seems low-or too proud, if it's high. This is your starting line. Use it to measure progress over time.

2. Dig into the dimensions. This assessment checked your financial wellness across the Five Dimensions of Money, plus an additional category: Relationship. Read more below, and seek areas to build on.

3. Take ONE next step. Let this feedback spark your motivation, but don't try to tackle it all! Pick one thing that interests you, and just do that. Celebrate when you complete it, then come back for more.

MEDIUM.INTRO: Take a closer look with three steps:
MEDIUM.DESCRIPTION:
1. Reflect on your overall results. Resist the temptation to feel ashamed if it seems low-or too proud, if it's high. This is your starting line. Use it to measure progress over time.

2. Dig into the dimensions. This assessment checked your financial wellness across the Five Dimensions of Money, plus an additional category: Relationship. Read more below, and seek areas to build on.

3. Take ONE next step. Let this feedback spark your motivation, but don't try to tackle it all! Pick one thing that interests you, and just do that. Celebrate when you complete it, then come back for more.

HIGH.INTRO: Take a closer look with three steps:
HIGH.DESCRIPTION:
1. Reflect on your overall results. Resist the temptation to feel ashamed if it seems low-or too proud, if it's high. This is your starting line. Use it to measure progress over time.

2. Dig into the dimensions. This assessment checked your financial wellness across the Five Dimensions of Money, plus an additional category: Relationship. Read more below, and seek areas to build on.

3. Take ONE next step. Let this feedback spark your motivation, but don't try to tackle it all! Pick one thing that interests you, and just do that. Celebrate when you complete it, then come back for more.

LOW.INTRO: It's time for a thoughtful evaluation of your relationship with the goal of moving forward.
LOW.DESCRIPTION:
When long-married couples speak honestly, they admit what you and your partner might have already figured out ‚Äì marriage is hard work. The two of you committed to each other because you made each other happy. But your marriage is happening within the context of real life which means - family issues, work stress and of course, financial realities. How do you get back to the joy that you bring each other?

There is hope: one of the most helpful things people can do to reinvigorate their marriage is what you're doing now ‚Äì stepping back and getting a solid understanding of where things stand in your relationship.

DRAWER_1.TITLE: Good to know:
DRAWER_1.DESCRIPTION:
Start small. Even an adjustment in attitude can bring big changes. By focusing too much on the challenges, finding deep happiness and satisfaction is that much harder. Research shows that focusing on strengths can bring the hope and help you need to difficult times.

As you and your partner begin to talk again, make sure you don't begin with the blame game. Blame is a sure way to stay stuck and not move on. Instead, remember the importance of your spouse and keep that as your guiding thought as you navigate difficult conversations.

DRAWER_2.TITLE: More to Think About:
DRAWER_2.DESCRIPTION:
This report focuses on the Seven Essential Factors for success in your relationship.

Tip: Read the entire report. Mark the two dimensions that most resonate with you. Then, start with yourself. Commit to doing one new thing. Can you do that thing for a week and build each week? As you do, you'll gain momentum to move ahead towards a better relationship with your loved one, and with your finances.

MEDIUM.INTRO: This is the perfect time to consider what's working and where you could use a little help.
MEDIUM.DESCRIPTION:
Your marriage reflects most people's lives ‚Äì there are good days and bad days.

We get married with an incredible amount of optimism. Two hearts become one, right? Two hearts that belong to two people with two different personalities, communication styles, family situations and hopes (not to mention work schedules, financial issues and general stress). It's not hard to see where things can go off course.

That's not to say that you don't think your marriage feels good and you're happy with how the important aspects are going. But life is busy, and that means that sometimes the comfortable routines that come to be the connective tissue holding you together gets interrupted. Fortunately for you, one of the most helpful things people can do for their marriage is what you're doing now ‚Äì step back and get a solid understanding of where things stand in your relationship.

DRAWER_1.TITLE: Good to know:
DRAWER_1.DESCRIPTION:
By looking at the communication and teamwork in your lives (especially around the topic of finances), you'll have a sense of how to keep moving forward positively.

As you dig in, don't look at it as a scorecard of who's right and who's wrong. Instead, think of this report as an interpretation of how you described your marriage.

Remember, marriage is a never-ending opportunity for the personal growth of two people. With some attention, you can have the marriage you want and need. Because, and you know this as truth: you're in love.

DRAWER_2.TITLE: More to Think About:
DRAWER_2.DESCRIPTION:
This report focuses on the Seven Essential Factors for success in your relationship.

Tip: Read the entire report. Find the top two issues that really resonate for you. Target these two areas for improvement and come up with your plan for change. Stay positive throughout! You're in this together.

HIGH.INTRO: You've developed a solid foundation to keep the two of you moving forward.
HIGH.DESCRIPTION:
Your marriage feels really good for you, and you're happy with how all the important aspects are going. Still, the busyness of life can get in the way of the most important things. When this happens, remember to stop and talk. And leave room for simply gazing at each other. (Seriously. Being looked upon adoringly never gets old.)

When you first fell in love, you idealized each other. As work, money, family and friends became involved, you began to know each other as you truly are and things became real. Even if you had already discussed how you made decisions, communicated and what you really valued, living it within a marriage is the beginning of a completely different story.

Being a couple that can work together, likes and appreciates each other and can navigate with effective communication are all significant keys to happiness in our relationship, especially around the topic of money.

DRAWER_1.TITLE: Good to know:
DRAWER_1.DESCRIPTION: With marriage, there's always work that can be done. What can you do to build on the secure foundation you have to make it even more solid and satisfying? Within the context of your partnership, how can you connect and have even more fun together?  Take it to the next level!

DRAWER_2.TITLE: More to Think About:
DRAWER_2.DESCRIPTION:
This report focuses on the Seven Essential Factors for success in your relationship.

Tip: Read the entire report. Find the top two issues that really resonate with you. Target these two areas for improvement and come up with your plan for change. Stay positive throughout! You're in love, and you're happy with each other. It doesn't get much better than that.

RESULTS_RELATIONSHIP.OVERVIEW_INTRO: , take a look at how you are doing in each dimension.

LOW.TITLE: The Humble Bee
LOW.SUBTITLE: The Humble Bee feels deeply that every person has a fundamental right to the essentials of life. As such, they are not concerned with their own material accumulations but turn their efforts toward making sure others have enough.

HIGH.TITLE: The Shark
HIGH.SUBTITLE: The Shark enjoys the finer things in life. The ends justify the means, so they'll stretch rules to get what they want. Material pursuits come first.

MAIN.DESCRIPTION:
When it comes to your principles, you are like super glue. You put people before money, and dream of a world where everyone has their fair share, and no one is standing on others in the pursuit of what glitters. 
 No one could accuse you of greed, selfishness or self-importance. But ask yourself: Do these principles ever make you feel guilty or ashamed for having (or even wanting) nice things?

DRAWER_1.TITLE: What are the potential pitfalls?
DRAWER_1.DESCRIPTION:
While knowing that money isn't everything is commendable, ignoring it altogether can be a case of denial. And that could get in the way of your ability to use money well-as a tool. 
 A budget could help you to take the mystery and anxiety out of your finances without compromising your values. Seeing your money picture as a whole can help you make more conscious choices about how you use it. 
 And remember, when you're giving, saving and living within your means, it is okay to LIVE. Spending money on things you value, like relationships or experiences with others, is not something to be ashamed of. Let that guilt go.

DRAWER_2.TITLE: What does this mean for your relationships?
DRAWER_2.DESCRIPTION: Don't let your own commitment to humility trigger resentment toward others who spend more freely or talk more openly about money. Having a friend-or even a partner-with a different approach to wealth could help you to find balance.

MAIN.DESCRIPTION:
You stand firm in the principle that money isn't everything-or even the most important thing. Sure, you have financial goals and a sense of purpose, but money doesn't define you. 
 Keeping your focus on a higher purpose gives you the perspective you need to be financially responsible without getting sucked into keeping up with the Joneses. After all, you know that the brand of your jeans or the mileage on your car won't change your sense of self.

DRAWER_1.TITLE: What are the potential pitfalls?
DRAWER_1.DESCRIPTION:
While it's great that money isn't your main motivator, showing too little interest in it could send you down a negative pathway too. Avoiding money altogether could leave you without a budget or a plan. 
 Taking a mindful, balanced approach to how you spend both your money and your time can help you to expand your practice of generosity and grow spiritually. 
 Think about your short, intermediate and long-term financial goals. Whether it's saving for an experience like a vacation (that's okay!) or giving to charity, being thoughtful about where you put your money will help you find a balance that's personally satisfying.

DRAWER_2.TITLE: What does this mean for your relationships?
DRAWER_2.DESCRIPTION:
It's wonderful that you feel a level of financial freedom in your life. But be sure that your commitment to your own principles doesn't lead you to judge others who have a different relationship with money. 
 Challenge yourself to be sympathetic to those who either live in fear of money or in pursuit of it. Whether it's a neighbor or your partner who approaches finances from a different lens, a little empathy and respect can go a long way.

MAIN.DESCRIPTION: When it comes to your principles about money, you seem to be a bit of a fence sitter. Some days you want the green manicured grass--at any cost. Others you're happy to be barefoot in the dandelions with someone you love.

DRAWER_1.TITLE: What are the potential pitfalls?
DRAWER_1.DESCRIPTION:
For now it seems you're in a good spot. But either extreme can be risky. Go too far in pursuit of the greener grass, and money becomes your master. Too far into the carefree weeds, and you could end up wreaking havoc on your life by ignoring the very real role that money plays. 
 Taking the time to think about and define how your financial life reflects your values and goals can help to work through any inner conflict you may feel. 
 Plan a time-with your partner if you have one-to write down all the things you value when it comes to your personal, family and financial wellbeing. Then consider where your spending matches those values-and where it doesn't. 
 Get in the habit of regularly checking in with both your budget and your values to make sure they align, and remind yourself of what's most important.

DRAWER_2.TITLE: What does this mean for your relationships?
DRAWER_2.DESCRIPTION:
Consider how your partner or other people close to you might impact your money decisions-for better or worse. It might be that you feel guilt or shame over spending on a nicer car, or that you feel embarrassed by the rust bucket you drive. 
 Be conscious of those feelings, and seek to understand different perspectives. Doing so can help you to maintain a balance.

MAIN.DESCRIPTION:
You know what money is worth, and you're not afraid to go after it. You're focused and driven, and keep your eye on the prize-specifically money and the nice things it can buy. 
 This personality trait drives a lot of your money decisions, and it likely makes you a smart businessperson. From perfecting the right image to using flattery to gain advantages, you know how to play the game, and you're determined to use it to build wealth and possessions.

DRAWER_1.TITLE: What are the potential pitfalls?
DRAWER_1.DESCRIPTION:
Be aware of how your choices impact others. If your pursuit of bigger and better leads to dishonesty or manipulation, consider the consequences. A life of "every person for themselves" could leave you in a pretty lonely place. At the extreme, it could get you into trouble in your relationships and otherwise. 
 On the flip side, clearly defining your personal values and boundaries may help you find a truer sense of peace. Think about how you can channel that incredible focus and motivation into the betterment of not just yourself, but also those around you. What would it be worth to compliment a coworker in front of the boss, rather than talking up your own achievements?

DRAWER_2.TITLE: What does this mean for your relationships?
DRAWER_2.DESCRIPTION:
Whether or not the people you're close to share this trait may influence your money behaviors. Do your friends also "play the game?" If so, it might fire up that competitive streak. 
 On the opposite side, check yourself if you're feeling frustrated by a friend or family member who seems to completely ignore what you view as the reality of money. It's tempting to think they are lazy or unrealistic. Instead, try to understand their perspective, and explore what you can each learn from each other.

MAIN.DESCRIPTION:
You're an expert at calculating and getting ahead, even if it means looking past the rules to better your bottom line. And you're not ashamed of it, either. You know how the world works. 
 When there's a financial decision to make, whether it's about a purchase, investment, career move or even giving, your impulse is to go for what's going to get you what you want.

DRAWER_1.TITLE: What are the potential pitfalls?
DRAWER_1.DESCRIPTION:
Be honest: How often do you find yourself justifying little "harmless" lies, or being less-than-honest with others so they'll give you what you want? 
 It may not sound particularly flattering, but you're hardly alone. Power and materialism can be very seductive. But the constant pursuit of more is an attempt to control your life. Have you ever sat down to consider what your "enough" is? 
 Consider if you could use a springboard to change. Winning can provide a feeling of power, but it's an illusion. The same is true of money: It's a tool for living, but it is not life. It's up to you to decide to re-align your behavior with your values. 
 Breaking free can be scary, but it doesn't have to happen all at once. How would it make you feel to leave a tip for the barista, or the street performer playing your favorite song?

DRAWER_2.TITLE: What does this mean for your relationships?
DRAWER_2.DESCRIPTION:
Remember, life isn't a zero-sum game. Instead of pushing down a co-worker to lift yourself up, consider how you might work together to both rise higher. And see how your relationships change for the better when you stop seeing those around you as either barriers or stepping-stones and instead see them as partners. 
 Life is so much bigger than bucking the system or one-upping the next person. Look around and see what you may have been missing because of it.

LOW.TITLE: The Rock
LOW.SUBTITLE: The Rock remains stable when others find circumstances too much to handle. This steadiness allows them to handle the highs and lows of money and all that comes with it.

HIGH.TITLE: The Feeler
HIGH.SUBTITLE: The Feeler lives with their emotions on their sleeve: what they feel is what you see. Faced with the rough and tumble world of modern-day finances, this unfiltered approach provides little protection from the stress that money is.

MAIN.DESCRIPTION:
Money is a part of life. It's something that you plan for and manage, but not something that controls you. Even in times of stress, you know that money is a tool and a resource, but not something that determines that value or quality of your life. 
 Three cheers to not stressing about money! It sounds like you have a very focused approach to finances, and one that isn't easily knocked off course by emotions or impulsivity. You make a plan and follow it, period.

DRAWER_1.TITLE: What are the potential pitfalls?
DRAWER_1.DESCRIPTION:
Beware of being so rigid with your money management that you don't leave any room for your heart to get involved. Doing so runs the risk of sapping joy from your life. Remember-it's okay to spend "just because" once in a while as long as it fits into your big picture plan and feeds your values. 
 Check yourself if you bristle at a charity request that truly pulls at your heartstrings, but isn't in your budget plan. Could sticking to your plan be keeping you from supporting your values?

DRAWER_2.TITLE: What does this mean for your relationships?
DRAWER_2.DESCRIPTION:
Always saying no to impromptu fun activities could take a toll on your relationships. Know that letting loose once in a while isn't necessarily a fast track to becoming a reckless spender. 
 Also, remember that not everyone shares your no-nonsense approach to money, and that's okay. Be open to sharing (without judgment) your stability and objective views, as well as learning from others' deep emotions and heartfelt approach. 
 Be grateful for the gift you have of feeling at ease in your money life. Think about the people along the way who've helped you, and take time to be grateful for those influences. Consider how you could pay it forward. Random acts of generosity don't have to be exorbitant, but whether it's a supportive word or a few dollars, you may be able to help someone else in profound ways.

MAIN.DESCRIPTION: You don't generally stress much about finances, or fall prey to emotional or impulsive money decisions. Lucky you! Many of us could use a little bit of your self-control.

DRAWER_1.TITLE: What are the potential pitfalls?
DRAWER_1.DESCRIPTION:
Be aware that even the most even-keeled money personalities aren't immune from downsides. If taken to the extreme, an unemotional approach to money could keep you from some of the joys of life. 
 For example, refusing to give in to supporting a cause, even one that is pulling at your heartstrings, could mean sticking to your budget but compromising your values. Similarly, completely closing yourself off from the occasional fun, spur of the moment activity or impromptu act of generosity could take a toll on you and your loved ones. 
 Be careful not to let your unemotional stance toward money translate to avoiding the subject altogether. Doing so could leave you unprepared for your future long-term needs. You don't necessarily need to stress about the future, but you should make sure to have general financial goals to work toward.

DRAWER_2.TITLE: What does this mean for your relationships?
DRAWER_2.DESCRIPTION:
Remember that not everyone shares your no-nonsense approach to money, and that's okay. Be open to sharing (without judgment) your stability and objective views, as well as learning from others' deep emotions and heartfelt approach. 
 Not stressing about finances is a gift. Make sure you take the time to give thanks for all that you have-maybe even telling someone how much they've contributed to the path you've found. No one gets to where they are alone, so it's important to think about the people along the way who helped you. 
 And be open to random acts of kindness. For those whose generosity, either through money or time, played a role in your finding the stable spot you're in now, pay it forward.

MAIN.DESCRIPTION:
When it comes to your emotions and money, it's all about your mood. Sometimes you go with the flow and don't let it worry you too much. Other times you feel anxious about economic challenges. Sometimes you're impulsive. Other times you're proudly pragmatic. 
 Being intentional with your finances can be an important key to balancing both your heart and mind when it comes to money. After all, they both matter!

DRAWER_1.TITLE: What are the potential pitfalls?
DRAWER_1.DESCRIPTION:
Both spending and saving can feel pretty empty if you don't have a sense of purpose. We all experience the emotional desire to spend sometimes. But taking a beat to step back and consider the big picture can help you to avoid the inconsistency and frustration that can come with aimlessness. 
 Come up with a plan that balances your wants and needs, simplify your life with a budget app like Illuminate, and pay attention to any patterns and triggers that you find lead to anxiety or impulsive spending. Then proactively plan how you'll counteract those moments. 
 And beware: A swing too far in either direction of this personality trait can be problematic. Get swept too far into emotional spending and anxiety, and it could lead to uncontrollable debt, stress and fighting about money in your relationships. Too far in the other direction and it could lead to an overly rigid or heartless approach to finances. That could keep money from being a tool in your life that allows you to live joyfully or give to help others with a sense of abundance.

DRAWER_2.TITLE: What does this mean for your relationships?
DRAWER_2.DESCRIPTION:
As you interact with others in your life, either sharing finances with a partner or splitting the tab at dinner with friends, be aware of how others' personalities influence you. A highly emotional person may bring out stress, or try to tempt you into rash money decisions you'll later regret. Yet you may find an overly unemotional person to be exhausting (and boring) in their rigid approach. 
 Practice empathy by asking questions and trying to see both the benefits and opportunities of different perspectives. We all can learn and benefit from each other's viewpoints.

MAIN.DESCRIPTION:
You tend to be impulsive and emotional when it comes to money. This shows up in the way you spend and save, and how you think and feel about finances. 
 Your ability to feel emotions deeply is a wonderful gift: it helps you bond with friends, feel empathy for those around you and give generously. 
 When it comes to money, though, big emotions can get complicated. They can make you prone to impulsive spending-as a pick-me-up, to patch bad feelings, or just because you like how it makes you feel-for a minute.

DRAWER_1.TITLE: What are the potential pitfalls?
DRAWER_1.DESCRIPTION:
Over time, all those emotional swings might cause you to feel anxious about money, avoiding the subject altogether. That can lead to debt, missed financial opportunities and even relationship problems, whether those you're close to are also emotional, or appear more rational in their approach. 
 Identifying how emotions drive your money habits is an important first step to gaining control. If emotional spending is making your finances haywire, get real about what your triggers are, and make a plan to manage them. For example, curtail a payday spending habit by auto depositing money into savings that are harder to access. Or ask a trusted friend to be an accountability partner you can call for encouragement to stick to your goals. 
 To counteract stress and anxiety around money, knowledge can be power. Write down your income and your expenses. Seeing your money coming and going, and making a plan for how you want to manage it, can give you a sense of control and help you to relax. An automated budget tool like Illuminate can make it even easier.

DRAWER_2.TITLE: What does this mean for your relationships?
DRAWER_2.DESCRIPTION:
You may be tempted to avoid people who differ from you on this scale. Those at the opposite extreme may seem boring or overly controlling in their approach to money, while those who seem to have more of a balance between emotions and self-control may make you feel self-conscious. 
 Remember, we all have strengths and opportunities. Don't be ashamed to learn some healthy habits from those who do things differently-and to share in areas where others can learn from you. 
 If you're working with someone different from you, seek to understand why they are the way they are. What could you learn from each other? Review your spending together and acknowledge the emotions associated with it when it's productive to do so. Be willing to listen to constructive feedback.

MAIN.DESCRIPTION:
You have a highly impulsive and emotional money personality. This shows up in in the way you spend and save, and how you think and feel about money. 
 Your ability to feel emotions deeply is a wonderful gift: it helps you form strong bonds, be an empathetic friend and maybe even give generously. 
 But when it comes to money, all that emotion can be trouble. You likely find yourself making impulsive purchases that you later regret-either to feel good or to avoid feeling bad. Or, maybe money causes you so much anxiety that you feel overwhelmed by it altogether. If you don't look at your credit card statement, it can't hurt you, right? (If only.)

DRAWER_1.TITLE: What are the potential pitfalls?
DRAWER_1.DESCRIPTION:
Impulsiveness can make it challenging to get control over your finances. For you, the answer isn't to try to control your emotions, but rather to be aware of how they trigger you with money. A perfect budget won't help if you ignore it when the desire to spend strikes. 
 Instead, work on getting to the root of how and why your emotions make it difficult for you to manage money the way you'd like to. It may be helpful to seek professional help. Money issues are often linked to security and safety, both of which trained counselors are used to helping people find healthy ways to deal with. 
 You can also take steps yourself to tamp down impulsive spending. For example, if payday sets off a spending spree, divert a portion of your paycheck into an automatic savings account that's harder to access. Or, delete the saved payment info from your online shopping accounts making it tougher to click and buy.

DRAWER_2.TITLE: What does this mean for your relationships?
DRAWER_2.DESCRIPTION:
You may be tempted to avoid people who differ from you on this scale. Those at the opposite extreme may seem boring or overly controlling in their approach to money, while those who seem to have more of a balance between emotions and self-control may make you feel worse about yourself. 
 Remember, we all have strengths and opportunities. Don't be ashamed to learn some healthy habits from those who do things differently-and to share in areas where others can learn from you. 
 If you're working with someone opposite you, seek to understand why they are the way they are. They could be compensating for fears and anxiety in their own ways. Set regular times to review your spending together-including talking about the emotions associated with spending when it's productive to do so. Be willing to listen to constructive feedback.

LOW.TITLE: The Individualist
LOW.SUBTITLE: The Individualist doesn't see the need to socialize simply because that's what people do. Or spend money just to be around people.

HIGH.TITLE: The Socialite
HIGH.SUBTITLE: The Socialite loves being with people, no matter what the occasion. This exuberance for the crowd means that money serves their social life. The degree to which they plan for that determines their financial health.

MAIN.DESCRIPTION:
When it comes to socializing, you can't wait to escape-that is, if you can't avoid it altogether. So it's not surprising that your social life is just about the last thing you're willing to spend money on. That's good news when it comes to staying within your budget. 
 It's great that you know what you like (and don't like) and aren't afraid to do what you want to do. And there's nothing wrong with being private or liking to spend time alone or with just a few people you're close with.

DRAWER_1.TITLE: What are the potential pitfalls?
DRAWER_1.DESCRIPTION:
While you're not tempted to overspend to keep up with a group, that doesn't mean you're never impulsive. It's just that your impulse is to always say no. 
 Meanwhile, don't assume that your aversion to social spending means your budget is ironclad. Keep an eye on what else you're shelling out for. Streaming services? Online shopping? There's plenty of spending you can do without talking to anyone.

DRAWER_2.TITLE: What does this mean for your relationships?
DRAWER_2.DESCRIPTION:
Check yourself before you become judgmental of others who enjoy socializing (and spending) more than you. And consider that occasionally it's good to go anyway. You may not like group events, but showing up-even for a little bit-does show people you care. 
 If you are in a relationship with someone much more extraverted, challenge yourself to respect your differences, and learn from each other. A more extraverted partner or friend could help you to break free from your shell (sometimes) while you can help them discover the beauty of staying in.

MAIN.DESCRIPTION:
We get the sense you're not particularly confident in group situations as it is. So it's not surprising that spending money to hang out with other people isn't really your thing. After all, why should you need to pay for other people's friendship or approval? 
 You'd rather spend your hard-earned income on what's important to you and those close to you. Sometimes that may involve socializing-but it's intentional. You don't go out just to go out.

DRAWER_1.TITLE: What are the potential pitfalls?
DRAWER_1.DESCRIPTION:
You're wise to sync your spending with your values. And spending less on socializing likely yields a more robust budget for other things (including savings).? 
 But keep in mind that toward the extreme of any personality trait there can be risks. For you, it's the risk of isolating yourself socially, or being so unwilling to spend that you're missing out on worthwhile experiences, or failing to nurture important relationships.

DRAWER_2.TITLE: What does this mean for your relationships?
DRAWER_2.DESCRIPTION:
Being a restrained spender may be great for your budget, but it can also take a toll on your relationships-especially with someone who's more extraverted. 
 It's easy to resent a person whose desire to spend and socialize doesn't match up with your own, especially if you share a bank account. Instead, try to appreciate your differences as just that-differences. You don't need to compromise on staying within your budget, but try to strike a balance that serves you both.

MAIN.DESCRIPTION:
From what you've told us, how you spend your time is more important to you than how you spend your money. That's an excellent perspective to have. 
 Sometimes you enjoy going out on the town, either with a few friends or with a group. Other times you're just as content to stay in. Either way, money isn't typically the driving force behind your choices, though it might play a role. It's more about your mood.

DRAWER_1.TITLE: What are the potential pitfalls?
DRAWER_1.DESCRIPTION:
As long as you pay attention to your spending habits and keep your budget in check, you'll likely have a healthy relationship with the role money plays in your social life. 
 But if you're not keeping up with your spending, financial difficulties are virtually guaranteed. When a decrease in income or an increase in expenses is causing financial stress, you need a plan. It's still okay to spend money for fun from time to time, but you need to have an eye on the big picture. 
 And remember: It isn't the money that makes the fun. There are plenty of ways to spend time with people you enjoy, no wallet required. 
 If you do feel good about the balance of your social spending, simply stay the course. Just be aware that straying too far in either direction can have drawbacks.

DRAWER_2.TITLE: What does this mean for your relationships?
DRAWER_2.DESCRIPTION:
Being a middle-sitter means you could be susceptible to influences on either side. A new friend who is the life of the party could lure you into a stream of spending without your even noticing. Other times you may find yourself hanging back from social events due to money worries, and your relationships could suffer. 
 It's healthy to communicate about these things with those you care about, even if it's to say, "Hey, I really want to see you, but I'm trying to cut back on eating out. How about dinner at my place?" 
 Likewise, pay attention if a friend seems to be withdrawing socially, and see if finances might be a factor. After all, it's the people, not the dollar figures, that make the life you love.

MAIN.DESCRIPTION:
You find a lot of value in the time you spend with people, and that brings energy to your financial life. You love work because it gives you a context to interact with others. It also provides income that you can spend socializing. 
 Cost isn't much of a concern for you, especially if you're creating experiences. You see going out with friends or family as a worthwhile investment, and you feel whatever you spend comes back to you tenfold in terms of connections made.

DRAWER_1.TITLE: What are the potential pitfalls?
DRAWER_1.DESCRIPTION:
If your spending and budget are in proper balance, there's no problem. If they're not, something's gotta give. 
 But do you know? If you're not sure how much you spend in a month on socializing, find out. Look at your bank and credit card statements for the past 60 days, or use an app like Illuminate that can pull the info together for you automatically. Is the amount what you expected? Is it sustainable, keeping in mind your other immediate and long-term goals? 
 If you want (or need) to scale back, consider how you could fill your thirst for shared experiences without overspending. How would your friends respond if you suggested less expensive options for hanging out? Would anyone be relieved? Chances are you're not the only one who could use a day off from feeling like they have to live up to the spending standards of the group.

DRAWER_2.TITLE: What does this mean for your relationships?
DRAWER_2.DESCRIPTION:
Keep in mind that everyone's budget-and personality-is different, and that's okay. Your friend who doesn't spend as freely isn't a dud or a buzz-kill-they just have a different approach to money. 
 And the truth is, you could probably both learn a bit from each other. You could help your friend stay socially connected, and they could help you learn some new ways to experience life.

MAIN.DESCRIPTION:
You are an extravert to the max. Your confidence and charisma are hard to beat, your energy has no bounds and when it comes to socializing, others seem to gravitate toward your unbridled enthusiasm for life. 
 The other thing that knows no bounds? Your spending. You don't hesitate to go out, buy whatever and enjoy every minute of it. Life is for living, right? 
 Being among friends is priceless in many ways. But remember there doesn't always have to be a price tag on togetherness.

DRAWER_1.TITLE: What are the potential pitfalls?
DRAWER_1.DESCRIPTION:
Fun is fun, but you could run the risk of putting your own financial health in jeopardy in exchange for a good time. 
 Humans are fundamentally social creatures. But it's also important to define some limits if your social life exceeds your financial means. With debit and credit cards, the cost doesn't always seem real in the moment. But those swipes add up, and if you don't have a plan, your spending could leave you in financial turmoil. 
 Love orchestrating a good social event? Put that talent to use making some fun free outings. Start a group text encouraging friends to contribute ideas, then start doing. Potluck picnic at the park? Free talk at the public library? Bottle of wine and someone's couch? 
 It's a win for everyone-after all, no one wants to be left out because of money.

DRAWER_2.TITLE: What does this mean for your relationships?
DRAWER_2.DESCRIPTION:
Learning to sometimes say no, or to explore more economical ways to socialize, is one important way to gain control of your finances. And it could strengthen your relationships, too. 
 Remember that spending less isn't always about experiencing less. In fact, consider if in your quest for new adventures you may be leaving out some people who can't afford to do the same things. 
 That friend who passes on the spendy dinner out isn't necessarily a dud or a buzz-kill-they may just have a different money personality. The truth is, you could probably both learn a bit from each other: You could help your friend stay socially connected, and they could help you learn some new ways to experience life-without going broke.

LOW.TITLE: The Critic
LOW.SUBTITLE: The Critic is driven to defend their position whatever the occasion. This self-assuredness can lead to tunnel vision when making their own financial decisions and can cause separation between them and others.

HIGH.TITLE: The Advocate
HIGH.SUBTITLE: The Advocate looks to contribute to others' success and satisfaction. Money is a secondary issue in their lives unless they give beyond what they can afford and, as a result, can't meet their own needs.

MAIN.DESCRIPTION:
When it comes to managing money, you are full of advice for anyone and everyone. After all, who doesn't want a better deal? So whether it's your family and friends or the person in front of you in the checkout line, you're quick to share what you know. 
 Helping others makes you feel good, and that's a positive for sure. But don't forget that money can be delicate for many people. Sure there are opportunities to help people. But it can't be forced. True help requires willingness on both sides; without that, nothing actually happens. The bigger risk: When a time comes for you to actually be helpful, the person you tried to help previously might be turned off to your advice.

DRAWER_1.TITLE: What are the potential pitfalls?
DRAWER_1.DESCRIPTION:
Even if you're truly trying to help, being overly critical of others' choices or overly defensive of your own personal views and values can make you a bit hard to get along with. Maybe you see it as something you need to work on, or maybe you just feel misunderstood. But either way refusing to compromise or admit when you're wrong can lead to a quick temper and little patience. 
 Unfortunately, for all the confidence you have in your views on money, if it leads to distrusting the world and people around you, no amount of being "right" will lead to happiness. 
 It's true we live in a world that seems to encourage taking as much as you can. But buying into that ideology it could be causing you pain, fear and unhappiness. Instead of avoiding people or lashing out in anger, pause, breathe and listen. Try meditating on the abundance of gifts you've been given, and see if that brings you some peace.

DRAWER_2.TITLE: What does this mean for your relationships?
DRAWER_2.DESCRIPTION:
What you see as others' missteps can have a real tendency to get under your skin, and that can make it hard for you to trust and forgive. 
 The problem: However sure you are that you're "right," being too critical with money could end up damaging the important relationships in your life. 
 Remember that when you hold a grudge you're really only imprisoning yourself. You might think you're controlling the other person, but it's an illusion. Forgiveness is always a more effective way to live. 
 Refusing to even consider helping others in financial need could lead to resentment, too, potentially creating a rift between you and that person. 
 A simple way forward is to begin a practice of offering kind encouragements or praise to those you care about. It may feel awkward at first, and your loved ones might even be surprised if you don't normally do this. But stick with it. Most people could do with a little more kindness in their lives.

MAIN.DESCRIPTION:
You have strong ideas about finances, and you're not one to keep them to yourself. You don't hesitate to tell others how they could be smarter about their spending or money management. 
 You see yourself as an authority on money, and you give out advice readily-invited or not. What you give out less readily: money. Either because you don't trust people to spend it wisely or you feel they aren't deserving of it, you tend to keep your wallet closed. Didn't they get themselves into this mess in the first place? You prefer to give only when you're confident the money will be spent on necessities. 
 Just keep in mind: However well-intentioned your advice, one downfall of unsolicited input is that it may fall on deaf ears-no matter how "right" you are. People have to want help in order to receive it.

DRAWER_1.TITLE: What are the potential pitfalls?
DRAWER_1.DESCRIPTION:
A tendency to be overly critical of others' financial decisions or to dig in your heels in when it comes to your own personal views and values can backfire. 
 In time, this way of thinking could lead you to expect the worst from people and view the world through a distrustful lens. When you start to feel like most people have let you down, and people are generally guilty until proven innocent, it becomes you versus the world. And that can be problematic. 
 Refusing to compromise or admit when you're wrong can be a quick path to a temper that bubbles up uncontrollably. It's true that we live in a world that seems to encourage taking as much as you can. But buying into that ideology can leave you with pain, fear and unhappiness. Instead of lashing out, pause, breathe and listen. Instead, try meditating on the abundance of gifts you've been given, and see if that brings you any peace.

DRAWER_2.TITLE: What does this mean for your relationships?
DRAWER_2.DESCRIPTION:
The truth is, some people may find this money personality type to be hard to get along with. Be aware of how that might play out in your relationships-including business partnerships or other financial arrangements. 
 While it may make you feel good to have information to share, the truth is knowledge shared at the wrong time isn't worth much. If you find yourself becoming defensive when people aren't responsive to your ideas, it may be a sign that you have some underlying insecurities that you'd benefit from addressing. 
 And remember that when you hold a grudge you're really only imprisoning yourself. You might think you're controlling the other person, but it's an illusion. Forgiveness is always a more effective way to live. 
 Don't let people's bank accounts be the measure of their human value in your eyes. Refusing to even consider helping someone in financial need could lead to resentment, potentially creating a rift between you and that person. 
 A simple way forward is to begin a practice of offering kind encouragements or praise to those you care about. It may feel awkward at first, and your loved ones might even be surprised if you don't normally do this. But stick with it. Most people could do with a little more kindness in their lives.

MAIN.DESCRIPTION:
When it comes to money, you tend to stay in your own lane. That doesn't mean you'd never help a friend in need. But in general, you prefer to do your thing and expect others to do theirs-no judgment. 
 Money is personal, as you see it, and it's not for you to decide how others should handle their financial lives. So you don't typically dish out advice (even if you know better) any more than you offer to step in for financial help. You'd prefer that everyone just live their own lives moneywise.

DRAWER_1.TITLE: What are the potential pitfalls?
DRAWER_1.DESCRIPTION:
There's nothing wrong with a live and let live approach. But consider if by steering clear altogether you might be missing opportunities to offer help or support to those you care about. 
 That doesn't mean you have to (or even should) go broke paying rent for a friend who lost her job, or lecturing a family member about his spending habits. Straying too far toward judgment and criticism, or too far into yes-land (agreeing to every request for financial help) isn't healthy for your relationships or your finances. But there is a middle ground: perhaps taking that friend who's struggling to lunch and offering a supportive ear.

DRAWER_2.TITLE: What does this mean for your relationships?
DRAWER_2.DESCRIPTION:
While keeping your distance when it comes to money topics is fair, it could limit the intimacy of your relationships. After all, finances are a part of life, and something that many people are anxious about. And talking about it can be helpful. 
 That's not to say you don't listen or aren't interested in the challenges your loved ones might be struggling with. But perking up your antennae more often might provide an opportunity to grow closer. 
 Because you are not overly invested in your loved ones' financial lives-and you aren't dying to give out advice-you are actually in a great position to be a non-threatening, supportive sounding board in their lives. And that's something just about anyone needs.

MAIN.DESCRIPTION:
When it comes to money matters, your number one goal is to avoid conflict-even if that just means paying for it yourself. Money is just not worth the discord it can create. If you see that someone may not be able to pay as much, you're quick to step up and pay a little more to bridge the gap. 
 For you, it's a cooperative effort to allow everyone to enjoy themselves. If someone doesn't pay you back or regularly contributes less than their share, you give them the benefit of the doubt.

DRAWER_1.TITLE: What are the potential pitfalls?
DRAWER_1.DESCRIPTION:
Not feeling defensive about money can take a major load off of your relationships. But while your generous spirit is commendable, beware of slipping into long-term financial entanglements that could harm your relationships or derail your own personal financial goals. 
 Taking on too much responsibility for others could put you in a position of needing help later. Setting a budget for yourself that includes gifts of time or money to others is a good way to protect yourself.

DRAWER_2.TITLE: What does this mean for your relationships?
DRAWER_2.DESCRIPTION:
Remember that sometimes people need emotional support, accountability or financial advice just as much or more than they need financial resources. 
 When giving cash to a friend, try to also sit down with them and try to understand what's going on in their life that led to this need. Simply giving your friend the chance to talk out their troubles may be helpful in and of itself. 
 And check yourself: It's not healthy to feel like you have to pull out your wallet in order to bring value or meaning to the relationship. 
 Be sure to value yourself, too. Buy yourself something you've wanted. Go on a trip. Take some time off of work. You have the right to take care of yourself and enjoy the fruits of your labors, even as you're caring for others.

MAIN.DESCRIPTION:
That guy (or girl) who's always first to offer to pick up the tab? That's you. You have a generous spirit and pocketbook. You love to say yes, and to help or save others-at times without thinking about the financial or long-term implications. 
 Generosity is a wonderful trait to have, and you get a thrill out of contributing to the group. But keep in mind that there are other ways you can bring the group together too, like helping to sort out the bill and gather the money rather than pulling out your own card.

DRAWER_1.TITLE: What are the potential pitfalls?
DRAWER_1.DESCRIPTION:
The notion that friendship and money go hand-in-hand can be problematic. Wanting to help is noble, but feeling responsible for others' financial wellbeing-together with an inability to say "no"-could lead to some unhealthy money decisions of your own. 
 Realize that there are many ways to help someone other than a financial gift. In fact, if you are giving cash to someone who has trouble with impulse spending, you probably aren't helping in the long run.

DRAWER_2.TITLE: What does this mean for your relationships?
DRAWER_2.DESCRIPTION:
Helping others is a great thing. Just beware of winding up in a situation where you feel taken advantage of. Mixing money and friendship is notoriously difficult, and you don't want your willingness to help to ruin a relationship or derail your personal financial goals. 
 To find a balance where you can be generous without feeling resentful or harming your own financial well-being, budget your income and determine how much you can afford to give away. Then stick to the plan and don't cave to pressure. 
 Explain that you have your own financial needs and constraints, and hopefully your friends and family will understand and not blame you for maintaining healthy boundaries. If they don't accept this, you may need to face the fact that your friends don't have your best interests in mind. 
 It could be helpful to explore the root of your drive to save others. Perhaps paying for others makes you feel valuable, or is your way of making an impact. As long as you're helping and giving from a healthy place, where you know your value regardless of whether you say yes to money requests, it can be a good thing. But it's not the only way to be a friend.

LOW.TITLE: The Free Spirit
LOW.SUBTITLE: The Free Spirit finds satisfaction in questioning the status quo. As such they are often first to explore new financial methods, unless they just ignore the financial world entirely.

HIGH.TITLE: The Planner
HIGH.SUBTITLE: The Planner thrives on order, efficiency, and careful planning. These traits are essential for financial success and, as such, the Organizer enjoys taking care of their finances. They are also probably good at it.

MAIN.DESCRIPTION:
When it comes to money, you may think of yourself as unencumbered. You don't worry about it, don't plan around it, and generally feel fine about it. You're a free spirit, who goes where the wind takes you. 
 There are many wonderful aspects to this kind of an approach. But be careful: Assuming that things will just take care of themselves can actually affect your ability to live freely. 
 You owe it to yourself to get a handle on your finances. Think of all the things you could do that you always dreamed of doing if only you had some extra cash. No matter how you slice it, you will benefit from better money management. 
 Know that it's okay to be a free spirit who has a budget. In fact a budget may actually allow for greater freedom because it allows you to relax.

DRAWER_1.TITLE: What are the potential pitfalls?
DRAWER_1.DESCRIPTION:
Even if you're not in debt, you're probably losing money as a result of your lack of financial planning. Whether it's missed opportunities, impulse purchases, or fees and penalties, inattention comes at a price. 
 Know that creating a plan for some things doesn't mean you have to have a plan for every tiny money detail in life, nor does it mean you have to spend a ton of time planning. Free and low-cost apps and automation, like Illuminate, can do the hard work for you. If you have a medium to high income, it might be worth it to pay someone to help manage things. If you have a lower income, many churches and nonprofits offer financial services for free that could help you. 
 Whatever path you choose, setting up systems can help you to take control so you can go back to being your free-spirited self.

DRAWER_2.TITLE: What does this mean for your relationships?
DRAWER_2.DESCRIPTION:
You may not realize it, but your disorganization likely causes anxiety for those close to you. Because you tend not to worry about money, you may not think twice about asking a friend to bail you out of a financial situation because you lost track of your debit card or forgot to pay a bill. But when it happens enough, this kind of thing could cause your friends to start withdrawing. 
 It can also be challenging for you to work with someone who's more of a planner. For them, organizing and planning is how they control their stress around money. 
 Keep at it. You may be able to help your partner learn to go with the flow, while they can help you create some planning and discipline. It can be hard to change this personality trait, but it's easier to benefit from a partnership with someone who brings you into balance.

MAIN.DESCRIPTION:
You tend to avoid overly planning or controlling your money. It's understandable. Dealing with all of the responsibilities of money management can be overwhelming. In that sense, your ability not to be burdened by every financial choice is in a blessing. 
 But whether it's not wanting to deal with repaying student loans, or not calling the repair person for your broken A.C. because you're dreading the big bill, your lack of attention to issues of money can affect your life negatively. 
 The good news: These are things you can improve at, and in the process, improve your life and the lives of those you care about. You don't need to lose your free spirit. It just takes a little planning and discipline to buy yourself more freedom in the end.

DRAWER_1.TITLE: What are the potential pitfalls?
DRAWER_1.DESCRIPTION:
Unfortunately, avoiding planning and organizing your finances too much can backfire, creating more chaos and money stress. 
 On the flip side, setting up systems to track your finances can help you think even less about money. That starts with looking at your monthly income and expenses and creating (or updating) a budget. An app, like Illuminate, can make this easy. 
 Another thing you'll want to incorporate into your budget if you haven't already is any outstanding debt. If your debt is really overwhelming you, it may help to seek a qualified financial guide for insight into the best way to tackle it.

DRAWER_2.TITLE: What does this mean for your relationships?
DRAWER_2.DESCRIPTION:
You tend to use money when you have it, and slow down when it starts to run out. That can be frustrating for people around you who don't know how to predict your behavior. 
 It can also be challenging for you to work with someone who's more of a planner. For them, organizing and planning is how they control their stress around money. 
 Keep at it. You may be able to help that person learn to go with the flow, while they can help you embrace some planning and discipline. It can be hard to change this personality trait, but it's easier to benefit from a partnership with someone who brings you into balance.

MAIN.DESCRIPTION:
You go with the flow when it comes to money stuff. You may not be the most organized planner, but you're not in denial about finances either. You don't worry about every dollar, but you check up on things enough to keep yourself out of trouble. 
 For you, money is neither a burden nor a hardship. You use it and live with it, but it doesn't define you.

DRAWER_1.TITLE: What are the potential pitfalls?
DRAWER_1.DESCRIPTION:
Although you do keep tabs on things in at least a relaxed way, being too lax with your planning could grow into a problem. 
 It's a good idea to do a holistic review of your finances at least twice a year. That means reviewing your monthly spending, evaluating the progress you're making with long-term investments and retirement saving, and checking whether your savings account is healthy enough to keep you afloat if you were thrown off course by an unexpected challenge.

DRAWER_2.TITLE: What does this mean for your relationships?
DRAWER_2.DESCRIPTION:
While money matters may not keep you up at night, remember that there may be others in your life that are affected by your financial decisions. Be sure to keep them in the loop, too. 
 Money is one aspect of security, so while it is good to enjoy the moment, some level of discussion about the future could help to keep future moments more stress-free when they arrive. 
 Because you are balanced in this money personality type, you may have the potential to help balance out others who fall to the extremes. When talking to more detail-oriented friends, try to stay focused and understand their perspective. With more free-wheeling types, don't hesitate to share how your goals help you.

MAIN.DESCRIPTION:
You embrace the challenges that come with managing finances, take the time necessary to understand what you need to do and take measured steps to carry it out. 
 Your attention to detail and ability to follow through are strong assets. Because of your approach, you are not generally subject to the type of surprises that might sneak up on someone less disciplined. As a result, you feel a measure of control of your finances and are in good fiscal shape. 
 Congratulations! Your responsible financial management likely takes a lot of stress out of your life and provides you comfort.

DRAWER_1.TITLE: What are the potential pitfalls?
DRAWER_1.DESCRIPTION:
Be conscious of not letting this personality type slide into an unrealistic level of perfectionism or a perpetual state of anxiety. If you become too fixated on balancing every penny you could find you're missing out on the here and now. 
 Make sure to leave yourself open to spontaneity sometimes, whether it's a last minute lunch invite or a spur of the moment donation to a cause that moves you. Know that it's okay to spend money once in a while without worrying about how it fits into your budget.

DRAWER_2.TITLE: What does this mean for your relationships?
DRAWER_2.DESCRIPTION:
Be aware that others in your life--especially those who fall toward the other end of the spectrum on this trait-may feel stressed by your attention to detail. 
 Try to empathize with these differences, and look for ways you can complement each other. They can help you learn to let go of control at times, and you can help them create a little order from their chaos. That can be a great partnership!

MAIN.DESCRIPTION:
You are extremely diligent when it comes to managing your finances. Your friends or family might even say you're a bit obsessive. You know where every penny is, and whether or not you can afford to buy the newest smartphone or splurge on that fancy dinner. 
 Your desire to keep an eye on things makes sense, but even money management has limits. When it turns into perfectionism, it can become debilitating. Nothing is ever good enough. 
 Perfectionism usually stems from some sort of insecurity, or a desire to create security through control. Everyone has these, and yours seems to be a desire to have total control over your financial life.

DRAWER_1.TITLE: What are the potential pitfalls?
DRAWER_1.DESCRIPTION: The risk you run with this personality type is when what began as an effort to be in control has instead begun to control you. If that's true for you it's probably time to set some boundaries. For example, check your balance weekly instead of daily. Accept a last minute invitation to brunch without considering your budget. Give a spur of the moment donation to a cause that moves you. A perfectly ordered life is meaningless without relaxation, escape or play.

DRAWER_2.TITLE: What does this mean for your relationships?
DRAWER_2.DESCRIPTION:
Know that others might not all appreciate your money personality as much as you. Those who fall on the opposite end of the spectrum may very well feel stressed by your restraint. 
 Instead of letting the difference between you cause tension, try to empathize with their personality and approach. Look for ways you can complement each other's strengths.

LOW.TITLE: The Traditionalist
LOW.SUBTITLE: The Traditionalist values few things more than repeating that which has worked in the past. Accordingly, they are highly invested in maintaining the financial systems with which they are familiar and unlikely to try something new and/or innovative.

HIGH.TITLE: The Kickstarter
HIGH.SUBTITLE: The Kickstarter takes pleasure in innovation, art, and new ideas and experiences. If they find some aspect of money matters that piques their curious nature, they may find a way into managing money that works, but having a financial team around them will likely be of benefit since they may be stargazing.

MAIN.DESCRIPTION:
You tend to be quite set in your ways when it comes to managing money, and you can even be a bit aggressive in defending your approach to those who disagree. That's not to say your ways are wrong, or that you don't have advice that could help someone else. But try to remember that your ideas aren't the only ones that exist-or the only ones that matter. 
 Your skill at being critical is valuable and it's something you should continue to hone. After all, you're hardly an easy target for a scam artist. But remember that criticism and critical thinking are not one in the same. Instead of immediately dismissing every new idea, question, seek to learn and look for consensus. Every new idea isn't a conspiracy. In fact, even the expertise that you now hold near and dear was probably new at some point!

DRAWER_1.TITLE: What are the potential pitfalls?
DRAWER_1.DESCRIPTION:
Your experience and knowledge is valuable and it's yours. But being completely closed off to anything new or unknown could cause you to miss out on opportunities to learn, grow or improve in your finances-especially if innovation changes the game or makes traditional ways obsolete. 
 Another risk you face is falling into a spiral of always blindly criticizing everything and everyone that is different from you. Being overly judgmental of others could lead to being perceived as closed-minded. 
 Try to be aware of how others respond when you have these conversations. Is it possible that your sense of superiority or open rejection of their ideas is off-putting?

DRAWER_2.TITLE: What does this mean for your relationships?
DRAWER_2.DESCRIPTION:
Being aggressive about your money beliefs or overly cautious about any change likely stems from some sense of fear-which is understandable, considering how much we rely on money and its occasional unpredictability. 
 But if you come to be known for a "my way or the highway" attitude, your relationships will likely suffer. 
 Even a little willingness to hear others out or weigh different ways of thinking could go a long way. 
 Better yet? Listening to others' financial issues, struggles and frustrations-without judgment- can provide an immense amount of relief. Over time, it could bolster your relationship and earn you the trust and right to offer the advice you're eager to share.

MAIN.DESCRIPTION:
When it comes to managing your money, you trust what you know. Sure, there are always flashy new ideas out there promising increased wealth or a quick dollar. But frankly, you feel more confident sticking with what's gotten you this far. 
 You like to to stick with what you've always done, and tend to view new or foreign approaches to money management as too risky and not worth the time or effort of investigating further.

DRAWER_1.TITLE: What are the potential pitfalls?
DRAWER_1.DESCRIPTION:
In general there's nothing wrong with sticking to the familiar. The thing to watch out for, though, is when you find yourself glued to an approach that might not work as well in a changing world. 
 Case in point: If your parents went to college when it was more affordable, they might have taught you that taking out loans for school-in whatever amounts necessary-is just something you do. Yet the cost of college education has risen faster than almost any sector of society, so these days it's not so simple. 
 In other words, even as you may value what you've always known, it's important to still be open to new information in light of changing circumstances. That doesn't have to mean throwing out the old way of doing things, but rather continuing to learn and evolve. Perhaps after evaluating student loan options, you might choose a more affordable school, or opt to attend graduate school part time while working. 
 Being too closed off to anything new or unknown could cause you to miss out on opportunities to learn, grow or improve in your finances, especially if innovation changes the game or makes traditional ways obsolete.

DRAWER_2.TITLE: What does this mean for your relationships?
DRAWER_2.DESCRIPTION:
Being set in your ways is one thing, but if you're constantly shooting down other people's ideas it could negatively impact your relationships. Make a point to really listen to your friends and neighbors and hear them out without being so quick to make a definitive opinion. 
 You don't have to change your mind or jump on board with the new investment your father-in-law is all jazzed up about. Simply being open to hearing what others think and learning from their different experiences can bolster your relationships. 
 Similarly, try not to avoid people on the other end of the money spectrum, even if what you see as a radical or careless approach to money trends makes you anxious. Forging good communication with a partner or friends on the other side of this personality type can allow you to balance one another.

MAIN.DESCRIPTION:
You're a mixture of open and cautious when it comes to money management. You like learning new things, but you take it slow so you can grow at your own pace-and not get in over your head. 
 Consider challenging yourself a bit more by venturing into new arenas of money management. If you've been budgeting faithfully for a while, perhaps you're ready to learn about more long-term investments. If you already have a financial portfolio, maybe you could get some new ideas by talking to peers or family about their approach. Learning how a neighbor balances her investments doesn't mean you have to go home and try to replicate her approach, but it might give you some things to think about. 
 At the end of the day, you're not a big risk taker, but you understand that some level of risk and openness to growing your financial life is necessary to long-term stability.

DRAWER_1.TITLE: What are the potential pitfalls?
DRAWER_1.DESCRIPTION:
Too much caution can land you in a rut, especially in times of stress. You may not mean to stick your head in the sand, but increased stress can lead you to avoid thinking about the future. It can be tough to admit you need help, but during these times a trusted partner, friend or expert can be invaluable in helping you to put one foot in front of the other and make a plan forward. 
 On the flip side, you aren't immune from the temptation to take risks or jump on the latest innovative solution. Just make sure when you do that you ask enough questions to understand the potential risks and benefits of any big financial decision, from choosing a mortgage lender to evaluating loan consolidation options. Financial decisions can have long-term consequences, so it's important to take your time upfront to fully understand what you're doing.

DRAWER_2.TITLE: What does this mean for your relationships?
DRAWER_2.DESCRIPTION:
As someone who balances openness to new ideas with caution and pragmatism, you can be a helpful ally to those at either extreme of this personality trait. Just be careful not to get pulled too far in one direction or the other without thorough consideration. 
 Within your home and close relationships, talking openly about the state of your finances can be a healthy habit to develop. For example, if your partner or best friend knows that money stress tends to get you into a rut of inaction, they'll better know how to support you during the inevitable challenges that life can bring.

MAIN.DESCRIPTION:
You are open to new ideas and enjoy expanding your knowledge about financial tools and opportunities. But you don't necessarily plunge in headfirst. Whether it's a new job prospect or an investment that seems in sync with your goals and values, you're usually at least open to learning more. 
 In general, you don't see financial ideas or advice as good or bad. Rather, it's all an opportunity to expand your knowledge. You seem to feel confident in your ability to evaluate new information, and willing to explore ideas that others might consider radical.

DRAWER_1.TITLE: What are the potential pitfalls?
DRAWER_1.DESCRIPTION:
Your openness is an asset that leads to a greater number of financial possibilities for you. But it's still a good practice to take your time and talk to others you trust when considering new ideas with financial implications. While new opportunities can be exciting, they also tend to come with increased risk. 
 Marketers and financial "gurus" might try to make you feel like you are missing out and have to act fast, but it's wise to take a beat to consider both the potential cost and potential benefit of any financial move. 
 By all means there are risks worth taking. It's just best not to rush in without thinking things through.

DRAWER_2.TITLE: What does this mean for your relationships?
DRAWER_2.DESCRIPTION:
Your open-mindedness may encourage others to share their financial ideas with you, because they feel less judged by you. Do your best to listen and be supportive, but don't feel like you have to financially invest or commit to every new idea that comes your way. 
 Meanwhile, when working with someone on the other side of the personality spectrum who prefers to stick with what's tried and true, make a point to be empathetic to just how hard it can be for them to take a leap. Be patient in helping them to see the merits of new ideas without forcing them out of their comfort zone.

MAIN.DESCRIPTION:
You thrive on being ahead of the curve, whether it's investing in a crowdfunding campaign for the next new thing, or trying a new technology to streamline your banking. You're open, inquisitive and eager to learn. And you wouldn't mind expanding your wealth, either. 
 Your willingness to try new things is on the whole a positive. But it's not without risks. Trust new information too willingly and you might have a harder time differentiating between the good and the bad. And that could expose you to financial hardship.

DRAWER_1.TITLE: What are the potential pitfalls?
DRAWER_1.DESCRIPTION:
As savvy as you may be, your eagerness to be on the cutting edge can make you a prime target for marketers and financial "gurus" who want to make you feel like you're missing out. (Hint: Chances are you're not.) 
 You might think you'd never get duped, but get rich quick schemes can be awfully seductive. And we all have blind spots-its part of being human. 
 One healthy practice when making financial decisions that are out of the norm is to talk it out first with someone you trust. They can help you think through all the angles before you hand over any account numbers. 
 Whether it's buying a new car, forging a new career or investing your money in something, take your time to decide. Get input from as many people as you can (and no, the internet is not "people"). Whatever you ultimately decide, make sure to go in informed. And always remember: If it seems good to be true, it probably is.

DRAWER_2.TITLE: What does this mean for your relationships?
DRAWER_2.DESCRIPTION:
Chances are you tend to seek out creative and open-minded people like yourself. After all, it can feel frustrating to deal with someone on the other side of the personality spectrum who has trouble being open to new ideas and prefers to stick with what's always worked for them. 
 Just keep in mind that their seeing the world differently from you doesn't mean that everything they believe about finances is wrong. Nor does it mean they can't benefit from something new. Try to have empathy for how hard it can be to take a leap. Be patient in helping them to see the merits of new ideas without forcing them to let go of what they're used to.

DRAWER_1.TITLE: What does this mean?
DRAWER_1.DESCRIPTION:
You don't get caught up in accumulating stuff or money. You buy what you need, and what your budget allows. You plan for your current and future needs. But happiness comes from your experience of living, not buying. 
 Some people see money as the answer to their problems, but you don't. When you're faced with a challenge, you try to address the need behind it through communication or getting involved in the process. 
 Happiness results from participating as fully as you can with yourself and others in all that life presents. There's no check you could write to replace that.

DRAWER_2.TITLE: What are the potential pitfalls?
