DRAWER_2.DESCRIPTION:
It's great that you don't expect money to save the day. But ask yourself if you are being so restrained that you never spend money on non-necessities because it feels too frivolous. 
 If that's the case, consider giving yourself license to indulge from time to time. Spend a little money on yourself, go away for a weekend, hire a babysitter or take a day off work to catch up with friends. It's important to do these things. 
 Alternately, you could be so unconcerned with money that you avoid it altogether. Keeping good financial records, along with a plan for current and future spending, can help you to keep money worries on the backburner while making sure you don't get into financial trouble.

DRAWER_3.TITLE: What does this mean for your relationships?
DRAWER_3.DESCRIPTION:
You know that happiness comes from how you live your life. That's good news for the people you care about, since it leads you to prioritize nurturing your relationships. 
 Just be sure to also take the time you need to nurture your financial goals. After all, you don't want future you to be forced to sacrifice time away from those you care about to make up for your past financial mellowness.

DRAWER_1.TITLE: What does this mean?
DRAWER_1.DESCRIPTION:
You typically aren't one to get caught up in accumulating stuff or money. You buy what you need, and what your budget allows, but you don't expect money to be responsible for your happiness. Sure, you're grateful for what you have, but your quality of life is tied to truer meaning: how you spend your time. 
 You probably have a clear financial plan to meet your current needs and future goals, and you find happiness in experiences that don't cost a lot of money. 
 Continue to take time to enjoy those little things. Listen to the music you love. Sit in nature. Take a road trip.

DRAWER_2.TITLE: What are the potential pitfalls?
DRAWER_2.DESCRIPTION:
While it's great to keep your focus on money in check, it's possible you have trouble spending money on yourself or others if it seems frivolous. It's okay to indulge from time to time, whatever that means for you. Spend a little money on yourself, go away for a weekend, hire a babysitter or take a day off work to catch up with friends. It's important to do these things. 
 Another risk is that you could be so unconcerned with money that you actually avoid it altogether. Keeping good financial records, along with a plan for current and future spending, can help you to keep money worries on the backburner while still making sure you don't get into financial trouble.

DRAWER_3.TITLE: What does this mean for your relationships?
DRAWER_3.DESCRIPTION:
While you enjoy what money provides, happiness for you is about how you live your life. That's likely good news for the people you care about, since it can lead you to prioritize nurturing your relationships. 
 Just be sure to also take the time you need to nurture your financial goals. After all, you don't want future you to be forced to sacrifice time away from those you care about to make up for your past financial mellowness.

DRAWER_1.TITLE: What does this mean?
DRAWER_1.DESCRIPTION:
You're aware that money has its price-whether it's paid in time, worry or effort spent trying to get more of it. And while you know that those things can be a part of building a good life, you're generally in control of how much power you give money in your life. It feels good, doesn't it? 
 But like so many things, being in control of your relationship with money is an ongoing process, and you make choices every day that affect it. When you find yourself worrying too much about material things, you usually catch yourself and redirect your focus. 
 Consider making these check-ups routine: Taking a few moments each day to think of the things that you truly cherish-not "stuff" but what matters to your heart.

DRAWER_2.TITLE: What are the potential pitfalls?
DRAWER_2.DESCRIPTION:
As balanced as your relationship with money seems to be at this point in time, no one is immune from life events and challenges that can throw things off-kilter. 
 A major change, like the addition of a child or a move to a new city with a higher cost of living, could shift where money falls on your priority list.  Or a financial hardship-even a temporary issue-could damage your self-worth. 
 Don't be afraid to let friends and family help from time to time, and know that life-and money-is a work in progress.

DRAWER_3.TITLE: What does this mean for your relationships?
DRAWER_3.DESCRIPTION:
You generally recognize that money doesn't buy happiness, but you also wouldn't mind having a little more to feel comfortable at times. It can be easy to slip into a pattern of putting opportunities for more income above time with those you care about 
 To keep yourself in in this healthy place, try making a gratitude list once a week, and share it with those you love. A little reminder of what's really at the heart of a meaningful life can go a long way to keeping money worries at bay.

DRAWER_1.TITLE: What does this mean?
DRAWER_1.DESCRIPTION:
You spend a fair amount of time thinking about how to increase your income and build wealth. Money provides you with a sense of control, and it's important to you to wear the right clothes or drive the right car. 
 While you're certainly not alone in this, you may already know that it's not fulfilling. "Stuff" can provide instant gratification, but can also leave you wanting more, creating an endless cycle. Money won't solve most of your problems-it can only cover them up. 
 Because money gives you the illusion of control, you may have bought into the idea that life can be controlled. But it can't.  It can only be lived. Be willing to see how your relationship with money affects your life in harmful ways as a first step to changing for the better.

DRAWER_2.TITLE: What are the potential pitfalls?
DRAWER_2.DESCRIPTION:
Focusing too much on wealth building can leave you feeling empty in other areas of life. 
 If you let money guide the most important decisions in your life, and then you experience financial hardship, it can damage your self worth. 
 Know that it's okay to let friends and family help you from time to time without getting overly concerned about the image you project.

DRAWER_3.TITLE: What does this mean for your relationships?
DRAWER_3.DESCRIPTION:
If you think that money is the key to a happy life, chances are you're not as present to the people you care about as you could be. Consider that the quality of your attention is as important, if not more, than the time you spend with your loved ones. Be available and really listen. There is no substitute for this. 
 Yes, money is necessary. But it's only a tool-not a source of meaning. Happiness results from the way you participate in your own life.

DRAWER_1.TITLE: What does this mean?
DRAWER_1.DESCRIPTION:
Having money provides you with a sense of control in your life, and it seems to lead you to spend a lot of time thinking about how to increase your wealth. As a result, you prioritize showing your prosperity by wearing the right clothes or driving the right car. 
 Money is a tool for living, but when it becomes more than that, it can be a destructive force. It may give you the illusion that you are in control of your happiness, but in reality, you're not. 
 The truth is, happiness isn't something you can buy at all. It's a byproduct of how you spend your time. Sure, financial stability can give you more choice in how you spend that time, but if you spend it thinking about how to get more money, you're missing the point. True fulfillment is found in things like friendship, joy and love.

DRAWER_2.TITLE: What are the potential pitfalls?
DRAWER_2.DESCRIPTION:
People who worship money often fall into compulsive buying behaviors. That can be a problem whether or not you can afford it. Being so focused on projecting an image of prosperity could leave you feeling empty in other areas of life. 
 That becomes an even bigger problem when it leads to things like avoiding looking at bank statements as a form of denial. Burying credit card bills under stacks of papers doesn't erase overspending, but it could lead to lasting financial difficulties.

DRAWER_3.TITLE: What does this mean for your relationships?
DRAWER_3.DESCRIPTION:
Putting too much focus on money could cause you to neglect personal relationships. Know that while more money may seem like it will make you happier, social connections are what really will lift you up in good times and bad. 
 Try this exercise for some perspective: Write down five things you value in life that are not material. For each one, log how much time you spend in a week on that thing. Seeing it on paper can help you to start making more conscious choices about what changes might enhance your quality of life.

DRAWER_1.TITLE: What does this mean?
DRAWER_1.DESCRIPTION:
You're committed to maintaining a balance between your home and work life. Work is a part of your life, but not the center of it. You do your job, but also to leave it behind when you go home at the end of the day. 
 You feel connected with your family and friends, and are content with your lifestyle and your current income. All in all, you're comfortable with yourself-which is a great place to be. 
 Continue to invest yourself in the things that you find fulfilling. This could mean exploring new paths at work or redoubling your efforts at home. Most people can benefit from a periodic pause to consciously re-decide if they like the choices they're making in their lives. Growing and changing is a part of life.

DRAWER_2.TITLE: What are the potential pitfalls?
DRAWER_2.DESCRIPTION:
While balance is good, being too lax about work could potentially put your job in jeopardy. 
 You don't want to neglect work to the point that you have to defend why you should remain in the position. Nor do you want to force extra responsibilities onto colleagues because you let something slide.

DRAWER_3.TITLE: What does this mean for your relationships?
DRAWER_3.DESCRIPTION:
You might talk about work sometimes at home or with friends, but it's usually not the center of your conversations. Consider if your loved ones might like to know even more about your life away from them. Being open about what's on your mind is a way to share in both your successes and challenges. It waters the roots of your relationship to keep it growing and prospering. 
 Meanwhile, caring about coworkers can make your work life more fulfilling. Don't be afraid to also invest in the lives of the people you work with. Your support could be helpful to those who struggle to find the work-life balance you have.

DRAWER_1.TITLE: What does this mean?
DRAWER_1.DESCRIPTION:
You work hard to maintain a balance between your home and work life. Work is a part of your life, but not the center of it. You're able to do well at your job, but also to leave it behind when you go home at the end of the day. 
 Sure, it's nice to get paid. But you're not going to try to work more just to make more money. In fact, there are times when you work more than you'd like. 
 You generally seem to be in a good place. Because work is not your life, you have pursuits of your own outside of work, too. You make an effort to invest equally in your family, friends and fun.

DRAWER_2.TITLE: What are the potential pitfalls?
DRAWER_2.DESCRIPTION:
It's great that you don't obsess about work or go out of your way to log more hours working than necessary. Just make sure you don't become so lax about it that you put your job in jeopardy. 
 Neglecting work or putting extra responsibilities onto colleagues because you didn't allocate your time properly could lead you down a negative path.

DRAWER_3.TITLE: What does this mean for your relationships?
DRAWER_3.DESCRIPTION:
You may talk about work from time to time at home or with friends, but it's not the center of your conversations. You don't depend on work to fulfill your social needs, and you maintain meaningful relationships with people outside of work. 
 Caring about those you work with is one way to enhance your life inside and outside of the office. Continue to invest in the lives of your coworkers while you're at work. Saying "hi" or asking someone about their day makes everyone's life a little better.

DRAWER_1.TITLE: What does this mean?
DRAWER_1.DESCRIPTION:
You know all too well that balancing home and work life is a juggling act. And sometimes there are more balls in the air than you can keep track of. 
 But while both work and home have ebbs and flows in terms of their demands, it's key that you're willing to adjust. Ask yourself: Is that flexibility being shared between your home and work life? Or does work always win? 
 You may assume that your job has little flexibility, leading you to always flex into your personal life. But there may be simple tweaks that would yield more time-or more quality time-for the people you love. Could you reschedule that Thursday meeting that always runs over for the morning instead of the afternoon and make it to your daughter's soccer games? Could you telecommute one day a week to be more focused-and save the commute time?

DRAWER_2.TITLE: What are the potential pitfalls?
DRAWER_2.DESCRIPTION:
You seem to have a pretty good handle on work-life balance. But that doesn't mean you're immune from missing out on family or social activities because of work obligations. 
 Keep checking yourself: If your dinner conversation is constantly interrupted by texts and e-mails from work, think about rebalancing those boundaries. It's normal to get caught up in work too much from time to time. But it's also a signal that it's time to shift things.

DRAWER_3.TITLE: What does this mean for your relationships?
DRAWER_3.DESCRIPTION:
If work is a common source of arguments with those you love, it's a sign that you need to reconsider your priorities. Missing out on family or social activities because of work can happen to anyone once in a while. But when it happens frequently, or when work is encroaching in other ways-like checking work e-mail during meals-it's not doing your relationships any favors. 
 A time inventory could give you a clearer picture of how you're balancing your time between work and home. At the end of each workday for a week or two, write down how you spent each hour. At the end of the day, look it over, thinking about where you might make adjustments. This isn't to say that every minute needs to be productive. But maybe you didn't realize how much time you spent checking e-mails, and could adjust.

DRAWER_1.TITLE: What does this mean?
DRAWER_1.DESCRIPTION:
Work can provide a real sense of accomplishment. And because it's so valued in society, it's easy to get caught up in it. But when hard work turns into workaholism, it can cause you and your loved ones harm. It seems like you're heading into this territory, and may be time to take a step back. 
 The most precious thing you have is time. Ask yourself: Are you investing it in ways you'll be proud of looking back at the end of your life? 
 There are a lot of factors that can contribute to workaholism, and money is likely only a small piece of it. For many people, working a lot gives a sense of control, financially and otherwise. Life can be unsettling at times, but nobody can blame you if you're working hard, right? 
 You could also be stuck in a cycle of overworking to keep up with overspending, or overworking to accumulate more and more in the pursuit of some impossible level of security. 
 While it's smart to plan for tomorrow, it's not good to create an unhealthy today in the process.

DRAWER_2.TITLE: What are the potential pitfalls?
DRAWER_2.DESCRIPTION:
There are plenty of downsides to workaholism, from getting sick frequently to losing sleep. It can be hard to see what's happening when you're in the middle of it, though. 
 Consider if feeling uncomfortable with yourself outside of your professional life might be driving you to hide behind your work. A therapist or life coach could help you address those internal fears and anxieties.

DRAWER_3.TITLE: What does this mean for your relationships?
DRAWER_3.DESCRIPTION:
It doesn't matter what the world thinks of you, or what societal standards you meet. If your work-life balance is out of whack, your loved ones will be affected. Workaholism is associated with relationship problems and has even been linked with behavioral issues in children of workaholics. 
 But simple steps can begin to improve your relationships. Look your loved ones in the eye and thank them for being in your life. Give them your undivided attention when you're with them (put the cell phone down). Your life is your habits, and it may be time for some new ones. 
 Adjusting your habits in small ways can also start you toward a better work-life balance. Leave work 15 minutes earlier each day, for example. Or pick a time during the week when you'll plan to catch up on work-in exchange for more time with family the rest of the week.

DRAWER_1.TITLE: What does this mean?
DRAWER_1.DESCRIPTION:
Chances are you've always been a driven person, and you thrive on the successes that you make at work. You are also by most standards a workaholic. 
 You might know that you're overdoing it, and you may justify it by pointing out that hard work provides you with financial security. That may be true to a degree, but it's still not healthy-or satisfying-when it leads to neglecting other areas of your life. 
 While money could be a motivating factor for you, it's probably not the only reason you work so much. You might be in a cycle of over-spending, and then over-working to keep up. Or, perhaps you've managed to save for emergencies and future goals-but it never feels like enough. So you keep pouring everything you have into your work in pursuit of some future day when you'll finally be able to relax and enjoy life. 
 Finding a balance between work and life can be difficult for a lot of people. But that's not an excuse. When work is at the forefront, it stops you from being all the other things you want to be, like an attentive parent, or someone who pursues their personal passions. 
 Remember: Human beings are more than what they do.

DRAWER_2.TITLE: What are the potential pitfalls?
DRAWER_2.DESCRIPTION:
Identifying workaholism isn't easy. Chances are you're probably so used to it that it just feels normal. But losing sleep and suffering more than your share of illnesses can be side effects of the stress of working too much. 
 If your family or friends complain (or even joke) about you working too much, really listen. Do you want to keep living this way? Nobody likes change, but you don't have to do it alone. It may even help to bring in an objective third party, like a professional counselor.

DRAWER_3.TITLE: What does this mean for your relationships?
DRAWER_3.DESCRIPTION:
Working too much doesn't just affect you. Workaholism also can impact the people you're close to. It's associated with relationship problems and has even been linked with behavioral issues in children of workaholics. 
 The people you love can also play an important role in your path back from workaholism. Discuss it with family friends and get their support. Then set small, manageable goals, such as leaving work 15 minutes earlier every day. Or, look at the week ahead and plan on a time you could work more to catch up, while cutting back the rest of the week in order to spend time with your family. 
 Along the way, make a point to really invest in the time you have right now with family and friends. Put your phone away, shut down that mental reel of work worries, and really be with them mentally and emotionally when you're with them physically.

DRAWER_1.TITLE: What does this mean?
DRAWER_1.DESCRIPTION:
You keep a very watchful eye on your finances, and know exactly what's going out and what's coming in. This diligent money management gives you a sense of security and a plan for what's coming. 
 Managing money is important, and you do a good job with it. But be aware of the place it has in your life. Knowing your bank balance at all times does not necessarily mean that your life itself is in balance. Consider how healthy your relationship with money is, being as honest with yourself as you can.

DRAWER_2.TITLE: What are the potential pitfalls?
DRAWER_2.DESCRIPTION:
Because you think about money often, it's likely that your challenge is maintaining a healthy relationship with it-one where money serves your needs, but doesn't run your life. 
 It could be that keeping a close eye on your finances is simply your way of being a good manager of money. But if watching your finances takes time away from more enjoyable activities, or you find it hard to ease up even when you try, there could be underlying reasons that are unhealthy, like a fear of financial insecurity. 
 If this is true for you, consider seeking support and guidance from an outside party-perhaps even a professional-to help you re-establish the terms of your relationship with money.

DRAWER_3.TITLE: What does this mean for your relationships?
DRAWER_3.DESCRIPTION:
Being confident dealing with money is a good thing. But keep in mind that everyone isn't as comfortable with money issues as you are. 
 While you may know exactly what you can and can't afford at any given time, others in your life may not be as financially savvy. If you take the time to really listen, you may learn that the very topic of money (or things that cost money) can be stressful for many people. 
 Work to be sensitive to how those in your life handle financial issues, and seek to be a support where you can.

DRAWER_1.TITLE: What does this mean?
DRAWER_1.DESCRIPTION:
Managing money is a priority in your life. You don't have every penny earmarked, but you do have a sense of your spending, your budget and the importance of planning for the future. 
 You spend a fair amount of time making sure to balance your income and your financial needs, so missed payments and overspending aren't typically problems for you. 
 Sure, unexpected expenses crop up here and there, as they do for everyone. But because you have a plan, you generally can deal with what comes.

DRAWER_2.TITLE: What are the potential pitfalls?
DRAWER_2.DESCRIPTION:
From what you've told us, you don't seem to have any issues with keeping up with your day-to-day finances. But your long plans could be less concrete. It's never to early to think about things like retirement, buying a home, starting a family or even going on a big vacation. 
 If you already have a long-term plan, give it a check-up. Regularly reviewing your plan and your progress gives you the opportunity to adapt it as your circumstances change.

DRAWER_3.TITLE: What does this mean for your relationships?
DRAWER_3.DESCRIPTION:
Being comfortable talking about money is a good attribute. Consider if you could use your easy nature on the subject to be a supportive listening ear for those who are not as relaxed as you. 
 Being open about your financial successes (and failures) may also provide an opportunity to share the value of having a financial plan and how one can help to reduce stress.

DRAWER_1.TITLE: What does this mean?
DRAWER_1.DESCRIPTION:
You don't exactly get jazzed about managing your money, but you don't bury your head in the sand, either. 
 It's good that you check in with your finances as needed. But while getting by may be okay for now, in the long term having a plan and reviewing your finances on a regular basis can make your life better. We promise. It's not about counting every dime or planning for every pack of gum you buy. It's about being in the driver's seat of your own life, and keeping your eyes on the road. 
 It sounds like you already glance at your bank accounts periodically. To step it up, try a budget. If you have a one already, see how your real life spending matches up with what you budgeted. 
 No budget? Create one. It's a simple way to become more intentional about where you're putting your cash-and putting yourself on the path to bigger and better financial goals. (Our free Illuminate app can make this even easier.)

DRAWER_2.TITLE: What are the potential pitfalls?
DRAWER_2.DESCRIPTION:
You might waver on how you feel about dealing with your finances-from calm to not-so-calm. But beware of a tendency to be so daunted by future financial planning that you put it off. 
 Procrastination can be tempting when it comes to many things you'd rather avoid, but when it comes to planning for future financial goals, you could very literally pay the price.

DRAWER_3.TITLE: What does this mean for your relationships?
DRAWER_3.DESCRIPTION:
Keep in mind when you talk about money with others that emotions tend to be mirrored in conversations. If you feel anxious, it's likely they'll feel anxious in return. If you're calm, they're likely to be calm too. 
 Be open to conversations with those who have a vested interest in your financial present and future. Talking about life insurance or disability coverage may not be fun, but when others depend on you it's an important conversation to have. Creating a plan to live, give and save is an important step, and a good one to do with a trusted partner.

DRAWER_1.TITLE: What does this mean?
DRAWER_1.DESCRIPTION:
Let's just say money is not your favorite subject. You check your balance (very) occasionally, but for the most part, you'd rather not know. 
 Unfortunately, dodging the money subject doesn't mean you're not worrying about it. In fact it might be weighing on you quite heavily. 
 Avoidance doesn't work, though, because money matters are a part of life for almost everyone. Ignoring them won't give you peace or a sense of security. That comes from living responsibly-starting with learning to face your finances. 
 It's okay not to be an expert. Money is something that has to be learned, and many people are never taught. Explore personal finance classes available in your community, or read an article on brightpeak.com. 
 Ultimately having a good grasp on how much money you have coming in and going out each month can be a powerful step towards getting in touch with your financial situation.

DRAWER_2.TITLE: What are the potential pitfalls?
DRAWER_2.DESCRIPTION:
Not wanting to think about money can lead to procrastination-about paying off debt, saving for retirement or even opening the credit card bill that just arrived. 
 The problem: Ignoring your money situation can lead to oversights in how much money you have to spend. By avoiding reality, you could end up jeopardizing both your current and future happiness. 
 Financial denial is also associated with low self-esteem. If you feel like you have no control over your life in general, it can cause you to give up control in your financial life, too. If this sounds like you, think about what emotion is at the core of your unwillingness to face up to your finances. Is it fear of falling short? Shame that you don't know more about money?

DRAWER_3.TITLE: What does this mean for your relationships?
DRAWER_3.DESCRIPTION:
Your stress about money may have a tendency to rub off on others around you, making it hard for them to stay positive. 
 Consider instead how you might be able to work with someone you trust to gain a healthier approach to money. Could you bring up the subject of saving for future goals? Could you ask them to look with you at the retirement savings you've been avoiding?

DRAWER_1.TITLE: What does this mean?
DRAWER_1.DESCRIPTION:
Money causes you extreme anxiety. And as a result you'd do anything to avoid dealing with it. In fact, you'd rather not know than look your finances in the eye. 
 Chances are your avoidance comes down to fear. Maybe you feel like you don't deserve money or the stuff it buys. But whether you're procrastinating about future financial needs, like retirement, or just avoiding financial reality altogether, you could be jeopardizing your current and long-term happiness. 
 It's not uncommon to feel some stress around money. Increasing your financial knowledge can help. Many people have a fear about money because they've never really learned how to manage it. Something as simple as getting reliable information might make it less daunting. 
 You don't have to face it alone, either. Reach out to a family member you trust, or to a financial counselor, which you may even be able to access for free. 
 Choose today to take one small step forward-there's no need to dive into the deep end. One small step can start your momentum and help you build confidence, step by step, until you see that you can take on your money successfully.

DRAWER_2.TITLE: What are the potential pitfalls?
DRAWER_2.DESCRIPTION:
Financial denial tends to go together with high levels of credit card debt. After all, avoiding looking at your money situation can lead to oversights in how much you have to spend. 
 Know that by avoiding money, you may also be missing opportunities to grow your income or net worth. 
 Money denial is also associated with low self-esteem. Feeling like you have no control over your life could lead you to give up when it comes to your finances, too. The problem is, closing your eyes doesn't make the problems go away. 
 Consider exploring the emotions at the core of your unwillingness to face your finances with someone who can help you work through it.

DRAWER_3.TITLE: What does this mean for your relationships?
DRAWER_3.DESCRIPTION: If you're already in a relationship or married, it's important to know that the underlying money denial could cause issues in your relationship. It's tough for others to stay positive when you're constantly stressed about money.

ITEMIZED_SUMMARY.DESCRIPTION: Congrats! You've completed your detailed budget. Take a second to review all your numbers. If you need to change any amounts, this is the place to do that.
